PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

BREAK.XREF: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION (REPEALS, TRANSITIONAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Productivity Commission Bill 1996. The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether we are returning to the amendment that we deferred yesterday for discussion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having alluded to a proposal yesterday, I have had prepared by officers overnight new clauses 8(1) and (2) setting out the policy guidelines for the Productivity Commission. The new clauses are an amalgam of the two items from the bill which the government regards as most important, and items that are obviously important to the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens. These were distributed by facsimile message to the Greens, Democrats and the Labor Party at about 8 o'clock this morning. It is being distributed in the chamber now.

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadow that I intend to move the following amendment:
Delete existing clauses 8(1) and 8(2). Insert new clauses as follows.
(1) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth Government:

PARA.TAB: (a) to improve the overall economic performance of the economy through higher productivity in the public and private sectors in order to achieve higher living standards for all members of the Australian community;
(b) to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government;
(c) to encourage the development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive; and
(d) to facilitate adjustment to structural changes in the economy and the avoidance of social and economic hardships arising from those changes; and
(e) to recognise the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community, likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission; and
(f) to increase employment, including in regional areas; and
(g) to promote regional development; and
(h) to recognise the progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers; and
(i) to ensure that industry develops in a way that is ecologically sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to Australia's international obligations and commitments and any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking some clarification on the amendment that has been circulated. Did Senator Campbell forget to put `environmental' in (b), or is that a deliberate omission?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —`Ecological sustainability' is given much greater weight in (i), but I do not think it would necessarily harm the amendment to include `environmental' elsewhere. But `ecological sustainability' has been given its own item at (i). I think that the words `to ensure that industry develops in a way that is ecologically sustainable' send a lot more serious policy guideline to the commission than just having the word `environment' standing by itself. Ecological sustainability is a much more detailed message, it is a stronger guideline, and it is a concept which, since the earth summit in Rio, is broadly defined and understood by most people in public policy around the world.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The circulated amendment is unacceptable to Labor and we will not be supporting it for the reasons I advanced yesterday.
—We are currently on Senator Sherry's amendment, which had been deferred. We are dealing with opposition amendment 3, to which Senator Campbell is discussing moving an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the conclusion of yesterday's consideration of this item in the committee stage there was a proposal by the opposition senators to basically accept a list of policy guidelines. There were some proposals by the Democrats to alter them and this proposal, which I foreshadowed, was to include the key items of the opposition's proposals and the important matters contained within the bill—the old 8(a) and (c). The item under contention from the opposition's point of view was item (c). They said that they could not live with keeping the current clause in the Productivity Commission Bill. The new (b) in my proposal is specifically to reduce regulation of industry, including regulation by the states, territories and local government. That was their major bugbear, even though it was in the Labor Party's 1990 Industry Commission Act.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also included concerns raised by the Greens and the Democrats. So it is a compendium that seeks to create a consensus. I will move that amendment formally. Procedurally, if this amendment is passed it would make redundant Senator Sherry's proposed amendment. It already includes the amendment of the Democrats and the proposal of the Greens so it would probably make any further amendments unnecessary. I am formally foreshadowing that I intend to move my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of procedure. I understand that I have moved my amendment. I understand that that should be put first, shouldn't it?
—Yes. For Senator Campbell's amendment to be put, you would have to withdraw yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to. In the opening line of Senator Campbell's proposed new amendment it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission must have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth Government:
Ours is differently worded in that it says:
In the performance of its functions, the Commission must give priority to:
So ours is more clearly an instruction on policy guidelines to the commission rather than having regard to the desire of the Commonwealth government, and we see that as important.
The government's new paragraph (b) reads:
to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government.
I would just reiterate that we see that it is undesirable for that to continue to be a policy guideline for the commission, for the reasons I outlined yesterday.

Firstly, to some extent the old powers of the Industry Commission were superseded by the National Competition Council in its role, and it is carrying out that role adequately. Secondly, given the greatly enhanced functions of the Productivity Commission that this Senate has approved, we do not believe that, as a subsidiary objective of those functions, it is desirable for that proposed government paragraph (b) to continue. They are the reasons why we will be putting our amendment rather than supporting the government's compromise amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a new item in the debate. Yesterday, the opposition said that they were not going to support this because we had retained the old 8(c) from the Industry Com mission Act—an act of the former Labor government. Now they are saying that they will not accept it because we are again adopting the wording from the Industry Commission Act of the Labor government in the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What they ask this Senate to do is to give an inane and stupid direction to the new Productivity Commission. It is a quite silly thing to do. If you said to a four‐year‐old child, `I want you to give priority to this—I want you to go and clean up your toys,' you might be lucky and your four‐ or five‐year‐old will go and clean up his toys. But if you say to your four‐ or five‐year‐old, `I want you to give priority to cleaning up your toys, going out and cleaning up the garden, tidying up your room, helping mum do the dishes' and three other things at once, your four‐ or five‐year‐old would probably get confused.

What these people on the other side would say is, `Look, we had it all wrong in 1990 when we created the Industry Commission Act. We shouldn't have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth to do these important things. You've got to give priority to all seven of them, regardless of whether there is some conflict between each one of those seven.' What you are really saying is, `Let's not be serious about it at all. Let's just destroy the meaning of the whole thing.'

It is quite sensible, as the previous government's Industry Commission Act said, to have regard to the desirability of doing these things. To say that you have got to give priority to seven things is just plain stupid, inane, and probably typical of the Australian Labor Party's general performance on economic matters since they came into government.

Senator Sherry did not come in here in his six years in government and say, `We can't live with this. We are going to have to amend this. The government is going to amend its Industry Commission Act because the Industry Commission doesn't work because it can only give regard to the desire of the government to do these things.' He did not do that. He was the parliamentary secretary for a few years. He was in an important position. He did not come in and amend the Industry Commission Act. But now he is saying, `We won't accept this because it's not good enough.' The hypocrisy is absolutely overwhelming, Senator Sherry. You should be ashamed of yourself, and so should your government.

It is not good enough to say, `We are going to live and die by this amendment because you will not give priority to this instead of having a sensible clause,' as was in your own act—the previous government's act. The Australian Labor Party is becoming a sad joke on economic matters; it really is. It has no credibility.

I put it to you, Madam Chair, that the wording in the proposal sought in a very genuine way to create a consensus on this issue. It pulled in the concerns of the Democrats and the Greens and accommodated all of Senator Sherry's proposals. He just keeps coming up with these little reasons why he wants to oppose it. It is churlish. It is childish. It is a dog in the manger sort of attitude. Senator Sherry, reconsider your position and get serious on this. If you were really serious, you would have changed your Industry Commission Act any time in the last six years when you were in this place.

It is just stupid to give priority to seven different things that can often be conflicting. I am sure that Senator Harradine and Senator Murray will not play your game. They are not people who are stupid or inane. I hope that they will see the genuineness of my proposal and will support it. I urge you to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell obviously got out of bed on the wrong side this morning. Maybe he needs a cigarette; I should oblige him.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons I have advanced this morning as to our concern with the government's proposal are entirely consistent with the reasons I advanced yesterday. Senator Campbell, we do take this legislation seriously, because we take the current economic problems facing Australia very seriously. I think even you would agree that we have a new range of circumstances in economic policy because we have a new government with a new set of priorities.

BREAK.PARA: We have in front of us a new Productivity Commission Bill which attempts, unfortunately, to combine all of the features of the three organisations it seeks to replace. I submit to the Senate that I do not think that it is inane or stupid to insist, as Labor has done, that the policy guidelines for the new commission should include growth in employment in regional areas, promotion of regional development, Australia's international obligations and progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non‐tariff barriers. I do not think that that is an inane or stupid approach.

We had some comment about the National Party's role, or lack of it, in this debate yesterday. I do not think Senator Boswell would regard our insistence on priorities such as growth and employment, including that of regional areas, and the promotion of regional development as inane or stupid. I look forward to Senator Boswell voting for our amendment in this regard, because I know how important the National Party rates issues in respect of regional areas and the promotion of regional development. I look forward to his contribution and support in this debate.

As I said yesterday, I pay tribute to Senator Boswell and his party as being the last true socialist party in this country. I think that is something we should recognise and get clearly on the record. I hope Senator Boswell will participate in this debate. I am pleased he is here this morning to follow this debate very closely, to expose the way in which Senator Campbell and the government are attempting to hoodwink the National Party. I know on many occasions Senator Boswell has stood up for regional Australia. I hope he recognises that in his contribution to this debate on the Productivity Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, I thought your remarks to Senator Sherry were a little intemperate. For my part—and I have had some very long debates with him—I have not ever found him stupid or inane. Sometimes he can be difficult and determined, but stupid and inane are not the words I would have used to describe him.

BREAK.PARA: With the permission of the chair, I think we need to debate both suggestions concurrently because they are alternates. Senator Campbell, I would indicate to you that it is our belief that you have gone a very long way to reaching the requests of the four parties that have put a view on this matter before the Senate. My one determination would be that you would look at your first line and take out `desire of the Commonwealth Government' and replace it with the word `need'.

I think Senator Sherry has made the right comment, as have other participants in the debate, that as far as possible the Productivity Commission should be giving independent advice and should not be seen to be unnecessarily subservient to the wishes of the government of the day. Obviously they have to take into consideration their opinions, but most of all they have to have regard to the needs of the entire economy as well as the government.

If Senator Campbell is happy to accept that change, we would then be happy to swing behind his amendment. We would request that Senator Sherry looks to amend his amendment if there are further words that he believes are desirable. We would certainly accept it as he has put it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is happy to accept that suggestion for change. I will amend my foreshadowed motion to delete the word `desire of the Commonwealth Government' and replace it with the word `need'. I think that is a sensible suggestion, Senator Murray. In my example of trying to give priority to seven things, when you prioritise things, you generally create a list of importance. We do that for legislation. We decide what is the priority legislation for the week or the month or the year. When we prioritise tasks in our private lives we do that. Necessarily, one comes on top and others come down the bottom.

SPEECH.PARA: In our lives and in our public policy we also look at needs, and needs can compete. I think priorities also compete, but ultimately you have to give something priority. You could suggest that regional development comes second last, as it did under Labor's proposal in terms of priority. We do not necessarily think you should do that. You should look at all of the competing needs and make rational, sensible judgments on those needs. Needs can compete, and that is a sensible suggestion which the government will support. I hope other senators will support it. You can have competing needs, but to give priority to seven different things is silly. It cannot be done. We will support this.

Senator Boswell, the coalition's proposal explicitly talks about regional needs, regional employment and the promotion of regional development. I think Senator Sherry might have been mischievously seeking to mislead our coalition partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does it regularly.
—I hope you will support this very sensible amendment, Senator Boswell.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Sherry's) negatived.
Amendment, as amended, (by Senator Campbell) proposed:
Clause 8, page 5 (line 13) to page 6 (line 3), omit the clause, substitute:
(1) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the need:

PARA.TAB: (a) to improve the overall economic performance of the economy through higher productivity in the public and private sectors in order to achieve higher living standards for all members of the Australian community;
(b) to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government;
(c) to encourage the development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive; and
(d) to facilitate adjustment to structural changes in the economy and the avoidance of social and economic hardships arising from those changes; and
(e) to recognise the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community, likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission; and
(f) to increase employment, including in regional areas; and
(g) to promote regional development; and
(h) to recognise the progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers; and
(i) to ensure that industry develops in a way that is ecologically sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak before we go to a vote, if I may. I was glancing at my notes and suddenly felt the cold wind of termination coming over me.

SPEECH.PARA: We thought that the original section 8 would have deliberately twisted, or had the potential to deliberately twist, the Productivity Commission to an even harder Right agenda than it has had. Paragraphs—such as those about deregulation, facilitation of structural change and the assumption that there would be hardship—that almost ignore environmental and ecological consequences were dangers which lay in the section.

Consequently, we welcome the government's determination now to give the Productivity Commission a much more positive agenda, particularly looking at avoiding hardship, particularly engaging in matters of regional development, particularly engaging in job advancement, and particularly—and this our party would stress—giving priority to the area of long-term ecological sustainability.

It is absolutely vital that the Productivity Commission begin to understand that social community and environmental needs are more important than economic ones. They come first. Economics must serve society; not the other way around. That is all I wish to say on our support for the government amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out that, despite my concerns yesterday, Australia's international obligations got the chop. That is of great concern, and it will continue to be so every time it happens within this parliamentary process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just wondering where this question of Australia's international obligations fits within the government's amendment. It has here `to recognise the progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers'. But I cannot see anything there about Australia's international obligations. There are a whole range of obligations that Australia does have which go not only to human rights questions but also to the very issues of trading.

SPEECH.PARA: We must be aware and conscious of the fact that in many ways we do have obligations to the less developed countries, and we must be conscious of those obligations. Obviously, we do not want to get into a situation in this whole trading area which would be similar to that which occurred before the last war, for example, where the developed world put huge barriers up against trade from other countries.

Just as priority here is given to developing our own industries, and so on, you have to strike a balance. But we do have to have regard, I believe, to our obligations internationally, and I agree with what Senator Margetts has said. I do not know whether there is somewhere in that particular proposal, as put forward by Senator Campbell from the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Item 2.

—I am looking at that item. Yes, it states `must also have regard to Australia's international obligations and commitments'. That has been included. I see what you have said. I come back to the point of item (b):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government;

I know that you will say that that was in the Industry Commission Act; that would be your response. But I am somewhat concerned—and you might be able to inform the committee, Minister—that this might be utilised to advance certain agendas that a Commonwealth government might have now or in the future.

An example would be if the commission were to be required to look into the informa tion technology area, and the government's view was one of deregulation or industry self-regulation—and `industry self-regulation' is a catch phrase. If that is the government's viewpoint, would the commission then proceed in recommending the dismantling of state and territory regulations, indeed Commonwealth regulations, which go to the standards that should apply to content on communications technologies?

This is a very, very real matter at the present moment. It may be alluded to in the next piece of legislation that comes before us: the broadcasting services legislation. I just ask the minister to consider what I have said and to express a view on behalf of the government to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question of the content, in technology matters such as that, it is up to the Commonwealth government to decide where it has jurisdiction and to the state governments to decide where they have jurisdiction, and nothing in this act could change that.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the question on the international obligation, I have drawn your attention to clause 8(2), which says:
In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to Australia's international obligations and commitments and any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.

It may well be better, now that we have changed the word at the top of 8(1) to `need' as opposed to `desire of the Commonwealth Government', to make the international obligations part of 8(1). It might also suit the ends of Senator Margetts if we were to do so.

I am having a piece of paper circulated which will put this more succinctly than I can put it in words, but, effectively, my proposal makes the international obligations part become 8(1)(j). So 8(1)(j) would read:
for Australia to meet its international obligations and commitments
and then 8(2) would become:
In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.
I think that would make it tidier. I see a few nods around the place so I seek leave to amend my amendment.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I amend my amendment as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of subclause 8(1), add:

PARA.TAB: ; and (j) for Australia to meet its international obligations and

SPEECH.PARA: Omit subclause 8(2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 13, page 10 (lines 3 to 8), omit the clause, substitute:

TAB.TAB: As soon as practicable after the Commission receives a reference to hold an inquiry, it must give reasonable notice in each State and internal Territory, by advertisement published in a newspaper circulating in the State or Territory, of its intention to hold the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 14, page 10 (lines 9 to 15), omit the clause, substitute:

TAB.TAB: Before the Commission begins to hold hearings for the purposes of an inquiry, it must give reasonable notice in each State and internal Territory, by advertisement published in a newspaper circulating in the State or Territory, of its intention to hold the hearings, the subject of the hearings and the time and place at which the first of the hearings is to be begun.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment (6) deals with the notice provision in clause 13. We believe that the notice provision in the new bill is manifestly inadequate. The public notice provisions which currently apply—I would like to emphasise `currently apply' to Senator Campbell—to the Industry Commission in the new bill are being downgraded so that the nature of the notice given to the public is purely within the discretion of the commission. We believe this is unacceptable.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment (6) proposes to reintroduce the minimum notice standards which apply in the case of the Industry Commission. Senator Campbell may explain why he wishes to change the rules which, at least in respect to the notice provision, have worked well up until now. We do not believe it is appropriate that the commission could fail to give proper notice to interested stakeholders and members of the public.

In respect of amendment (7), in a similar vein to amendment (6), this amendment proposes to ensure that proper notice of hearings is guaranteed to members of the public and to stakeholders. I wish to stress that this amendment does not in any manner limit the type of notice that the commission can give; it merely prescribes reasonable minimum standards which must be complied with. The commission may, in fact, choose to give additional notice if it wishes. For example, the commission may choose to advertise scheduled hearings on their Web site or by some other electronic means. That option will remain if our amendments (6) and (7) are passed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill seeks to provide a more flexible way of notifying inquiries, including through advertising. This amendment would narrow some of the options available under the bill. The amendment moved by Senator Sherry just reverts to the Industry Commission Act. The government would prefer to have more flexibility in these matters and would ask the Senate to support the provisions of the bill.

—It is hard to work out a situation where there would be a commission inquiry, which might have the ability to make fairly far‐reaching recommendations, where it would not be advisable or desirable for notice to be given. You would wonder what kind of inquiry would be so urgent that it would be necessary to act without people being given notice. Could the minister give some indication of what kind of circumstance he could envisage where it would be necessary for the commission—which now has a lot of power and will be given more power, and scope, than the Industry Commission had—to conduct an inquiry which it would not be advisable to give notice of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that all inquiries would be made public. It is not a matter of making them public; it is a matter of the means. This bill seeks to give the commission flexibility as to how the inquiry is made public and through which means. As you know, Senator Margetts, from your own experience on Senate committees, sometimes putting ads in national and regional newspapers is the appropriate way to do it. At other times, it is more appropriate just to send letters to the key organisations involved. The bill really is seeking to provide the commission with that flexibility, which will add to the practicality and efficiency of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, the government is not proposing to spend much time debating this. That is the reason for it; we think it is a sensible provision. The opposition's proposal takes it back to the Industry Commission's existing proposals. But that is the reason. All inquiries would be public; it is just a matter of the means used for notifying people. We seek to ensure that that can be done in a way that is most efficient and that is appropriate to that particular inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —With all due respect, Parliamentary Secretary, this is not the parliament. It is not open to the scrutiny of the parliament in that way and the `round up the usual suspects' method of inquiry is not acceptable when you have an organisation which is making major recommendations to government on the way industry operates. I cannot see that you have justified your point here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just conclude my remarks by saying that we are not attempting to limit flexibility. I am always suspicious when the government resorts to these arguments about choice and flexibility. What we are attempting to ensure is that there will still be the same flexibility but there will also be a minimum standard preserved. The minimum standard is the advertisement that we have moved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the issues that are included in the amendments to clause 13 and clause 14 are the same, and that those two items be dealt with together; that is, amendments 6 and 7. That would speed things along.

—The Democrats will support Labor's amendments 6 and 7. We think they are important amendments because they require the maximisation of public input into Productivity Commission inquiries and this, in our opinion, has been one of the positive aspects of Industry Commission procedure. The inquiries are public, a draft report is put out for public comment and then, and only then, is it reported. We think the process should be opened up even more—as I am sure Senator Margetts would agree—and not contracted, as this bill seems to allow it to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry made the point perfectly well that what is required by these amendments is a minimum obligation on the part of the commission and, as such, I support it. It does not inhibit in any way, as I see it, the commission from writing to the `usual suspects', to use Senator Margetts's words.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—(10.11 a.m.)—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 6, page 4 (lines 8 to 26), omit "matters relating to industry and productivity" (wherever occurring), substitute "matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity".
(2) Clause 20, page 13 (lines 12 and 13), omit "matters relating to industry and productivity", substitute "matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity".
These amendments are consequential to those changes that we made yesterday by including the word `industry' before `industry development'.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —A natural mistake was that the committee felt that clause 8 had been completed but in fact it had not. If I can draw senators' attention to sheet 612, amendment No. 3, after No. (2) of clause 8, the Democrats have recommended an amendment to the Senate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 8, page 6 (after line 3), at the end of the clause, add:

(3) The Commission, in all of its reports and assessments, must provide a variety of viewpoints and options, representing alternative means of addressing the issues before it and, if any economic modelling is relied on in a report, must utilise at least two different economic models with the assumptions and results of these models made explicit.

We considered the ecological amendments that we were seeking yesterday as being absolutely vital to us. But this is probably the most important amendment that we are moving in this debate. It will require the Productivity Commission to shed what we regard as its one‐eyed ideological approach to report writing. It will require it to provide alternative sets of recommendations and alternative modelling to what we consider as the very discredited ORANI model, and to provide full explanations of any assumptions used.

Senators would recall the publicity surrounding the car tariffs decision, when three models came into the debate and contributed very well to a far more reasonable appraisal of the alternatives which faced the government in its decision making and, in our belief, assisted the government to come to a decision which was helpful to that industry. The Industry Commission, in our view, has not been notorious for being open to new ideas or alternative theories or to any viewpoint that does not fit with its particular ideology. The ORANI model has, time and again, been found to be biased towards supporting its ideological positions. We feel it has become a weapon rather than a tool. Our amendment does not say that you may not use the ORANI model; it does say that you must take into account other models.

BREAK.PARA: This amendment will require the Productivity Commission to become more inclusive in its reporting—not just to dismiss alternatives and to put up different modelling results. This amendment, more than any other that we will move, will require the Productivity Commission, with all the massive powers this bill gives it, to change the way it operates and to not just become bigger and uglier but to develop as a broader church, to use the Prime Minister's favourite phrase, a forum for ideas and alternatives. We think that is what Australia needs from the new Industry Commission—not a $25 million ideological public relations, right‐wing firm. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will be supporting the amendment, for the reasons Senator Murray outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —A really interesting image is emerging of a model being a bit like a science fiction creature that becomes huge and very powerful. We have seen the examples of both ORANI and megABARE in recent times, where the model is used as a tool to beat people over the head. The publicly funded organisations—and, as we found out later, privately funded but directed by private interest as well—do not necessarily have to come up with these models by themselves: there are people working on models within the community. Surely one of the roles of such organisations is to seek out those who have alternative models within the community and give critiques of those as well. That is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear what the Greens (WA) view of this proposal for the Productivity Commission is but, if we are going to spend public money in propping up yet another major rationalist think‐tank, the very least that we ought to do is to get them to work as a think‐tank and not as a single‐minded body in pursuit of a particular end no matter what the evidence may be. In the words of Shakespeare, `There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy.' Horatio ought to realise that he has to do some more work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would regard this as a message to the commission—and not an unreasonable message. Whether it should be put in black letter law and become a mandatory requirement is debatable. I think it would be unnecessarily restrictive. Clearly, from the indications from senators speaking to this amendment, it has support. However, there is one serious problem with it, and that is that to require under statute that the commission utilise at least two different economic models—
—If they use a model; they can choose not to.

—Exactly. Senator Margetts makes a point that I think reinforces the point I seek to make. They may choose not to use economic models in an inquiry. If they are mandatorily required to use at least two economic models in an inquiry where there may only be one economic model—and I have to say that I have never used an economic model in my life—
—Very dangerous things.

—I know. I have heard you talking about them a lot. ORANI sounds like something you go down to Toys R Us and buy—a model of the USS Orani . On a rainy day when you have got the flu and are staying home from school, you sit putting together the little cannons and aircraft carrier pieces of the USS Orani .

SPEECH.PARA: Seriously; it could create practical difficulties, both from the perspective that, if there was a model that was appropriate for a particular inquiry, you might be forced to use another model that was inappropriate, because the law said you had to. Or you might be forced, because of the law, to develop a whole new model, just to comply with this fairly strict, black letter, legalistic determination.

I had not thought of this before you interjected, Senator Margetts but, where you might want to use a model for good reasons and, because of this law, quite properly say that the assumptions and the results be explicit—I think that is a good idea—you might, because you are required to use two models, decide not to use any at all, even though a model could be useful in what you are doing. So I think it does create practical difficulties. I ask Senator Murray if he would consider including in the second last line of clause 8(3) of his proposed amendment the words `wherever practical' after the word `must' and before the words `use two economic models.' That still sends a clear message but it does get over those problems.
We do not like the clause. We will be voting against it. We could live with it, but it would make it a lot more livable if there was a recognition of the practical problems I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, Parliamentary Secretary you do make some sensible and helpful observations. In this place we all know that economics is an art and modelling is a very dangerous weapon in the wrong hands, if it is not independently, objectively and honestly used—because of the hackneyed but very true saying that, if you stick the garbage in, you are going to get the garbage out.

SPEECH.PARA: I think your argument is weakened, Parliamentary Secretary, by the fact that you are now reverting to one source of advice to the government. You no longer have a variety of sources. This is a consolidated commission and, apart from external sources of advice, it will provide the prime source of information and calculation for government opinions on various industry matters. It is because there are not going to be competing models available from competing agencies within government that we think we should make it mandatory that, where you use a modelling process, you use at least two models.

I should remind the Senate of the importance of models in the car debate and, frankly, presently in the greenhouse debate. In the car debate it was claimed that, according to those models, savings ranging from in excess of $2,000 to $80 per vehicle would result. Until such time as the alternative private sector models were made available, consumers were led up the garden path of believing that the ORANI version would result in these huge benefits to consumers, whereas other models regarded that approach as just a myth.

Because very few ministers or departments have the time or the energy or the experience to evaluate mathematical models at length, the government does need alternative modelling available. So what would otherwise normally be a sensible suggestion to give you some flexibility I think in this case would gut the intention of our amendment, which is to require the commission to deliberately and actively consult alternative models.

The parliamentary secretary says it will be difficult for the commission to have access to alternative models. I think—and I do not mean this in any unkind way—the government's inexperience shows in that the process of constructing models is quite widely available and used by professional commercial houses, by universities and indeed by the Industry Commission. I would suggest that their fears are a little unfounded. I hope that those responses will persuade those senators who have not indicated their position to support our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this amendment that has been moved by Senator Murray is commendable. It is something that one looks for in parliamentary reports—different attitudes being expressed with the facts set down and I suppose the various reports coming from different points of view—not only in the economics area but also in the social area.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliamentary secretary, however, has indicated that he, too, recognises this amendment as being a message given legislatively to the commission to ensure that those viewpoints and opinions are thoroughly expressed. As Senator Murray's amendment says:
The Commission, in all of its reports and assessments, must provide a variety of viewpoints and options, representing alternative means of addressing the issues before it . . .
If carried, this will be a legislative requirement imposed on the commission with which we agree. From what I heard the parliamentary secretary say, the government would agree with that as well.

BREAK.PARA: I think he has raised a practical point in respect of where the commission would have to refer to a particular economic viewpoint—you can call it modelling, viewpoint, option or whatever you will—which, on my reading of the first part of the amendment, represents alternative means. As the parliamentary secretary said, for economic modelling it should be applied where practical. I have no real problem with that.

Obviously, the clear intention of the parliament is expressed by the bulk of this amendment. The parliamentary secretary has explained to the committee that he foresees some need to insert `wherever practical' for particular circumstances. I would like the parliamentary secretary to give the committee a practical example of which he might be thinking. If he is able to give some sorts of practical circumstances where that might apply, then I see no harm in agreeing to those two words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put a viewpoint based on a heretical standpoint in relation to economic modelling. My standpoint comes from studying most of my economics at the University of East Anglia. The advisers seem to think that is funny. The University of East Anglia looked at economics from the viewpoint that it is not a science—and it is not. It is not even a social science. It is actually a theoretical construct, and it actually also is very much based on what philosophical viewpoint you come from.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of development studies, economics could be looked at from a variety of different viewpoints depending on where you start in your assumption. You could actually have, and we did have, an economics text which was written in three columns which looked at three different theories of economics. Every issue that is brought up with an economic theory can be looked at depending on what your basic assumption is—what the causal factor is and what the outcome is.

If you assume that there is only one model, you are actually saying that economics is some sort of science. As far as I am concerned, it is a science only in terms of the science of alchemy. You can have the old story about light bulbs and economists. You have as many theories, in reality, as you have economists—and sometimes more. The reality is we cannot put into legislation some assumption that there is one theory and one way and that somehow or other economics is a mathematical science. It is not. There are some ways of describing what we know. There are never ways of proving what we know within economics. It is not that kind of study.

I think if we assume that there ever can be a situation where there is only one way of modelling, it is the assumption that classical economics is the only way of looking at things. A number of years ago I was talking to a lecturer in economics at the University of Western Australia. I said, `Look, it is extraordinary to me that those people who have never been out of the system teach Keynesian economics as if it is a branch of classical economics.' This chap never had been out of the system. He looked at me and said, `It is, isn't it?'

That is what we are suggesting here today: that somehow or other, economics is something that can tell us what to do; that it is some sort of science that can be put into a mathematical formula and that there is a right formula—that there can be a right formula that applies to a particular situation. I would firmly and vociferously say that it is always a theoretical construct and your assumptions will differ depending on which angle you take it from. On the cost of production, do you take classical economics, Marxist or Keynesian economics? Depending on which angle you come from, the causes and outcomes will differ; and to assume anything else is alchemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —To reinforce the point, Senator Harradine, I pick up on what Senator Margetts said. There can be no one model that creates the perfect picture of the world. Otherwise, there would never be an economic problem in the world; we would have this perfect model that takes into account everything that happens, including natural disasters and man‐made disasters. So I generally agree with her on that. I might be able to classify myself as an East Anglian school economist; one thing I never want to be called is an economist. In relation to Senator Murray's amendment, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "must utilise", substitute "must wherever practicable utilise".

Speaking to that amendment to Senator Murray's amendment, I profess not to be a great expert on all the different economic models and how they are made, Senator Murray, but I do have a broad concept of what makes up an economic model. I agree that there are a whole range of different economic models available from private sector economic organisations—which I have referred to a number of times over the last couple of days—and from universities.

I think it was the Monash model that was used for the car industry inquiry. The point is that there is a range of advice available to the government now from the emerging range of private sector economic organisations and from universities. To say that this is consolidating all the government's advice ignores the fact that EPAC had been run down under the previous government to a staff of about 10. It also ignores the fact that BIE was never a statutory organisation. It was not an independent organisation; it was a division under the industry portfolio.

It ignores the fact that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) and the government can create—and do create—their own economic advice within the industry department. It may not have its own letterhead or its own quasi‐organisation, but it can create that advice—and I am sure that that occurs on a daily basis. It ignores the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his department can get advice, from any of those places that you identified or from within their own departmental sources, to challenge the Productivity Commission or to challenge the view of Treasury. That is a natural, healthy debate that occurs within the hallowed walls of government on a daily basis, particularly on matters such as the car industry and the TCF matters that will be before the government shortly.

BREAK.PARA: To focus on the question that you ask, `What is a practical example?' there will be an off‐the‐shelf model that is most appropriate in considering a particular inquiry. In relation to the car inquiry it was regarded by the commission that the Monash one was the best. Others would say that there are other models that may have been more appropriate, but there will be specific inquiries where a model that is available will be the most appropriate model to use. To be forced legislatively to go out to a university or another private sector organisation and say, `Under clause 8(3) of this new Productivity Commission Bill we have to have two models is not practical; can you develop us a model or can we buy some other model even though, because of the equations contained in it, it is not particularly suitable to that inquiry, be it on a forest, TCF, cars, electricity, gas or any other area?' on the face of it, imposes an inefficiency, a requirement for the commission to go off and do something it does not, practically, need to do, particularly when the government has accepted that Senator Murray's proposal that the assumptions in and the results of the model, and the economic modelling relied on in the report, be made explicit.

Putting some sunlight on that whole process ensures that we will be able to say, `Was the model that was used any good?' What we are saying is that there will be, and there are, obvious practical examples of where forcing the commission to go out and buy another model from some other supplier or have one created adds expense unnecessarily. So I would ask you to support the sensible requirement that it do so wherever practicable.

It does not weaken the intent of the amendment, Senator Murray. I think it maintains its entire integrity. All it says is that there is a practical recognition of different circumstances. They would be actually breaking the law if, where it was practicable to get another model, they did not do so. If what you say is correct—and I have no doubt that it is—it will be practicable in many circumstances. I do not think it weakens the integrity of your amendment; and I urge support for my proposal to amend that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your remarks, Parliamentary Secretary. They were very helpful. Senator Harradine, if to win your support you suggest that I accept the government amendment, I will of course be willing to do so. I would prefer not to, but if that is the will of the Senate, I would certainly accept it on that basis.
—The question is that Senator Campbell's amendment to Senator Murray's amendment be agreed to.
—The question now is that Senator Murray's amendment, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes division 1, part 4, in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Part 4, Division 1, page 12 (line 2) to page 13 (line 18), TO BE OPPOSED .

Amendment 8 relates back to our general position that the commission should remain as a specific reference body. I have discussed this in amendment 2. The amendment seeks to delete division 1 of part 4. The basis of the amendment is simply that we do not support the commission extending its functions beyond those currently performed by the Industry Commission.

I have sought to amend clause 6 of the bill to delete the additional functions. This amendment complements that earlier amendment by removing what we had hoped would be redundant provisions. That argument was not accepted by the Senate, so I do not intend to argue any more on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government would have to point out to the Senate at this stage that we cannot see the sense in deleting this section, which is really linked intrinsically to the functions which the Senate has already agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose division 2, part 4, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Part 4, Division 2, page 14 (line 2) to page 17 (line 11), TO BE OPPOSED .

Labor does not support the commission gaining a role in the complaints process for the competitive neutrality regime. We were particularly surprised that this new function was included with respect to the Productivity Commission. We do not believe that this has anything to do with what is essentially an academic research body. There is already a specialist Commonwealth regulator, the ACCC, which is obviously the appropriate body to undertake the competitive neutrality investigation function. The ACCC has vast experience in administering competition policy. It is a specialist body in the competition area—it is not a general research body—so it should undertake this function, not the Productivity Commission.

In one respect we are slightly amused by the government's proposal because it would seem to the opposition that it is completely contrary to the type of recommendation that the commission would actually make. There are conflicting approaches. It is an example of inappropriate functions being proposed to be given to the commission, which are not complementary and which may even conflict with its research functions. This is a function that should be undertaken, but the commission is clearly not the appropriate body.

In respect of clause 10(4), that subclause mandates inclusion in the annual report of details of the competitive neutrality investigation activity of the commission during the year. Since we wish to transfer the competitive neutrality role to the ACCC, the provision concerning reporting in the annual report would become redundant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually think that this proposal of the government is monstrous. It is monstrous especially when you think that currently before the Senate there is a proposal to look into the socioeconomic impacts of competition policy. That simply has not been done, yet here we are talking about putting in a very powerful body without much access to the parliamentary process to be looking at virtually regulating competitive neutrality.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just not supportable. It is appalling and I do not think it should be supported in any way. I give notice that I will not be supporting Labor's proposal to put it into the ACCC either. I do not think there is any way this parliament should do that without looking at the socioeconomic impacts of what we set in train in relation to competition policy. What basis of the so-called concept of neutrality is under law and why should we be jumping into that?

Why should we not be looking at such things as the outcomes for real people and not putting the emphasis on some sort of artificial concept of competitive neutrality that someone has dreamed up because private industry thinks that they should push out any basis of accountability of services provision by governments? There is no way in the world I would support the government's proposal. I will definitely be supporting the opposition's amendment 9 and the new amendment 2 on page 632.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point that, again, this amendment proposed by the opposition does tend to ignore the fact that the Senate yesterday voted under 6(c) that the functions of the commission are, `on and after 1 July 1997, to receive and investigate complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements in relation to Commonwealth government businesses and business activities and to report to the minister on its investigations'. These provisions we are now debating—and we are debating a motion to delete all these provisions which are on pages 14, 15, 16 and 17 of the bill‐ set up the legislative constraints on how the commission would receive and run such inquiries. The Senate has already agreed to give the commission the power to do this, so that debate has been had. These provisions seek to tell the commission how it could go about doing those things.

SPEECH.PARA: We could have a debate about whether setting up a complaints mechanism, which the Commonwealth under the previous Labor government agreed it would do with the states, is a good thing. I think most small businesses that have had their businesses ruined by unfair competition from a Commonwealth government business or some other government business would regard this as a very sensible move. I think the previous Labor government saw this as a very important thing to do. So there was bipartisanship on that concept. The Labor Party said that it should go off to the ACCC. We are saying that it is appropriate that it be done here. Either way, the Senate has agreed to give the commission this power. We agreed to that yesterday, I think.

So all this part does is to say, `Now that it has this function, how should it fulfil the function?' This part, if anything, constrains the commission in how it would run the operations. If you were to delete this provision, and I have not taken high-level legal advice on this, I would think that the commission would have this function and it could make up its own mind how it would run the inquiries. With the amount of trust that has been evident around the Senate in the past couple of days about the commission being allowed to do anything it wants, I suspect the Senate would probably want to seek to give it some guidelines and constraints in the law as to how it would conduct those inquiries, and this is just what part 4 does. The same argument that clearly convinced Senator Sherry to withdraw his amendment No. 8, I think it was, applies to this one. We have already given a function to do these inquiries. This part ensures that it does so in a way that is controlled by the provisions in the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary. He has probably given a very good reason why this bill is looking more and more unacceptable as a total.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats intend to support Labor on this one, although, as they would be aware, for entirely different reasons. As Senator Kernot made clear in her speech in the second reading debate, the Democrats do not regard competitive neutrali ty disputes as real disputes. We recognise that that language and those requirements are out there in the public domain. But, with regard to the public sector, we do not believe it has any competitive advantage over the private sector. We do not think that it is a bad thing for the public sector to be providing a comprehensive service, even when it does so exclusively.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions of this part, in our view, are deliberately unbalanced and are biased towards forcing the public sector to cede more and more functions to the private sector. We stridently oppose these provisions as anti-public sector, inappropriate and poor policy. Poor competitive neutrality principles have already, in our view, cost thousands of public sector jobs and seen working conditions reduced.

Let us not forget, Senator Sherry, that competitive neutrality was a Labor invention. It was a Labor invention that destroyed jobs, stripped services, introduced far too much contracting out and introduced unnecessary privatisation. The whole rationale, and it is one of the reasons why we feel so strongly about the Productivity Commission's record, was based on a terribly flawed Industry Commission report—you remember, the one that promised $25 billion worth of benefits from the competition policy that it laid out. That was the report which, amongst others, Professor John Quiggin found riddled with double counting errors, broad brush assumptions and other errors and inaccuracies. He found that the so-called benefit of $25 billion would be barely one‐twentieth of that claimed. That is still a lot of money, but was that money worth all the jobs destroyed, the services stripped and all the horror that was caused in our economy? Yet that was the rationale for pursuing current competition policy and the flawed competitive neutrality. So I am in accord with Senator Margetts's great concern over this particular ideological view and we will support Labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, this amendment has the effect of making the ACCC rather than the Productivity Commission—
—No.
—It will.
—That's the intention.

—That is the intention. I am sorry; not this amendment. You are right, Senator Margetts. If I can debate it in the context of what is intended by the mover of the motion: as I said, it is part of making the ACCC rather than the Productivity Commission the responsible body for inquiring into competitive neutrality complaints. Senator Murray made the point that it was the previous government's policy to commit itself to the concept of competitive neutrality. Yes, that is true. I am sure it was not the previous government's policy to see that implemented in such a way that would disadvantage many people in the government business enterprise area or the government departmental area.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are not going to accept what is in the legislation here, and that is what the amendment is saying, it does not affect the functions of the Productivity Commission. It can do that in any event. Rather than being required to do the things that the parliament is suggesting that it does in the bill, in the division we are talking about, it will simply allow the Treasurer to write off a reference to the commission and sign it off. It might be the lesser of two evils but it is better for us to follow what is contained in the legislation. It at least sets down certain provisions which the commission is obliged to follow.

On the question of whether competitive controversy matters go to the ACCC as against the Productivity Commission, the latter is an advisory body; the former is the body which pursues firms which may be breaching the law. Competitive neutrality issues do not necessarily mean that the firms are breaching the law. There may be remedies. There may be means of ensuring the principles of competitive neutrality. The effect of this in regard to providing more reasonable services at a cheaper cost to the consumer can probably be solved in a number of ways by the recommendations of the Productivity Commission as distinct from the straitjacket in which the ACCC finds itself. So I suppose on that basis there are reasonable grounds to suggest that it ought to be a function of the Productivity Commission rather than the ACCC.

Suggestions have been made about the competitive neutrality of government business enterprises. That works the other way as well. Under these provisions the government business enterprises could complain about private firms who may be offending against the competitive neutrality principles. I see that as somewhat of a plus. So, overall it is my intention to support the provisions of the bill. It is better to do that than simply allow the Treasurer to run the show; in other words, to determine what are to be the guidelines in any inquiry that he may refer to the Productivity Commission about these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I ought to explain some of the implications of competitive neutrality before we move on. There are a number of examples that I can think of where it is cheaper for the government service provider to continue to provide services that could be provided by the private sector. The desire by the private sector for competitive neutrality means that the advantage that many government service providers have because of their unique situation of being government, which is that there are some costs they do not have to have built in, is lost, and those costs have to be built in. That means that there will be services provided by the private sector which will cost the taxpayer more than they currently paying. The reason is that those advantages that come from those services being provided by the government will not be available any longer or they will become costed into the process and then they are easy to pull out.

SPEECH.PARA: One example of this is the provision of security training for Commonwealth drivers. It is all very well to have talkback radio people talking about why it should be possible for private sector providers to compete on the same terms but in the meantime the government pulls out its subsidy for security, which means that the training is not necessarily required to be provided. They can put in the tendering document that this is a desirable characteristic but you lose that control. So you get a service which is not the same, but you build in, if you like, a subsidised advantage then to the private sector.

This ought to be debated. This ought to be put out into the public sector—that people may get a lesser service, that there will be a reliance on some sort of tendering document to cover all contingencies, that you will get less accountability and that you will move towards what the government seems to be wanting to move to, which is a Public Service which is one‐tenth of what they came into. Basically you are building into these huge bodies, whether it is the Productivity Commission or the ACCC, the ability to enter a process of eating up the current system without ever considering whether this whole principle, this flawed and, as I call it, monstrous principle of competitive neutrality is valid, never having had the guts to go out to the community and have a full inquiry into the socioeconomic impacts of competition policy, into whether what we are doing is the right thing in terms of outcomes to people in the areas of health, security, education and environment and whether what we are getting is better than what we have. This is a blinkered ideological approach.

This is very dangerous. This is a watershed in Australia's history. It is not just a matter of working out what is better. It is a matter of whether or not we, as taxpayers, are going to be expected to subsidise competitive bidding by private industry which will often mean less services and less accountability. Once you do that it tends to be a one‐way process. I do not think we should go past this lightly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not persuaded by the argument of Senator Harradine in respect of this issue. He certainly has pointed out very succinctly what may occur when the vote is taken on this particular division. The government can make a choice depending on how the vote turns out. Albeit for reasons different from those given by the Greens and the Democrats, we will be opposing this particular division.

—I go back to what I said before. The Productivity Commission Bill does not par ticularly entitle a GBE to make a complaint under the breaches of competitive neutrality principles. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to explain to the committee how these will be attended to. The boot is on the other foot. Sometimes you can have a situation where private firms are making arrangements which do breach the competitive neutrality principles, if you like to call them that, that are virtually supported by both the government and the alternative government. How can those government business enterprises effectively attack those breaches by private firms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raises a good point. In his previous contribution to the debate he said that GBEs could use this complaint mechanism. The provisions which the Labor amendment is seeking, with the support of the Democrats and the Greens it would seem at this stage, to strike out of the bill in fact say that a person may complain to the commission—I am only paraphrasing—that a particular Commonwealth business or business activity is not being conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements. As described in part 3 of the Commonwealth competitive neutrality policy statement of June 1996:

SPEECH.PARA: A particular Commonwealth government business or business activity should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements.

So those provisions do not allow for a GBE to come to the body. An amendment to include what you are referring to could be put in there if you proposed it. But you would not be able to put it in there if Labor's amendment was supported because they seek to strike out the entire division. We think there are good reasons that such a provision not be included, but if you were to propose an amendment we would be happy to revisit it. But you would not be able to have an amendment if this bit were struck out.

Your arguments in relation to the role of the ACCC and the Productivity Commission in relation to these complaints are absolutely impeccable. The ACCC investigates these sorts of matters in a very legal way. They come to a conclusion and they usually take injunctive or court action or some other action. The commission will be allowed to look into these matters and give advice to the government as to how the GBE or government activity could be changed to ensure that it was fairer to private firms.

I am sure that in your experience during your long service in this place, Senator Harradine, you would have received many complaints from small businesses in Tasmania and other parts of the country about unfair competition from Commonwealth government and, I presume, Tasmanian government GBEs and other activities slicing into the market of small businesses in particular. It is certainly my experience. We think it is important that they have a place that they can take a complaint to without having to go to the great big ACCC where the complaint is a very serious matter that could end up in the Federal Court. Quite frankly, small business would be very interested to hear the views of senators who think that this sort of mechanism should not be available to them.

I do not think a month would have gone by, particularly during my time in opposition, where I did not get some small business complaining to me of some federal government activity. As you know, Senator Harradine, I raised a number of matters in the Senate concerning the engineering divisions of the Commonwealth competing unfairly for projects like Maralinga and the Commonwealth car hire business—trade union officials getting cars at cheap rates, et cetera. You will remember those things.

If you sought to put an amendment in we would have an open mind about it because we appreciate your support in principle for having a set of legislative requirements for handling competitive neutrality complaints. The Senate has already agreed that this function should go there so the debate that Senator Margetts is seeking to have is a debate that we have had. I have to respect her views in relation to that, even though they differ from mine. We have had that debate.

We are now saying, `Right, now that that power is within the commission, how should it be handled?' As you quite properly pointed out, these provisions spell out, in some intricate detail over four pages in the bill, how these complaints can be commenced, the fees that would apply to them, how they would be investigated, how reports are made, how the minister is to respond and so forth. If they are not in there, as you quite properly pointed out, the Treasurer, because the commission has this power, would simply have to provide it with some advice, probably by letter or some other brief as to how to do this.

It is a matter of whether the Senate wants a role in how it fulfils this function, and I think that is desirable, or whether the Treasurer advises the commission how it will fulfil those functions from time to time at his whim. Surely it is desirable, from the parliament's point of view, to say, `This is the way it should be done,' rather than leaving it to the Treasurer to do that from time to time.

In relation to those GBEs, we would say that already there are constitutional limitations on what GBEs are allowed to do. There are a range of other matters that apply specifically to government businesses. If government businesses have complaints about their position vis‐a‐vis a private sector competitor in a marketplace, they can already go to their department and their minister to make those complaints, and the minister then makes a decision as to whether that matter can be rectified. They should not need to go off to another quasi‐government organisation such as the commission to have that dealt with. It should be able to be dealt with within that department that has responsibility for that GBE.

There are examples that I can recall where that has happened. For example, Comcar have come to the minister—a series of poor unfortunate souls have been ministers for administrative services over the past 10 years—and taken complaints up. Where those complaints have not been acted upon, they have come to us and said, `Look, nasty old McMullan'—or `nasty old Frank Walker'—`haven't done this.' What I am trying to say in a roundabout way is that there is a mechanism for GBEs to go, within the normal lines of accountability, to their minister and say, for example, `Look, we need redress because it is unfair that Hertz Rent A Car are unfairly competing against Dasfleet.'

We regard it as unnecessary to have another provision there. But, on the broader point, we do say that it is important that the parliament says, now that the commission has this power and this function, that it be dealt with in a way that is controlled by this legislation in detail over four pages and not dealt with by order of the Treasurer from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This part of the bill may have to be dedicated to Alan Jones. The debate has been going on in some respects, but in a one‐sided way in the public arena. That information has been somewhat one‐sided. It is about whether or not government bodies in service provision like Comcar have a unfair advantage. The outcome was the removal of the security training. The government decided that security training was an unfair disadvantage to the private sector and so took it away.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have the functions that government were providing being affected by someone in the private sector who has a whole lot of say out there in the community, when in fact it is a big conflict of interest. It might be useful to ask whether his own drivers have the same level of security training as Comcar drivers were given under that fund. Here we have the private sector insisting that that function, which in the past has been considered important—that people who drive high profile people should have some sort of ability to act appropriately in times of crisis or in some sort of emergency situation—be taken away.

Someone in the private sector in the media has used the opportunity of bringing that out in debate to the point that that function was taken away as an unfair advantage. That function was taken away because it did not allow the private sector to compete. That is what it is: it is the Alan Jones memorial amendment to this bill. Perhaps we ought to build a little memorial to him.

We are seeing functions in the public sector—not just this one; this is just an example—that will actually alter as a result of the private sector saying, `No, we don't think that this is fair, because we would like to provide it cheaper but we can't do it if we, for instance, have to provide security for a person's information, for their information technology and so on.' They are saying that that is an unfair disadvantage, and the government is saying, `We'll let you compete cheaper. We'll take that away.'

That is what is happening. It is about security. It is about a person's ability to eventually point to where responsibility lies when things go wrong. That is what we are talking about. Competitive neutrality is about eroding those values which do not necessarily have that dollar value or might be subsidised in some way or other in the provision of that service, but there are often very good reasons for that. That is the debate we have never had. Yes, there has been the debate in the public sector. Yes, we know that those people who listen to talkback radio like Alan Jones ring through and we know other industries do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair, I rise on a point of order. I am reluctant to interrupt. It is an important debate to have, and it is a debate I am happy to join, but it is not relevant to the amendment moved by Senator Sherry. Broadly speaking, competitive neutrality is relevant. It is a topic that you could certainly cover in a second reading debate. But it is not relevant at this stage of the committee debate when we are considering Senator Sherry's amendment.
