—Madam Temporary Chair, on the point of order: I believe that I was talking about the principle of competitive neutrality. We are talking about entrenching that principle in legislation. How you can call that not relevant to the debate is beyond me, but I will leave it to the chair to rule.

—Madam Temporary Chair, on the point of order: I would agree with Senator Margetts. We are in fact talking about division 2, which is precisely that. In my view, the point that has been made by Senator Margetts is directly relevant to division 2.

—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Margetts's remarks are relevant. Her speech is contained within the lines of the debate. I would ask Senator Margetts to continue but to be aware that it is easy to stray from the fundamental point.
—I do not intend to delay the committee any longer than I need to, but I want people to be aware of what it is that we are beginning to entrench in legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Labor started the process of competition policy, and I know that very little of this whole process is available in the public arena. We know that the 2,000 pieces of legislation are being reviewed. We know that the provision of government services is changing, as we speak, at a very fast rate. Many people are concerned about that. I think at the very least we have an obligation to tease out some of those issues so we can throw out terms like competitive neutrality and act as if it is a principle that has been accepted. I do not believe it has. I believe it is a principle that is very poorly understood.

We have heard that the Victorian government would like to see lease cost tendering. This is one step further. Lease cost tendering asks, on the face of it, what the cheapest provision of service is, but that is still a very debatable concept because it is about whether or not in a tendering document you can include all of those values which would otherwise be provided in the provision of a government service.

This is one step further: it says that basically, if there is a tax advantage, if there are other advantages in infrastructure that already exist within a public department, you have to build those in as if they were costs. That may result in the service being more expensive. It is poorly understood, and I think the strongest argument possible should be made that it is time that the Senate looks at these issues carefully. I agree that we have not looked at those issues fully. I think the community ought to be involved. I think the Senate ought to be supporting a reference to look at those issues carefully and in detail so that we know what we are getting into, so we do not make these stupid mistakes and put these things into legislation without the general public knowing what it is that we are doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, I think your arguments were seductive but not persuasive. I want to refer back to the actual text. Section 56(1)(c) says that the function of the commission, as agreed by the Senate yesterday, shall be that the commission can receive and investigate complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements in relation to Commonwealth government business and business activities and to report.

SPEECH.PARA: If that were left open ended—which would be the result of Senator Sherry's amendment being accepted—it would mean that hopefully a revitalised, renewed, restaffed Industry Commission might say, `Competitive neutrality is not appropriate in this circumstance. Maybe competitive neutrality does not apply in this circumstance.' They would be able to take a far wider, far broader, far more open minded approach to evaluating a complaint than they would under your part 4, division 2. Part 4, division 2, which is prescriptive, states:
. . . a person may complain to the Commission that:
(a) a particular Commonwealth government business or business activity is not being conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements that apply to it; or
(b) a particular Commonwealth government business or business activity should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements.

In other words, it forces the commission to make sure that the competitive neutrality arrangement is complied with—not to make an assessment that it might not be appropriate in certain circumstances, not to be able to take an open minded and objective appraisal; it actually forces it to become an implementor. It is not an investigator, it is not an evaluator, it is not an objective determiner; it is an enforcer.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong.

—I know that you believe it is wrong, but that goes to the heart of the complaints that Senator Margetts and I have. The effect of division 2 is to enforce competitive neutrality arrangements which, in our view, are seldom appropriate but which, in your view, should at least be recognised as sometimes not appropriate. It cannot be appropriate in every single circumstance. Consequently, we are concerned about that. I think the breathing space that Senator Sherry has offered you and the alternative process he offers you is worthy of consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not something I would normally say because Senator Murray tends to get things right more times than not, but he is absolutely, totally wrong in relation to this. He selectively read from division 2, part 4. The effect of this is to set up a procedure for someone to make a complaint. It says that a person may complain to the commission that a particular Commonwealth government business activity should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this provision, a small business person in Western Australia may make a complaint. A panel beater in Victoria Park who has rung me recently complaining about some unfair activity can complain that a Commonwealth government business activity should be required to be conducted in accordance with these arrangements. It is up to the commission to do some sort of investigation and make a recommendation. It does not force anyone to do anything. It gives a right to a private citizen of Australia, more often than not a small business person or a family business, to make a complaint to an organisation about this activity.

This provision does not force anyone to do anything. It is totally misleading. The words speak for themselves. A person on or after 1 July 1997 may complain to the commission that a government business is being conducted or should be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements, ensuring that they have the right to protect their business from unfair competition from a government business entity. It gives them a right to complain.

It does not force the commission to uphold the complaint. It does not even force the commission to do anything about it, if the commission agrees that it is not a very sen sible complaint or that it falls outside all of those other things that should be taken into account.

Also, Senator Margetts, because we have put in ecological sustainability and social and environmental aspects, the Senate has required that the commission take all of those things into account. It is misleading to say that we do not consider those matters; we do. The Senate has agreed just today that the commission, in dealing with these matters, take into account regional development, regional employment and ecological sustainability. Again it is misleading to say that competitive neutrality ignores all of these factors. The commission has to take all that into account.

Criticise the government for all you will, but do not criticise us for things that we have not done. Give us credit where we have done some things that are right. I do not believe that in the last 18 months you have ever done that. But in this bill today we have agreed that, when looking at competitive neutrality arrangements, we will be looking at these complaints and, while doing so, take into account ecological sustainability, recognise the interests of employees, consumers and members of the community likely to be affected by these things and look at social and economic hardship—all matters that you have referred to.
You have said that the commission does not, cannot, and will not, in relation to competitive neutrality. The reality is that it does, it shall, and it must.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, I deliberately did not read out the full two pages because it is a lot of reading. But let us then proceed, if we may, to section 23. Section 23(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commission receives a complaint under this Division, it must investigate the complaint in order to determine whether there is a strong possibility . . .
In other words, it is required to look at the possibility of there being a competitive neutrality problem.
It goes on to state:
(a) the government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint is not being conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements . . .
That is a prescriptive and narrow direction in which it is taking it. Further:
or;
(b) the government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements . . .

If your argument was correct, you would have a (c) in there which would say that it is not appropriate that competitive neutrality applies in this instance, or that the decision to apply competitive neutrality in other laws or in other processes is wrongly based and should not apply here. In other words, you have not given the broad based and objective possibility of viewing these complaints, which is the heart of my argument to you. Section 23(2) goes on to state:
If the Commission determines that a possibility referred to in subsection (1) exists, it must make a written report to the Minister—
all right, that is fair enough—
on its investigations and findings in relation to the complaint.
(3) If the Commission determines that a possibility referred to in subsection (1) does not exist—
and that is a very narrow requirement, because they have been asked to look at it specifically in terms of competitive neutrality—
it must make a written report to the complainant on its investigations and findings in relation to the complaint.
And it is fair enough that it reports to the complainant. Under (4)—and I am going through all this deliberately so that people who are listening to the debate can follow it:
The report to the Minister under subsection (2) may include a recommendation that:
(a) the Minister refer the matters raised by the complaint to the Commission for inquiry and report under section 11; or
(b) the Minister take other action in relation to the matters raised by the complaint.
That is fair enough; that is executive discretion in these matters. Then (5):
The Minister may specify additional procedures to be followed by the Commission in dealing with complaints under this Division, and the Commission must follow any procedure so specified.
Fair enough.

My primary complaint is that they receive complaints which are specifically and narrowly confined in terms of the competitive neutrality principles, as under section 21; and then, under section 23, they are not permitted to reject or regard as inappropriate, or to regard as unfairly or unsoundly based, the original competitive neutrality requirement in itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chairman, I will address those points made by Senator Murray and also Senator Margetts, and I will ask you a question on certain points that have been raised, which are similar to the ones I was going to raise.

SPEECH.PARA: With these competitive neutrality principles, we are faced with the fact that both the government and the alternative government are supporting that principle. I think that `competitive neutrality' is often a myth. But, still, let us deal with the matters in practise. First of all, one of the matters raised by Senator Margetts related to the Commonwealth car service—a very, very important area. But what is the alternative? What happens now? This is why we parliamentarians feel so helpless about it.

The matter now is just dealt with by the minister. There is no public examination of the arguments that might be used by Hertz, or whoever. Under this, the minister who receives complaints from organisations could say, `Well, look, the provisions now are in the legislation. There are provisions there for complaints to be put to the Productivity Commission. You go there and complain and see how you go.' That is, I think, a better way of dealing with it than having a situation whereby, without any public scrutiny, the minister takes decisions, as the minister has taken decisions in respect of that particular matter.

I was concerned also about 23. We are not actually dealing with that just at the present moment, I suppose, because we are dealing with Senator Sherry's amendment. I looked at the rather prescriptive and narrow provisions in 23(1)(a) and (b). But I assumed that the commission, when looking at these complaints, would have to perform that function in accordance with clause 8(1).

Senator Margetts quite correctly expressed a concern that social and economic impacts may not be able to be considered if the commission proceeds strictly in accordance with section 23 of the bill. The area of concern for a lot of us in this chamber is regional development; for example, the regional structures of some government departments. Is the very fact that, by ministerial direction or by government department policy, those government departments have branches in certain regional areas to be regarded as not being competitively neutral, if a complaint is made by a private firm?

What I really need—and I think Senator Murray has also adverted to it—is for the parliamentary secretary, on behalf of the government, to make it perfectly plain to us, either by amendment to the proposed section 23 or by a formal statement to the committee when the time comes, that the provisions of 8(1) will be required to be followed by the Productivity Commission in examining complaints under division 2 of this proposed legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, it is exactly what I said in response to Senator Margetts's previous intervention and, for the record, I reiterate that they do—clause 8(1) principles apply to this function.
—This relates to Senator Campbell's statement because I think that is an important statement to the Senate. I want to know if it is the governing and overriding principles that govern that section.

—In other words, does it mean that the commission will be able to say that, in view of our consideration of the matter and the matters that we need to have consideration for under 8(1), competitive neutrality principles do not apply in a particular case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The competitive neutrality matter is described in part 2, section 6(1)(c) of the bill. So it is a function. Then you go to the amended 8(1)(j), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the performance of its function, the commission must—
So it is an overriding principle in relation to this matter.

I will just say—and I am not going to speak again, because I think we have hammered this whole matter to death—that, in relation to Senator Murray's previous intervention about where the commission must do these inquiries, at section 26, the commission does have the discretion not to investigate complaints, for a range of reasons, which include: if it is vexatious or frivolous, if a complainant does not have sufficient interest in the matter, or if an investigation is not warranted having regard to all the relevant circumstances. Of course, those circumstances could include any of those matters in 8(1). That concludes my contribution on this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that part 4, division 2, stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 10, page 6 (lines 25 to 29), omit subclause (4).

Given the defeat of division 2 the opposition moves this amendment, which deals with annual reports. I note we are dealing with the productivity bill and I do not want to unduly keep the time of the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, opposition amendment No. 2 on sheet 632 would require the commission not to report on any competitive neutrality inquiries it might make—is that correct, Senator Sherry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summary, the effect of what the Senate is doing is as follows. We have given the commission the power to conduct inquiries into competitive neutrality issues. We have now agreed that the parliament should not legislate how those inquiries be conducted. We have just said to Peter Costello—or whoever happens to be Treasurer at the time—that he can write to the commission and say, `This is how you can do it,' whenever he wishes. So the parliament has basically said, `Do it how you like, government. We do not need to scrutinise how you accept these inquiries.' And now the effect of this is to say that, when it conducts these inquiries, it need not even make a report in its annual report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interesting turn in the Senate's scrutiny of government. We have a Senate that is now saying, `We won't constrain you as to how you conduct the inquiries and we won't constrain you by having you report on it.' I am sure the government can live with this, but we are opposed to it. We think that the commission, when it conducts these inquiries, should make a report. It should report on how it does them and how many it makes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of our consistent themes is that the Productivity Commission should not be dealing with the issues of competitive neutrality. What remains to be seen is whether it will be dealing with anything. The government should be cognisant of the views of the minor parties and the Labor Party in respect of this concern, and it has not been to date. We will see how it all falls.

SPEECH.PARA: But it would be entirely inconsistent. Having seen the defeat of the competitive neutrality complaints provisions, we do not believe they should be dealt with by the Productivity Commission. We believe they should be dealt with by the ACCC. When we get to our later amendment, which seeks to ensure that the competitive neutrality complaints are dealt with by the ACCC, the government can make up its mind whether it supports us or not. If it does not, that is the way it will fall, but it will be in the government's court.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes that the commission should be required to make a report. We think that it is important, for accountability reasons, that the Productivity Commission make a report on these inquiries, and we will be opposing this amendment which would make it optional for the commission to report.

—Parliamentary Secretary, it would be a pity if the very civilised way in which this debate has been carried out should deteriorate into a bit of bad temper. I would indicate that part 2 was rejected partly on the basis of its being too narrowly confined in terms of how the Productivity Commission should operate and should receive complaints. But the fact is, as you have pointed out many times, 6(1)(c)—that the commission will investigate complaints—is on the books. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats have absolutely no objection to the commission reporting on the number of complaints it has. So, although I understand where Senator Sherry is going, I certainly would not stop the commission reporting on that. We will support the existing clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the nature of complaints will probably be a function of the general push in the direction not only of requiring the privatisation of the Public Service but also of requiring that those elements which are left of the public sector find revenue from other sources.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are current sources of complaints, they may often arise from situations like the one that springs to mind—the proposal by what was the Federal Airports Corporation to put in shopping centres at Perth airport. At the time, the complaint of the community was that, because of the tax advantage which the Federal Airports Corporation then had, they would be proposing to put in some megastores and superstores and to invite, perhaps, overseas investment, and they would have a competitive advantage because of that tax advantage.

That proposal was being pushed by the fact that government business enterprises were being required to turn a dollar. They were not being required to simply provide a service—in this example, airport services; they were being required to find other sources of funding. Therefore, there was an inevitable consequence that those enterprises were looking for ways to compete with the private sector. That is what they were being told to do.

In the example of the Federal Airports Corporation at Perth airport, it meant that, instead of creating new businesses, they would be taking business from others. Usually in those kinds of instances where you are putting in stores and shops and so on, superstores take business off existing stores. Studies indicated that it would not add to the total economic activity in the area; it would take away from other shopping centres—which were already suffering badly at the time—and particularly from the areas around Belmont.

I can understand that, but it is an indication that we are pushing along with this idea that government entities have to compete with the private sector and the private sector has to be able to take business off the government. In the end, those things which the government sector does which are not commercial get virtually taken off the slab or become regarded as unimportant, because the tail wags the dog.

If there are going to be complaints, I guess they ought to be made public. While I have generally supported the opposition's amendments, if I read Senator Sherry's body language correctly—and perhaps it is unfair of me to do that—I am not sure that he is thoroughly convinced about this amendment either. That is for him to decide for himself. The Greens have always been in favour of scrutiny and, if there is a complaints mechanism, let us see the reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with what should be contained in the annual report. I think that this is quite important. I think members of parliament particularly are very concerned that there be in the annual report of particular authorities full and open discussion about how they have performed their functions. We of course have the opportunity to discuss and question those reports, as we do quite frequently, either at the normal sessions of standing committees or at the legislation committees considering the estimates. So I think it is important to have full disclosure in those reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Without reflecting on the previous vote in any shape or form, might I just point out what the committee has done by having a tied vote on the last occasion. We had a provision in the bill whereby parliament was setting down quite clearly what must be done by the commission when considering complaints on competitive neutrality arrangements. That provision has been, as a result of that tied vote, excised from the legislation.

But of course under section 6(1) the commission will still be required to look at these particular matters. The only difference now is that, instead of being required to undertake those investigations in the manner required by parliament, it will be simply by order of the Treasurer. The Treasurer will be able to ask them to proceed in accordance with his viewpoint and his viewpoint alone.

On reflection, I wonder whether honourable senators realise what we have done in virtually giving the Treasurer a free hand in this matter, unmanacled, if you like, by the provisions which parliament should, in my view, have adopted, which would then have required the commission to follow them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has correctly pointed out that division 2 was defeated in the last vote. We still have 6(1)(c) in the legislation, and I could move, as I understand it, while the committee is proceeding that 6(1)(c) be deleted. That would obviously require a positive vote of the Senate, unless the government changes its mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I do understand Senator Harradine's concerns about this being transferred to the ACCC. We may have some discussions about this over the break, and the government may reconsider our position. But I cannot see us reconsidering our position on not supporting division 2.
Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine have indicated their position on amendment 2 on sheet 632, and I do not intend to speak any further with respect to it.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 28, page 18 (line 17), at the end of subclause (2), add ", including employment in industry development, environmental or social equity matters".
(1) Clause 28, page 18 (line 17), at the end of the clause, add:
(3) At least one Commissioner must have extensive skills and experience in applying the principles of ecologically sustainable development and environmental conservation.
(4) At least one Commissioner must have extensive skills and experience in dealing with the social effects of economic adjustment and social welfare service delivery.
(5) At least one Commissioner must have extensive skills and experience acquired in working in Australian industry.

Under clause 28 the appointment of commissioners is to be made by the Governor-General. The opposition supports this method of appointment. We agree there should be a test to be passed before a person can be appointed. At the moment the bill simply provides that the appointee must have qualifications and experience relevant to the commission's functions.

The amendments propose to include more detail on the relevant experience that the appointee must have. Both our amendment and the revised amendment on sheet 641 outline the types of skills and experience that commissioners have. We believe this will ensure that a proper balance is brought into the commission's considerations.

The government is saying that the new commission really will be taking on the role of two other bodies in addition to the Industry Commission—the Bureau of Industry Economics and EPAC. If that is the case, then this shifted emphasis onto industry development and social areas is appropriate. We are surprised that the government did not consider ensuring that the legislation reflect a broader background of appointment, given the amalgam of three organisations and the possible additional powers in respect of complaints about implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements, however that ends up. We have an Industry Commission under a new name, the Productivity Commission, with significantly more functions and power—and no competitors.

I wonder whether the parliamentary secretary in his response could give an account to the Senate of the staffing changes that have occurred since March 1996. We would be interested to know the number of staff in the former Industry Commission, BIE and EPAC that have been carried through into the new Productivity Commission. We do note—and it has been referred to earlier in this debate—that the reorganisation of the three organisations into one has been carried out before parliament approved the organisation. It is of interest to us to know what proportion of staff have been carried over from each respective organisation in their employment by the new Productivity Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I do not think we have the detailed questions on the staffing levels at hand, but I am quite happy to supply them in as much detail as possible. I take that on notice, if I may. In relation to this matter of parliamentary approval, the Commonwealth has acted entirely within the bounds of its administrative responsibilities. As I have said a couple of times, the BIE was a division of the department and the Commonwealth can, under normal departmental arrangements, decide from time to time how to structure its departments, without reference to the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the main issue under debate with this amendment, Senator Sherry said something along the lines that he wonders why, with the amalgamation of the three former bodies, we did not allow a broader range of commissioners. I think it is obvious from reading clause 2 that it really ensures that the broadest possible range of commissioners can be appointed. You are allowed, I think, somewhere between four and 11 commissioners and clause 28(2) says that the Governor‐General can make appointments based on qualifications and experience relevant to the commission's functions. We have had a long debate about the functions and also about the policy guidelines, and you could not really get a lot broader than that. It does not fetter it in any way and, in fact, the amendment proposed by the opposition and a similar set of words proposed by the Democrats do tend to fetter it in some ways.

The history of the commission, I am advised, is very much that the government has always considered skills and experience which are necessary when it makes such appointments. The areas that are raised by this amendment look at environment, social matters and industry. I think it is worth noting, for example, that in relation to the environmental, waste management, equipment and systems inquiry the government appointed Dr Tor Hundloe as a commissioner for that inquiry. Dr Hundloe's background is as a lecturer in the School of Australian Environmental Studies at Griffith University and planning officer to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That is an example of a commissioner who has been appointed because of his skills and experience in that area.

In relation to the charitable organisations inquiry, Sister Margaret McGovern AO was appointed. Sister McGovern had previously served on the board of the Mater Hospital, the Australian National Council on AIDS, the St Vincent de Paul inner city homelessness programs, the Independent Commission Against Corruption, and numerous other projects involving refugee camps, the aged and Aboriginal people. Another example in relation to the TCF inquiry currently before the commission is Mr Philip Brass, the former Managing Director of Pacific Dunlop.

The government has, on its past record, appointed as commissioners people with the skills required. Clause 28(2) ensures that those appointments must be made on that basis. It is a broad power that allows the appointments to be made based on the functions of the commission and the inquiries at hand, and the government intends to continue appointing people with a range of skills. The downside of accepting the amendment is that it actually narrows the choices and the decision making of the government in trying to create a balance of skills and experience by ensuring that commissioners with special skills in each one of these areas are appointed as commissioners, regardless of the needs of the commission at that time.

Each one of these skills can be appointed depending on the work of the commission at the time. As we have said, there is already good evidence of what the government has done in terms of appointing people with specific skills. More importantly, if there are skills needed in a particular area of social welfare, industry or sustainable development, it is open for the commissioner at any time to use a range of consultants in these areas.

They are the arguments that the government would proffer in opposition to the amendment. We think the bill as it stands provides what the amendment would seek to do but it does it in a more broad and flexible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are issues in relation to whether or not you truly do believe that those agreed functions that the Senate has talked about earlier are functions of the commission or something you simply apply if you have an inquiry which has something similar in the name.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues that comes up for me in terms of being a Green politician is that most of the issues that affect things such as social justice, environment and even peace and disarmament do not necessarily come up in bills that are called social justice, peace and disarmament and environment bills. They are actually embedded in other laws. They could be tax laws, customs laws or industry laws. They change the way people relate to ecological sustainability. They punish or penalise certain activities or they move people away from other things. So, in reality, unless you actually do accept that these are functions, they do not necessarily happen.

I am currently reading a book by a former New Zealand politician, Marilyn Waring. She mentioned a major multilateral aid agency which had as its stated goals that the program should be, for instance, fully cognisant of the needs of women in development, recognising the very important role of targeting women, because they tend to be a means of making things happen within society, especially in small communities. However, when it came down to it, the actual programs—with all the good words and all the good agreed functions—did not work that way because those people who were making decisions within the organisations on an ongoing basis did not know how to implement them. The bells did not ring as to how they actually change their function and how they actually recognised within their normal day‐to‐day operation how to implement the policies and functions that they were meant to implement.

So I would go along with the proposal that unless you actually have those people with that sense within them of what to look for, many things will go by which do affect all of those functions and nobody will know. In the end we will come back a year or two later and say, `We have these good words in section 8, but what have you done about them?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This revised amendment No. 641 from Senator Sherry of the Labor Party encapsulates the earlier amendment we circulated, and we drop it in favour of this amendment. I think the points made by the parliamentary secretary really go to the root of the problem—that is, throughout our institutions and throughout our statutory board, committee and authority process, there are virtually no guidelines, protocols or established criteria by which appointments to really vital positions are made. That applies whether you are talking about the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Reserve Bank of Australia, the appointments of High Court judges or commissioners being appointed to the Productivity Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a problem which at last was recognised and dealt with in the United Kingdom, where they introduced the Nolan committee recommendations, which clearly established the criteria under which such appointments should be made. In due course, we in the Democrats hope to see that the proper principles under which appointments are made come into practice in this country as well because in all these things we have to rely on the good offices of what is inevitably a partisan government. That is the nature of government; it is partisan.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that this amendment will improve the community's perception that commissioners have been of a biased and unsatisfactory nature in commission work which has been of fundamental importance to the Australian community and the Australian economy. This amendment adds to the requirements that commissioners—there are only three spelt out—must have extensive skills and experience in the principles of ecologically sustainable development and environmental conservation. I note that many businesses are now accepting those as desirable goals for themselves to follow. Commissioners must have extensive skills and experience in dealing with the social effects of economic adjustment and social welfare service delivery and extensive skills and experience acquired in working in Australian industry, which leads to a very practical approach.

Whilst I understand that it will constrain you to some degree in a minority of appointments made to the commission, I would urge you, parliamentary secretary, to consider at some future date laying down more fully the broad and general principles and criteria in legislation under which these sorts of vital appointments should be made. It should be no surprise to you, having heard what I have had to say, to know that I will be supporting Labor in this matter.

We think that in the past some reports have used the environment almost as a footnote or a throwaway line and that the benefits have been oversold relative to the costs, especially in the long term. We just hope that these sorts of guides to the government—these sorts of requirements on the government—will improve the range and character of the people who will serve the community on the commission. Accordingly, I commend Labor's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate my support for the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 43, page 26 (lines 5 to 17), omit the clause, substitute:
(1) The Chair is to convene such meetings of the Commission he or she thinks necessary for the efficient performance of the functions of the Commission.
(2) Meetings are to be held at such places as the Chair determines.
(3) The Chair must preside at all meetings.
(4) The Chair may give directions regarding the procedure to be followed at or in connection with a meeting.
(5) At a meeting:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Chair and 3 other Commissioners form a quorum; and
(b) questions must be decided by a majority of votes of the Commissioners present and voting; and
(c) the Chair has a deliberative vote and, if necessary, also has a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) The Chair may permit a person to participate in, or a Commissioner to form a part of a quorum at, a meeting by means of telephone, closed circuit television or any other method of communication.
(7) A power of the Chair under subsection (1), (2), (4) or (6) must be exercised, so far as practicable, only after consultation with the Commissioners.
(8) This section has effect subject to sections 44 and 45.
This amendment lays out the meetings of the commission. I draw senators' attention to subclause 43(6) in the bill which says:
In the event of a disagreement on a question arising at a meeting, the question is to be decided by the Chairman or in the manner specified by the Chairman.
Our subclause 43(5), which is relevant to this issue, says:
At a meeting:
(a) the Chair and 3 other Commissioners form a quorum; and
(b) questions must be decided by a majority of votes of the Commissioners present and voting; and
(c) the Chair has a deliberative vote and, if necessary, also has a casting vote.

We find it quite extraordinary, in the way the government has written this legislation, that in the event of a disagreement on a question arising at a meeting the chair decides the question. There is no vote. So presumably the chair could be in a minority and, because he disagrees with the majority, he decides, because there is a disagreement. This seems to me to be an extraordinary approach to any meeting procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is great if you are the chair.

—I was going to reflect back on our time in the TTLC, Senator Harradine. I do not think any of us could have imagined or dreamed up a provision like this. We would have had enormous authority. When I became President of the TTLC, I would have loved to have been in a position as chair of those meetings where, if we had a debate and one delegate disagreed, I could have decided the matter. It would have been a wonderful world in that sense. So we do find that this is a somewhat unusual procedure—I was going to say `quaint', but `quaint' is not the word to describe it—that the government has included with respect to meetings of the commission.
—It is under the WA Liberal Party constitution!

—I will take that interjection. I hope you have repealed it from the WA Liberal Party constitution. I have a fair idea who ensured that it was put in. But I have to say that in my many years of activity in the political arena I do not think I have ever seen a provision like this before. So we have suggested a fairer approach in the event of a disagreement. We think that giving the chair a deliberative vote and, if it is tied, obviously the costing vote is a more reasonable way to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw attention to a part of the amendment which I like very much, and that is part 6:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairperson may permit a person to participate in, or a Commissioner to form a part of, a quorum at a meeting by means of telephone, closed circuit television or any other method of communication.

It could even be better. Perhaps it should just give the right to the commissioners to do that without having to get permission from the chair. But it is obviously good that the chair knows that this is going to take place. It is going to be a bit churlish if a chair says: `No, you can't'.

Honourable senators may remember that this was part of a change to the standing orders which I put to the Senate. To his credit it was supported by the then President, Senator Michael Beahan, another Western Australian who realised how difficult it is to attend all committee meetings. It is a great idea that we now have some recognition that through the aid of technology, through the use of video conferencing or teleconferencing, in a country as large as Australia people can, in important matters, be officially part of a quorum.

We should be doing this more and more. Maybe in the future we will be attending parliament by videoconference. We could sit in our electorates and attend parliament. That is a long way off, I know. We can only dream that we do not have to spend so much time away from our electorates and homes and yet still participate within the parliamentary process effectively. That is in the future. This part of the amendment is very good. More and more government entities should participate in it. If that happens, then I think we will end up having convenient teleconferencing centres and videoconferencing centres that people can go to. The technology will become cheaper and cheaper the more we use it. It would be great if we did not have to use up as much fuel flying people from, say, Sydney to Canberra or from Perth to Canberra. We would use the airports less and create less social havoc and, obviously, less greenhouse gas. It would mean that those people who are already very stressed could spend more time in their homes with their families and loved ones. It is a great idea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This comes from the Western Australian Liberal manual of excellent control of meetings and outcomes prior to people like Senator Campbell contributing to its partial reform. I will see what his reaction is, but I would be very surprised if Senator Campbell were to defend this with any passion. It is the most extraordinary thing I have seen in a long time. I am sure it was introduced merely to give us some light entertainment in this heavy debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We took about one nanosecond to decide that Senator Sherry's amendment was dead on. I concur with the remarks and the humour that accompanied his promotion of his amendment. It almost implied as the bill is presently that they are going to appoint people but their opinions do not really matter; if you have the chair you have everything. Imagine! Just give Bill Scales that kind of power and authority and we would really be right in the cart. Apparently, there are people even worse than that out there in terms of the ideological position he takes. So thank you, Senator Sherry and Labor. It is an excellent amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment. Can I just express some surprise that the bill got through the House of Representatives without that matter being focused upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —One great benefit of coming from the great state of Western Australia and the great Liberal Party of Western Australia is that you do learn to count. It is quite clear—on one hand, I can count—that this measure is going to go down, so I will not waste any more of the Senate's time seeking to stand in the way of what will be an inevitable vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Clause 49, page 30 (line 13), at the end of subclause (1), add ", after engaging in an open and transparent, competitive tendering process".
(14) Clause 49, page 30 (after line 13), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) The terms of engagement of a consultant under subsection (1) must be published by the Commission in the Gazette .
Page 30, line 13, states in respect of consultants:
The Chairman may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, engage as consultants to the Commission persons who have suitable qualifications and experience.

Then follow two more subparagraphs. We have had some discussion about the significant powers of the chair of the commission. I do not want to reflect on the current chair in making the comments I did earlier or in the comments I am making now. The enormously expanded functions of the Productivity Commission, as Labor said, we are not very happy about. Nevertheless, the Senate has approved that expansion of powers. In the modern world consultants are becoming more and more prevalent and, given the significant increase in the functions of the Productivity Commission vis-a-vis the old Industry Commission, we believe that it is appropriate that—as we have moved in respect to the letting and engagement of a contract for services or a contract of service—this should occur after engaging in an open, transparent, competitive tendering process.

In amendment 14 we have moved that in this process the terms of the engagement of a consultant under subsection 1 should be published by the commission in the Gazette so that we ensure that in this very important new commission a transparent situation will result. Given this very important Productivity Commission's greatly enhanced responsibilities, we think that these two amendments ensure a greater transparency in respect of consultants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are prepared to accept this, except that we do have one reservation and that concerns small consultancies. I am informed that under Labor one of the consultancies that was let for contract was for an amount of about $1,000. I think there are broadly accepted protocols across government as to when consultancies are required to go to tender. I am not readily aware of those as I stand here. I know that when I was parliamentary secretary to Robert Hill in the environment portfolio we had to look at a number of consultancies when we were establishing Green Corps. We were advised by the secretary of the department of employment and the secretary of the department of the environment as to what those guidelines were.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just having drafted a set of words which would entirely encapsulate the sentiment and indeed the words of Senator Sherry's amendment, but which would also propose that the tendering process apply to consultancies under, say, $10,000. Otherwise you could again have an impractical situation. I have a set of words: after Labor's amendment add the words, `where the estimated value of the consultancy exceeds $10,000'. Another one is, `or as specified by regulation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, you are entirely at liberty to move an amendment to the amendment.
—I so do. The most flexible way would be to add after the words in Labor's amendment, `where the estimated value of the consultancy exceeds an amount to be specified by regulation.'
—Is this an amendment to opposition amendment 13?
—Yes. I move:

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the amendment add "where the estimated value of the consultancy exceeds an amount prescribed".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to keep the committee on this for too long. I do not think that that is a bad suggestion. I would like to know what other colleagues think. Could I just have your assurance that there will be a regulated figure? If you give that assurance to us then there can be some tick‐tacking about what is reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to give that assurance. We will discuss whether it should be five or 10 or whatever. It will be a reasonable amount that ensures that the intent of the committee is recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Sherry's amendment No.13, as amended, be agreed to.

—I think that what we are trying to achieve here is to get the best brains through the best process. I appreciate the Parliamentary Secretary's assistance in the matter. I have a point of clarification: Parliamentary Secretary, would these regulations be disallowable? In what form do they come?
