BREAK.PARA: This is a very important area for the Labor opposition. I am sure that Senator Campbell will point out that the offences that are set out for the Productivity Commission are the same as those for the Industry Commission, and he would be correct. So let me deal with that issue firstly.

I have one of my acknowledged experts in this area, Senator Cooney, who will be making some contribution to the debate. He is far more authoritative, knowledgeable and experienced in this particular area than I am, so I am not going to speak for an enormous amount of time.

It may have been valid to have had these offences in respect of the Industry Commission but we are dealing with a proposed new Productivity Commission which has enormously enhanced functions. This is a productivity commission which is taking on the role of the old Industry Commission, EPAC and the BIE as well as being given additional powers in a number of other areas. So it has the power of the three old organisations as well as new powers and there has been a transference, in part 7, of the offences from the Industry Commission. Given the increased functions of the commission and what will be a greatly enhanced Industry Commission, we have argued earlier that it is the tiger unleashed in a metamorphosed form.

It seems to us inappropriate that the offences that are outlined in part 7 should have very heavy and draconian penalties carried over to the Productivity Commission. There are a number of significant powers the commission will have in respect of offences. Just to run through those quickly, they include hindering or disrupting the commission, intimidation and notice to persons to provide information and documents. Given the context of the new functions of the commission, I am very concerned about this notice to persons to provide information and documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only talking about hearings and inquiries.

—As I understand it, it is everything. My colleague Senator Cooney, who is far more incisive in this area, is going to make some observations. The powers also include to summons the person to attend a hearing and refusal to answer questions or produce documents. I think it is a bit over the top that, if you refuse to answer questions or produce documents, you are imprisoned for six months, given the expanded functions of the organisation.
—It is the same thing as under the old one.

—Yes, but the new Productivity Commission is greatly expanded in its functions, Senator Harradine. When you look at the list of functions in 6(1) and reflect on the combination of the three organisations, plus the additional powers, the Productivity Commission becomes a much more significant body than the Industry Commission, with significant powers of enforcement. There are also other sections here dealing with false or misleading evidence or information, restriction on publication of evidence, documents produced in relation to an inquiry, allowance to witnesses, and a number of other references. So we have concern about the six‐month imprisonment in a number of areas.

BREAK.PARA: What we have sought to do is submit, in the case of amendment 15, page 32, line 31, to do with notices to persons to provide information and documents, a penalty of $50 rather than imprisonment for six months. On page 32, clause 52, we have suggested a change, and my colleague Senator Cooney, with his legal background, can deal with that. It is a similar principle right through the particular amendments to the other clauses, 53 and 54. We think that in those areas the level of penalty that we have suggested in our amendments is more appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter for some concern. I think what will be said from the government side is that this is a usual sort of process, that if you have got a body such as the Productivity Commission is going to be then you need to be able to enforce certain actions or certain proposals on their part. If they are going to hold an inquiry there are certain things that should be open to the person who is conducting that inquiry, such as getting evidence and making sure it comes before the commission.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that Senator Sherry is right, that this goes beyond what is reasonable. If you look at proposed section 50, it says:
A person must not:
(a) obstruct or hinder a member of the Commission in the performance of the Commission's functions—
they are very wide functions, of course—
or (b) disrupt a hearing before the Commission.

So, if a commissioner is writing something on the tram or is discussing a matter with someone and somebody obstructs or hinders the member, then in doing that, outside the hearing function, he or she is liable to a penalty of six months imprisonment.

Again, under section 53, the chairman may summons a person in writing to appear at a hearing to give evidence and to produce documents specified in the summons. If the person does not attend on that summons, there is a penalty of up to six months imprisonment. And under section 46 the chairman can delegate his functions to a commissioner, so the commissioner who is hearing the matter can both serve the document—issue the document and have it served—and then provide evidence that that has not been attended to. I take it that the chairman or commissioner would then have to go off to court to prove that, but nevertheless it is unusual in the general scheme of things to have what in effect is a tribunal issuing its own summons and then having the capacity to see people punished for failing to attend to the summons they are issuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m, the consideration is interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on matters of public interest to report the release of a very important report called the Information Policy Advisory Council report on on‐line services. This report heralds the policies that Australia should be developing as the information age comes upon us. The report was released last week by the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. I want to congratulate the minister for the speedy release of this report. It acknowledges the urgency of this matter for Australia, which the report says is at the cross‐roads in terms of information industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes in technology that are now coming about are equivalent for Australia of the time of the industrial revolution. The move into the information age is as significant as the move into the industrial age 150 years ago. Governments have to have the policy frameworks in place to cater for this incredible shift in economic activity and take into account all its social and personal consequences.

This report from the Information Policy Advisory Council provides us with the blueprint for doing that. It outlines the way in which the nation should prepare in gearing up to these new technologies. This comprehensive report, which I will return to in detail shortly, was presented only one year after its commissioning. I commend the Howard government for also establishing parallel to this a very powerful interdepartmental committee called the Commonwealth of Information, which is chaired by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). It has senior cabinet ministers representing all key departments that are related to the information age.

The purpose of that group is to determine strategies for on‐line information and communication services that are significant to Australia's prosperity within the growing global information economy. We now have three reports from the government to assist the nation in this transition to the information age. This IPAC report, the Goldsworthy report and the Mortimer report are all vital in the national interest as we undergo this shift.

As I told the Senate in a series of speeches almost three years ago, the information age for Australia is a reality, and we are now on notice to embrace the information age or suffer the consequences of the economic loss that Australia will face if we do not undertake this new path. Thankfully, the implementation of policy response is now out of Labor's ineffective hands. If you look at the appalling record of the ALP on this matter in those vital years of the early nineties as we approached the information age, you find that there were many missed opportunities.

The former ALP government's approach to this was best characterised by the former minister, Mr Lee, sitting on his hands. They did set up what they called the broadband services expert group, which developed a report under the chairmanship of Brian Johns. It reported in December 1993. They then tabled the final report in July 1994. The final recommendations appeared in 1995, and by the time they had lost government in 1996 nothing had happened. We had an interim report from 1993 through to 1996. We lost a quarter of a decade while they wondered what they would do about it. When they left office, they had not implemented any of the recommendations.
Barry Jones, the member for Lalor and the ALP national president, used these words on ABC radio in July 1994 to describe the ALP government's performance on matters relating to the information age:
We tend to react to things . . . we tend to stumble into things. Oh really we ought to have a policy response to that. But we don't anticipate changes, we react to them.

Labor left a structural situation where Australia's information industries were underweight and underdeveloped. Labor did nothing to turn around the slow trend of Australian companies to reinvent themselves to make themselves ready for the information age.

My colleague Senator Alston and the Howard government are now seizing this opportunity. It is vital that they do that because the information economy is a reality with growing users and services. Across the world there are 50 million users of Internet services. Getting ready for the information age are countries such as Malaysia, the USA, Ireland and Japan which have developed special industry zones reserved for information industries to attract those industries to their countries. Australia should be well placed at this time. We have people who use these sorts of services quite extensively. We now have one million estimated users of the Internet, which puts Australia fourth in the world in terms of per capita usage.

Australians rapidly adopt new technologies. One in five over the age of 16 have used the Internet. Ten per cent of Australian households have on‐line connections. On‐line services provide some five million‐plus sources of information and connection, and this is growing exponentially. We have on‐line libraries which people can access from a wide range of centres around the country. We have movies on demand; entertainment is just over the horizon. People are increasingly studying for degrees by external studies through the services provided by information technology. Right across the country we now have instant communication through E‐mail, and the whole area of electronic business and commerce is growing very rapidly.

It is my view that Australia has the capacity to benefit from the rapidly changing world of on‐line commerce. We must take action to capitalise on our opportunities—but it is action that is needed now.

The information industry sector is big and growing, and we must understand the unique nature of this new economy. In 1995 it represented $65 billion in economic activity world wide. It should not be categorised and seen in traditional terms, like we perhaps look at the steel industry or the motorcar industry. It is a grouping of very different activities that range across a wide range of products and services, including electronic components, hardware and computer software, through to communication networks and content production. These elements are bound together in a chain of value adding services through to the delivery point.
The IPAC report rightly says that Australia is at the crossroads and facing technological change as we move from the industrial age to the information age. The report emphasises:
A sense of urgency is required. We need to be bold and ambitious.
So what is the potential value of electronic commerce to Australia? IPAC reports this in some optimistic detail.

On‐line transactions on the Internet and information based production is forecast to capture a rapidly growing share of international economic activity. This growth is reflected in the supply side, which is growing at three to four times the rate of the national economy. Further, the bulk of new jobs and sales growth in the leading national economies is directly attributable to the exploitation of information and communication technologies.

We must turn potential into reality because, as it stands, Australia is still a bystander in the electronic international trade sector. At present we represent a trivial 0.3 per cent of the global market share of this new information age. Our share compares very unfavourably with the shares of other smaller Asian economies. Singapore, for example, represents 6.9 per cent of the world's share; Malaysia has 5.5 per cent.

The IPAC report recommendations set out a framework for action to ensure that the Australian government and businesses improve on this poor sharing and take up the immediate challenges of the information era. The report recommends that Australia invest in education at all levels to produce a skilled work force to allow us to operate successfully in the global information economy. It recommends that we relax immigration rules for people with demonstrated on‐line skills to enter Australia. It suggests that we develop a national uniform on‐line policy where action by federal and state governments has an orientation to building and funding on‐line technologies. It also recommends that we improve our access to global distribution channels and networks.

We need to increase the international recognition of Australian on‐line products, and we need to further develop the capital markets to finance technology based enterprises that use information formats. We need to enact legislation for electronic commerce and on‐line transactions that address new developments, including digital signatures, certification and electronic authentication.

In addition, the IPAC report outlines some vital elements of reform in this new information age. I am particularly attracted to the IPAC recommendation that we aggressively implement competition policy in telecommunications to ensure the world's lowest price advantage for Australia with our major on‐line trading partners.

Only last week Senator Alston provided to the Senate dramatic evidence that shows that Australia now has one of the most liberalised and effective telecommunication networks in the world. There have been substantial price reductions announced by carriers since 1 July 1997, when we opened up the telecommunications market. A company called AAPT an nounced a 60 per cent reduction of current costs for national and international long distance calls. Primus‐Globe‐Talk has reduced its international call rate for all Australian customers. WorldxChange is now offering a flat rate of 39c per minute for calls to the United States. Telstra is now offering local call deals as low as 18c for households and 12c for high volume business customers.

Like the minister, I believe that a great deal has occurred, and more cost savings for telecommunications are in prospect. This development, this very rapid change, is placing Australia well for these new products and services in the information age. I fully support other developments that the government is now involved with, including new electronic commerce centres that allow small businesses in like fields—like aquiculture and dairying—to get on‐line delivery and services nationally and overseas.

This IPAC report is to be recommended. It outlines a blueprint for structural adjustment which will take our economy into the information age. I commend the report and its contents to the Senate and to the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I want to speak about this government's commitment to end discrimination against women. Since the 1970s, successive governments, both Liberal and Labor, have supported the need to end discrimination against Australian women. It has been part of a worldwide movement. Malcolm Fraser, Gough Whitlam, Bob Hawke, Paul Keating and John Howard—having appointed Senator Jocelyn Newman as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women—are all, I presume, united in their commitment to end discrimination against women.

SPEECH.PARA: In July the Australian government had to report to the United Nations on its policies that implement our obligations under the Convention to Eliminate All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I am surprised that, since the United Nations issued its report, the minister, Senator Newman, has not, to my knowledge, spoken publicly about its recom mendations and how she proposes to implement them. I am hoping that I can remind her of her obligations in this regard.
The CEDAW committee said in response to the Australian government's report:

Government should carefully monitor the impact of recent policy changes in all areas covered by the Convention for inclusion in its next periodic report. . . [and] conduct analyses of the successes and shortcomings of the new policies. . . It recommended that the Government design a long-term strategy aimed at the full implementation of the Convention.

I am sure Senator Newman is working on that, but I think both this chamber and indeed the Australian electorate would like to hear from her about the plans that this government has to not only meet its responsibilities as a signatory to the convention, but to take up the recommendations.
There were a number of areas of concern. The report states:

The Committee was concerned about the Government's apparent shift in attention and commitment to the human rights of women and the achievement of gender equality. Indications such as the cut by 38 per cent in the budget of the Office of the Status of Women gave rise to concern. While increased efforts at gender mainstreaming into all sectoral areas were commendable, the Committee was concerned about the weakened role of national machinery in providing policy advice on equality issues.

I would have to ask: has Senator Newman insisted at cabinet that the advice of the Office of the Status of Women on the need to retain the Sex Discrimination Commissioner's position—and indeed I would argue the other commissioners that specialise in their relevant areas of expertise—be maintained? It is extraordinary to think that in 1997 there could still be a debate about whether or not Australia needs a sex discrimination commissioner, but in the end that is precisely the debate that is still being held within cabinet circles.

If Senator Newman were to detail this forward‐looking strategy as recommended, it would make it much easier for her to add weight to the need to retain the sex discrimination position. The committee went on to say:

The Committee was alarmed by policy changes that apparently slowed down, or reversed, Australia's progress in achieving equality between women and men, such as in housing and childcare programmes, and in employment assistance. It was concerned about the delay in appointing a Sex Discrimination Commissioner and about the Government's declared intention to change its human rights policy and legislation as it pertained to women.
The report went on to state:

The Committee expressed its concern that at a time of fiscal constraint, resources for programmes and policies benefiting women or aimed at overcoming discrimination, such as in health, in the provision of legal aid services, of training and awareness programmes for health workers, judicial, professional and others on violence against women, might be subjected to disproportionate budget cuts.
The Committee noted with concern that violence against women, notwithstanding major efforts, remained a central concern to Australian women. . .

The Committee noted with concern that legislation on industrial relations providing for the negotiation of individual contracts between employer and employee may have a disproportionately negative impact on women. Part-time and casual workers, of which women formed a disproportionate share, are usually in a weaker position than other workers to negotiate favourable working agreements, in particular with regard to benefits. The reservation to the Convention with regard to paid maternity leave, and Australia's non-ratification of ILO Convention 103, remain a concern for women workers with family responsibilities.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I would remind senators that these are statements that are being made by those people who are expert in monitoring the progress of countries around the world. These are not comments coming from the opposition, though of course we have made these points in debate repeatedly over the last 12 to 18 months.

But I want to put it very firmly on the public record that Australia is risking losing its very forward‐looking reputation that it had during the 1980s when the previous Labor government gave a major commitment to gender equality issues, gender policy development, women's budgeting, child care and all the programs that particularly focused on the need for women to be given a greater say and equality within society.

I am sure from my conversations with a number of women members and senators from the government that they share my concern. But, to date, they have not been able to get that level of concern reflected in cabinet decision making. I understand that. I have sat at the cabinet table. I know there are misogynists around this parliament. There are also many men who are very supportive of women having an equal role in the participation of decision making and all aspects of community life.

I sympathise with government women, but I say to them—and particularly to Senator Newman—that it is time they stood up to be counted. They cannot always hide behind cabinet solidarity or support for what is the predominant view within the party room. When women were elected to the coalition, they were elected on the basis that they would speak out strongly on these issues. Regrettably, I feel they must be being constrained or we would not have received this report from the United Nations.

The United Nations made some suggestions and recommendations. I actually called it something of a 10-point plan for the equality of women. We have still to hear from the government as to how they are going to respond. The report went on to state:

The Committee recommended that the Government should carefully monitor the impact of recent policy changes in all areas covered by the Convention . . . It recommended that the Government design a long-term strategy . . .

They particularly singled out the need for an evaluation of the Workplace Relations Act and an assessment of its impact on women of different age groups with different educational levels and in different occupational groups, and especially to focus on part time and casual women workers.

The committee further encouraged the government to assess the benefits of a continuing national women's health policy—again, an area that is subject to much concern among women generally, particularly those who work in the women's health area. Because of negotiations for devolution to the states, there is, to my knowledge—and I am happy to be corrected—because I talk with women health workers quite consistently, no guaranteed protection to maintain the momen tum built up by the national women's health strategy over nearly 10 years now. We cannot, I think, trust state governments to automatically put the priority on these issues that have previously been set at the national level. The report goes on:
The Committee recommended that the Convention, as well as the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action should be translated for non-English‐speaking Australians.
Has that issue been taken up with Mr Ruddock? It goes on:
The Committee recommended that a comprehensive strategy to eliminate violence against women should be adopted following the National Domestic Violence Summit.

I commend the government for holding a summit, but we have to have the commitment and the resources to follow through. There are so many financial cutbacks, both in the legal aid area and in resourcing, particularly to women in rural areas, that all the fine words that may be expressed at the summit will come to nothing if there is not a commensurate commitment to dollar resources. The report goes on:
The Committee noted differing state provisions in relation to prostitution and encouraged the Government to assess the effectiveness of varying measures in reducing the exploitation of prostitution.

The Committee encouraged the Government to collect statistical data on the participation of indigenous women in the work force, in decision‐making, in politics and administration, and in the judiciary.

On a positive note, I want to commend Senator Newman and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for the choice of indigenous women in terms of the constitutional convention. That is a positive move, and I acknowledge it. The report goes on:

The Committee recommended that, in the light of Mabo and Wik judgments of the High Court, the Government should develop the necessary legislative and policy measures to ensure women's equal access to . . . native land.

That is an area that will be of considerable interest to this chamber in the coming months. Are women's views in relation to, particularly, the 10-point plan being considered by the government? The report continues:

BREAK.PARA: The Committee encouraged the Government to strengthen its support for women's studies, to provide funding for research and teaching, and to facilitate international academic exchange and cooperation in that field.

I wonder if Minister Vanstone has had that recommendation placed within her area of responsibility. I would also note that it is very important that the officers of the Office of the Status of Women be resourced both physically—in terms of staffing—and with travel to allow them to continue to play the role that Australia has played in the last 10 or so years in leading on gender policy issues.

I find it very sad that the office has been so dramatically cut, which places a great deal of stress on those dedicated officers who are still doing their best to maintain the input on all decisions affecting women. Of course, we know women's issues are not some narrow little basket over here. We have to have a gender perspective across all areas of government decision making. Frankly, I am not convinced that this government has yet acknowledged that. The report continues:
The Committee encouraged the Government to resume its active and visible participation in international forums on women's equality . . .
It also recommended that the government ensure there is wide dissemination of this report so that women in the Australian community can monitor this government's progress.

In conclusion, I appeal to Senator Newman to mobilise all those women on the government side and go to the Prime Minister and insist that gender policy be given a high priority by this government. There is no point having elected a large number of women to the coalition ranks—and I congratulated them on a non-partisan basis for that—if they are not allowed to do anything. What are they allowed to do if we get this kind of report from the United Nations?

There is a lot of rebuilding to do. There is a lot of work that Senator Newman and her women colleagues, in consultation with the Prime Minister and cabinet, must address. I hope that we will hear from Senator Newman. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a topic which has been the subject of a spate of attacks by politicians and public figures in recent weeks and months—that is, the High Court of Australia and its judges. While it is healthy for any public institution to be subject to public appraisal, the strength and tenure of recent attacks on the High Court and its judges has placed a renewed focus on the composition, role and function of the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The confidence of the community in the High Court has been deliberately eroded for political reasons. It is important, indeed vital, that the community maintain a high level of confidence in the highest court of the land. One method of doing this is to ensure that there is confidence in the appointments process. We must, as a nation, protect the reputation, independence and legitimacy of the High Court and its office holders.

The coalition has failed to take the lead on this issue and to depoliticise judicial appointments. Indeed, it has done the reverse. The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, has deliberately politicised the debate with his comments that the coalition intends to introduce capital `C' conservative coalition judges.

It is unsatisfactory that under the current system we must simply trust that the Commonwealth Attorney-General, who is responsible for the appointment of judges, consults with the Chief Justice of the High Court, the state attorneys‐general and relevant presidents of law societies in determining who, according to convention, is the most eminent and capable barrister or judge. This is a problem which is reinforced because, historically, such persons have tended to be from a common background, and the inference has therefore been that appointments to the High Court have been affected by that social bias. They are regarded, rightly or wrongly, as establishment figures.

In our view the current method of appointment is archaic and inadequate for an open and modern democratic system that rests on the doctrine of the separation of powers. A transparent, open and independent selection process must be put in place if we are to safeguard the judiciary and improve accountability. The principles of open government must be applied to the appointments process. Its workings must be transparent, and information about appointments must be disclosed to parliament and the public. Many establishment figures will resist such changes, being comfortable with the old ways. But the campaign of the Deputy Prime Minister and others of his ilk has, in my view, placed the appointments of High Court judges in real danger.

The three principal weaknesses with the current system of appointment of judges to the High Court of Australia are that, firstly, the qualifications for appointment are not adequately prescribed; secondly, there is no regulation or established selection procedure; and, thirdly, there is an absence of effective external scrutiny of appointments.

The current method of appointment is of concern for a number of reasons. Judicial appointments tend to be clouded in secrecy, making it impossible to determine the process by which a choice is made. This does not serve to promote or protect judicial independence, nor does it enhance public confidence or trust in the judiciary.

Despite the separation of the powers, appointments to the High Court are still made by the executive. This creates a risk that the independence of the judiciary is weakened or even undermined by the appearance of ministerial patronage connected to judicial appointments to the High Court, a perception of patronage which is specifically confirmed by the remarks of the Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer.

Those statements have exposed the establishment's long complicity in the now explicit expectation of the executive that they can bypass the separation of powers and appoint judges to the High Court who are not politically independent. Therefore, the principles of open government have to be applied to the appointments process. Its workings must be transparent, and information about appointments must be disclosed to parliament and the public.

BREAK.PARA: In order to reduce the politicisation of the judiciary, appointment methods should be scrutinised by an independent body such as those recommended in the Australian Democrats's model which I released recently. These failings in the current method of appointments mean that there exists no real accountability in respect of judicial appointments.

The Commonwealth constitution sets out basic requirements and restrictions on the make‐up of appointment to the High Court and on the qualifications of appointees. The constitution provides that the High Court shall consist of a chief justice; there should be at least two other justices—currently there are six, plus the chief justice; appointments should be made by the Governor-General in council, which is made on the advice of the executive, incidentally; and appointees must be less than 70 years old.

The High Court of Australia Act 1979 adds some basic but important requirements on appointments. It provides that the Commonwealth Attorney‐General consult with the attorneys‐general of the states before an appointment is made and that the candidate must have served as a judge of a court or must have been enrolled as a barrister or solicitor for not less than five years. These requirements are minimal, and one of them is largely discretionary, and they do not set in place procedures or criteria which ensure an open and transparent selection process based on merit.

The aim of the appointment process to the High Court should be to make the selection process transparent and open to scrutiny, to ensure that appointment is on the basis of merit and to ensure that no artificial barriers prevent the appointment of women and other under‐represented groups.

The Australian Democrats have therefore recommended that a judicial appointments committee be established as a selection and advisory body, that selection criteria be established and made public to assist in the evaluation of suitable candidates, and that the selection criteria be recorded in a protocol and be reviewed periodically by the judicial appointments committee.

A judicial appointments committee should be established to select and recommend appointees to the High Court. We think that that committee should comprise at least seven members. We believe the members should include the following: the Commonwealth Attorney-General; one representative nominated by the Australian Bar Association; one representative nominated by the Law Council of Australia; one academic with expertise in constitutional law; one community representative; and two representatives of the states nominated by COAG, the joint Australian governments committee.

The function of the judicial appointments committee would be to scrutinise applicants and recommend the selection of future High Court judges who are then to be appointed by the Governor‐General; establish and publish the qualifications for appointment and selection criteria; and record in a protocol qualifications for appointment and selection criteria to be reviewed periodically by the judicial appointments committee.

The qualifications, skills and experience which are required for appointees to the High Court should be clearly set out in the selection criteria. Merit must be the overriding principle governing selections for appointments to the High Court, not Mr Fischer's capital `C' conservative coalition political criteria. Equal opportunity principles must be included in the selection processes as well as consideration given to non‐traditional and minority representation in the make‐up of the bench.

Individuals selected for appointments must be independent from government, independent from political parties and independent from other politically partisan organisations. Individuals selected for appointment must match standards of probity and must satisfy the appropriate level of professionalism. Establishing a system of appointment which provides for independent scrutiny of applicants and which sets out the selection criteria and the method of appointment for the High Court of Australia would provide transparency; it would reduce the potential for political appointments; it would broaden the representation within the court; it would safeguard the independence of the judiciary; and it would improve accountability.

It also would defeat the declared and deliberate intention of this government to appoint judges of a particular flavour. The Australian Democrats and I do not want capital `C' conservative judges or capital `L' Liberal or Labor judges. We want capital `I' independent judges selected for their capital `M' merit. We have therefore commended our model to the Senate. We regret that the Senate, through the major parties, saw fit to reject our recommendations. We continue to urge the government to implement our model before the next two judicial appointments to the High Court, which are due early next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday marked the successful completion of round one of the Commonwealth Green Corps initiative, `young Australians for the environment'. On Friday the Green Corps participants in the 24 round‐one projects attended graduation ceremonies which celebrated their achievements over the last six months. I am sure all honourable senators share with me the admiration of these young people who have volunteered—I emphasise `volunteered'—to join the Green Corps. They are genuinely committed to the future of Australia and genuinely committed to improving the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The completion of the first round marks the delivery of a key election commitment by this government. The Green Corps is a commitment to help young people and a commitment to help the Australian environment. Australia has daunting environmental problems, ranging from salinisation of our best farmlands to weed invasion of our most treasured national parks.

In recognition of these problems the government announced the Natural Heritage Trust, which will deliver a better environment for all Australians. Green Corps sits beside the Natural Heritage Trust as another strategy to assist the efforts to improve the environment.

As a society, we are trying to do less damage to the environment which sustains us. But remedying 200 years of neglect and outright vandalism is a massive task, requiring in many cases a great deal of painstaking and skilful hands-on work. Just as we are concerned to restore our land to its potential, we also want our young people to reach their potential, and Green Corps is effective training—intelligent, 1990s skills training.

Because Green Corps is managed on the government's behalf by a leading private sector environmental organisation, it has harnessed private sector methods to Public Service objectives. Occasionally a government program perfectly meets the needs of the time and fires the imagination of a country. The Green Corps program is one of these. It is young people participating in projects designed to allow them to demonstrate their commitment to improving Australia's natural and cultural environment. At the same time, they are helping the community and learning new skills.

In addition to undertaking a major environmental project, Green Corps participants also receive training. Last Friday I had the pleasure and honour of attending the graduation of the Green Corps participants at Merimbula. The trainees at Merimbula were trained in environmental auditing, first aid, land conservation, occupational health and safety, introduction to chainsaw safety, weed control, park pathway construction, planting and on‐site practical use of tools. That sort of training received by that particular Green Corps is mirrored and multiplied right throughout Australia in all the various Green Corps projects under way at the present time.

Green Corps participants are required to commit 40 hours per week for 26 weeks, the duration of the project. The skills achieved by Green Corps participants are many and varied. Again in the case of the Merimbula group, the participants received skills relating to power tool use, environmental design, team work, leadership, commitment, responsibility, reliability and a respect for our environment.

BREAK.PARA: So we see that young people who have recently graduated from the Green Corps program have developed these new skills and have developed confidence. They have a certain knowledge of their ability to take on complex tasks and to see them through to completion. They can also be assured that in doing this they have committed not only to the local communities in which they have undertaken their projects but also to the Australian community at large.

To this end, the Green Corps has built into it a community service component. This component of the project involves the participants identifying how they believe they can contribute to the community in which they are working.

I hope that Green Corps team members will come back with their friends and families, and in time their children, to visit their projects and say with justifiable pride that they took part in the Green Corps and contributed to this walking track or that repair of an eroded area, or participated in some other way in a Green Corps project right around Australia.

They will be able to identify what they have learnt about their environment from the work they have done, and they will be able to say with some pride that they were instrumental in preserving a part of Australia's flora and fauna or as the case may be, depending on their particular Green Corps project.

So far we have received a lot of positive feedback, particularly from participants, supervisors and the partner agencies. By sitting and talking to the participants and encouraging their ideas and feedback, we will be able to continue to improve the program and make sure that it meets the government's aims and objectives, improves the environment and gives training and incentive to the young people involved.

Because it has been such a well received program, I was a little disappointed recently to hear the carping criticism from one particular senator, who is becoming known for her carping, who obviously has not taken the trouble to understand the Green Corps or to get her facts correct. The Green Corps is not—I repeat not—an employment program. It is an environmental initiative for volun teers—I emphasise `volunteers'—who receive a training wage strictly according to the award, and they also receive training.

Amongst the many positive comments from participants and others alike, I have seen only one complaint. Interestingly, it was the one that the senator mentioned recently, which, curiously, was not in a letter or a comment to government but in a letter to a newspaper copied to five politicians, two of whom were Democrat politicians. It was quite a well constructed letter but, interestingly again, for such a well constructed letter the names of the two Democrat senators were badly misspelt. I found that interesting. If any senator has suggestions about how to improve this exciting initiative and has a genuine interest in the environment, as opposed to trying to score a couple of cheap political points, I would welcome that input just as I do welcome and do actually receive input from participants in these programs.

To give full recognition to these projects, the government has provided funds for a plaque to be erected in each Green Corps project location, which will list the names of the young volunteers involved and will also list the partner agency. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and as one with a particular interest in the Green Corps program, I have attended a number of Green Corps project and group meetings right around Australia.

The project in Merimbula had significant environmental and training achievements, with the young participants reflecting that the project had boosted their self‐confidence and independence and had motivated many of them to take a greater interest in environmental management issues. I have got the same feeling from the visit I had and from the contact I have had with the Green Corps in my home town of Townsville. This is a great group of young people who have done very worthwhile work on the banks of the Ross River in conjunction with the Townsville City Council which, like all the partner agencies, has made a magnificent contribution to this program.

As well, I have had the privilege of speaking with the participants and being involved with Green Corps projects in Cooktown and Malanda in north Queensland, and Sydney, amongst others, and they have all been particularly worthwhile experiences for me. In going to speak to these people, I have seen their enthusiasm for the work they have volunteered to do. I was particularly encouraged when one young participant said to me, `I am still not quite sure if I will devote my life to an environmental career but taking part in Green Corps has shown me how much hard physical work and money is required to ensure that we have a sustainable environment.'

Many other comments from participants have indicated to me that they now take a much greater interest in our environment and in our country. Even if they do not proceed to training in environmental areas, they certainly have benefited very considerably from their involvement in the Green Corps. Many of the participants, however, have indicated that they will be pursuing environmental studies. If they do, of course, they will be receiving the government's $500 contribution towards the cost of the studies. Many of them will be going on to do that, but all of them have acknowledged the huge benefits that they have gained from their involvement. I and, I am sure, all honourable senators congratulate all of the participants throughout Australia in these Green Corps on their efforts. I am sure that all senators will again join me in wishing these participants and recent graduates well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak during the matters of public interest time on an issue that I certainly am very concerned about, given the direction of the federal government. The issue is information technology and its role in Australian society leading up to the new millennium. There has been a recent proliferation of reports prepared from a number of perspectives emanating from the government on this particular issue. The two I would like to make greatest reference to today are the report entitled The global information economy: the way ahead from the Information Industries Taskforce, commonly known as the Goldsworthy report, and the report entitled A national policy framework for structural adjustment within the new Commonwealth of information , a product of the Information Policy Advisory Council and which I will refer to as the IPAC report.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrival of these two reports coincides with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) rediscovering or, perhaps in his case, discovering information technology as an issue of substance for the very first time. It is an issue that has been quite well documented in a global sense as well as in the Australian political context and certainly with great detail in the period of the previous Labor government. In the context of global dialogue about industry development and the future of the global economy, it is at the forefront of those discussions. But here in Australia our Prime Minister has just discovered information services and information technology, so much so that his discovery of this issue just happens to coincide with the delivery of a number of reports that attempt to position this government in such a way as to somehow focus a positive policy direction on that particular sector.

I would like to refer briefly to some of the common themes within both of these reports as there are some very interesting similarities. The first is, of course, the positive commonality—that is, the high degree of emphasis that both reports place on industry intervention as a means by which the government can support and foster growth in this particular sector. The various proposals put forward in both the Goldsworthy and IPAC reports in relation to this have varying degrees of merit. It is not my intention today to explore specifically the substance of the particular measures proposed other than to say that the clamour from the private sector, from the industry, for the government to take far greater responsibility for industry development is very loud in all industries, and these two reports focus specifically on the fact that there is a lot of complaint from the IT sector about the lack of support from this current government. It is worth mentioning that the research and development incentives that the government has cut in previous budgets form an integral part of what has shaped industry's perception of neglect by this federal government in that regard.

Another commonality between these two reports is not so positive but, again, is worthy of emphasis, given that it goes straight to the heart of the attitude of this government. That is that both reports state, at the very top of the priorities of government, that leadership is required from this government to show the commitment it has to the development of this critical industry sector. It is leadership that has been so lacking, and that is why the Prime Minister's recent discovery of IT as an issue lacks so much credibility. That is why it has been taken with a degree of contempt within the industry.

Lack of leadership at such a critical time in the development of this sector is what has denied this country not just 18 months of a critical growth period since this government has been in power but far longer than that in terms of impact because of the regressive steps this government has made with industry development policy: research and development incentive cuts, the computer bounty being denied and so forth. So we are not just talking about standing still for 18 months; we are also talking about an industry that has actually regressed under the lack of leadership of this federal Liberal government.

This is, of course, a particularly sad indictment for all of those private sector entrepreneurs who were fooled into believing that this federal Liberal government was actually good for business, as was stated in just about every piece of election propaganda that it could associate itself with. Those lessons have been hard learnt by the private sector. Whilst this government has recently claimed to be supportive of this particular sector, the sector has learnt from bitter experience and bitter disappointment that this government can no longer be trusted in that regard.

There is another common theme within both of these reports that reflects on another critical issue confronting the IT sector at the moment. It is in relation to government procurement policies. The outsourcing of IT services in government departments has certainly not only been embarked upon in this year's budget decision by Minister Fahey to actually proceed upon a specific program to do that. What we have also seen is that both of these reports have taken the same path as Minister Fahey in respect of IT outsourcing.

I will explain what I am talking about. The path taken by all of these groups has been one that favours the position of the large corporations in the sector—the multinationals, the top end of town or whatever you want to call them. The involvement of those corporations—whether it is through their involvement in advising the Office of Government Information Technology and the Department of Finance or whether it is through their involvement in the respective boards and committees that have prepared these reports—has ensured a structural bias in these proposals against local indigenous Australian small to medium enterprises in the IT sector. There is no other way of describing the alienation and the exclusion of that part of the industry in all of these proposals.

Not once have I seen a recommendation or a policy proposal forthcoming from this government that turns specifically to the needs of the local small business IT sector. In fact, in a greatly detailed exploration of the outsourcing plans of this federal government, we find evidence of very specific cases of exclusion of these firms to the point where their very involvement in the competitive process for the outsourcing of the IT services of Commonwealth departments hinges upon the benevolence of a multinational to take a local company under its wing in some form of partnership or subcontract arrangement and hence allow its participation.It is a structural issue that emerges from the concept of a competitive regime as being what delivers savings to government. The problem is that, in a competitive regime delivering savings to government, the people advising government of those structures are the ones who have said from the outset that the savings will come only through efficiencies relating to size. It is their magnitude that allows them to provide those returns or savings to government.

I offer a couple of other points. First of all, if the prerequisite of the delivery of those savings to government relates to size and cost efficiencies, why is the evidence not there in a global context that those savings are actually forthcoming? We have a couple of Australian and many global examples of the savings being advocated prior to an IT outsourcing arrangement not being realised in many cases in the short, medium and long term. So it is interesting to note that, now that we have exposed that reality, we hear justification of the outsourcing process of government IT services now being for reasons of industry development.

This quite specific shift by the government in justifying its IT outsourcing can again be explained very simply by looking towards the actual structural processes that have been put in place for that IT outsourcing. They go straight to the heart of the ability of the larger corporations, multinational ones, to allegedly facilitate and foster sector growth in the particular area in which they establish themselves. So we are seeing a change in position as the debate evolves around IT outsourcing in industry development.

The last point I want to make about outsourcing is this: it is too easy to pocket small local IT business in one area and large multinational corporations in another and have a political debate about who is in favour and who is not in favour. The facts are that, in this industry, there is a combination of all of those entities. We have multinational corporations with regional offices which operate very much at a local level. They employ local people, they have a local development plan, a local business plan and they bring great benefit to the local economy.

However, given this blend for the purposes of the point I am trying to make, I am talking about the vertically integrated corporations who do not seek to establish regional offices with the degree of autonomy that contributes to the local economies. I am talking about the companies that seize the opportunity to secure massive contracts and then, for the purposes of delivering the promised savings, deal with the management of their work force and the management of the services that they provide and the equipment that they provide in a way that directly disadvantages, first, job prospects for Australian people and, second, the equip ment supply sector that has traditionally fed Australian demand for hardware and software.

It is those sorts of issues that must be addressed quite specifically in any government procurement or outsourcing strategy. It also addresses the need for a more complex analysis of multinationals and small Australian businesses to see who is returning the benefits in terms of jobs, revenue to the local economy and industry development incentives, innovation growth and so forth.

In summing up, it is a sad day when you see two generally well constructed reports—although certainly lacking in some depth—focus their primary issue on the lack of leadership in this area in this country. It is a vindication of the neglect of industry that both reports advocate the high level of industry intervention that has not been forthcoming under this government, which has left this industry not just at a standstill for the last 18 months since the Liberals have been in power but, in fact, regressed and denied a significant proportion of growth that would have continued to occur under the sound policies that fostered growth put in place by the Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, John Howard, has spent the whole of 1997 going backwards in the polls, but he has decided to fight back with a goods and services tax. There is not one member of the Senate unfamiliar with the issues of Fightback, so let's bring on the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: First, there are his guiding principles: no overall increase in the tax burden; a reduction in personal income tax; and a broad based consumption tax to replace existing indirect taxes. Every proposal for a GST starts with the GST replacing the present wholesale sales tax. In addition, advocates of a goods and services tax want to replace payroll tax. A GST which exempts basic necessities would have to be set at 11 per cent to cover just those two issues. Advocates of a GST—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?
—Professor Freebairn, actually; he is a bit of an expert whom you guys quote regularly.
—Who is he?

—A supporter of the GST. Advocates of a GST want to remove stamp and financial institutions duties. According to Professor Freebairn, a GST would have to be set at 15 per cent to cover removal of stamp and financial institutions duties as well as the removal of wholesale sales tax and payroll tax. But, according to John Howard, the GST must not only cover the removal of all of those items, but also provide an income tax reduction of 10 per cent, which would mean increasing the goods and services tax to 19 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party—and there are a couple of colleagues over there—insist on removing the fuel excise as well. That would lead you to a GST of close to 25 per cent. This is the wish list from the other side in the tax debate. Let's have the debate, let's have some honesty from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're speculating.

—I am quoting the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer. If John Howard is to achieve major tax reform, as he now advocates, Australians will get a GST set at 25 per cent. We are back to the John Hewson package that was rejected by the electorate in 1993. The only difference this time is that John Howard will attempt to deceive the electorate, as he did before, by not showing his hand.

SPEECH.PARA: The former leader, John Hewson, set his GST at 15 per cent. But to achieve his target, which was to abolish payroll tax and petrol excise and cut income tax, he had to cut government spending by $10 billion per year. This option is not available to those on the other side because you have already made those cuts. And you have promised there will be no further major cutbacks to health and education. But a GST involves new taxes. A GST means a tax on tourism. There are now six million visitors to Australia each year. At the start of the decade there were less than three million visitors per year. By the year 2000 there will be 10 million visitors per year. Tourism is our fastest growing export industry. Can we afford a broad ranging tax on every aspect of tourism—for example, air fares, hotel accommodation, meals, taxis?
Tourism is increasingly price sensitive. It is a competitive market out there. Do the Queensland coalition senators suggest a GST on all aspects of tourism?

TALK.START.PARA: —You have obviously got no idea on the way it works. The thing is rebatable all the way through.

—That is a decision that is yet to be taken or suggested by your side. A GST means a tax on health. As our population ages, there is an increased demand for access to medical and surgical treatment, nursing homes, special accommodation houses, palliative care and the provision of increased services to enable people to stay in their own homes for as long as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Coalition senators are interjecting. Why won't the Prime Minister rule out taxes in these areas? Why won't he say he is going to exempt these areas from GST—make them rebatable? He was asked last week in the House—and what did he do? He squibbed it! He would not give a commitment to zero rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of a GST means that there will be a broad based tax on: visits to the doctor; in‐patient surgical treatment; day surgery; physiotherapy; dental treatment; podiatry; nursing home accommodation; meals on wheels; cleaning in the home; house repairs and maintenance; gardening; nursing in the home for palliative care patients; feeding and veterinary treatment for pets; funerals; and, of course, private health insurance. All you had to do last week was rule this out, and you would not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party is a bit concerned about the funerals.
—For the aged on fixed incomes the introduction of a broadly based tax on health care will be a nightmare. A new tax on private health insurance will be John Howard's funeral.

BREAK.PARA: A GST means a tax on education. Education is one of the most rapidly growing export industries and, of course, is the cornerstone, the key investment, to our future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Export industries do not have a GST.
—You have just got to give them an exemption; just stand up here and do it. You're on the frontbench. Give the exemption; commit to it. Don't sit here making interjections; give a commitment to it.

BREAK.PARA: The introduction of a GST means that there will be a broadly based tax on all aspects of education: child care; kindergarten; books; school uniforms; private school fees; tutorial assistance; private music or foreign language lessons; sporting equipment and uniforms; university union fees; HECS fees; library fees; meals at school or university; train and bus tickets; project materials; science equipment; and paintings. That is what you guys want to tax—or you could give it an exemption. Have some courage and say where your position is; say what your rate is. Education must be affordable at all levels for parents and students, both local and overseas. A GST will undermine the competitiveness of Australian education. As a nation, we cannot allow this to happen.

There are a number of myths peddled by our opponents about the benefits of the GST. This is very important. The first myth the coalition government try to peddle is that Australia is one of the highest taxed nations in the world. Unfortunately, the statistics do not bear this out. In comparison with most other developed countries, Australia has a much lower proportion of income tax in its national tax take. Australia is at 54 per cent; the OECD average is at 61 per cent. That is once you add in the social security levies they have in other countries, which coalition conveniently members leave out when they make these comparisons. Australia's level of taxation is 8.5 per cent of GDP, which is lower than the average of comparable countries. We pay $40 billion less than we would if we were taxed at the average levels of OECD countries.

The next myth they peddle is that Australia is to reliant on income tax. But when it comes to taxes on goods and services as a proportion of the overall national tax cake, Australia is more or less equal to the average of advanced industrial countries. Australia is about 30 per cent; the OECD is about 32 per cent.

Then they say that there would be less tax avoidance with the GST. This is probably the cruellest trick the coalition is trying to pull. They want people to believe that a GST will end tax avoidance. There is no correlation between a country having a GST and having a small black economy. Currently, income from trade in personal services often escapes income tax through non‐declaration. Imposing a GST on personal services, for example, home maintenance, would actually increase the incentive for non‐declaration of income, thereby allowing both GST and income tax to be evaded. While it is true that the spending on this black economy income would involve some GST being paid, some taxes are already paid on the spending through the existing wholesale sales tax and excise system.

Another claim they make is that a GST is going to increase the savings ratio. A GST is not the answer to improving national savings. There is no evidence of that happening. The Netherlands and Belgium both have consumption taxes. But while Belgium has the highest savings rate of the major OECD countries, at 16.5 per cent, the Netherlands has the lowest saving rate at 0.2 per cent. There is no evidence anywhere in the world that a GST will lead to an increase in savings.
Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just find it, Senator Ferguson. You find it and you table it in the Senate. Savings are simply deferred consumption. So if we increase our tax on consumer goods, that tax will be paid whether we spend it now or later. Hence it does not affect our decision when to spend.

BREAK.PARA: It makes exports cheaper—that is a hoary old chestnut that they trot out. If we improve the relative position of exports compared with imports by changing the tax base, making it rebatable, it is likely the benefit would be wiped out by an appreciation in the dollar. That is what happens in the real world. Let's have none of this myth peddling about how exports are going to be cheaper. You are living in the 1970s with a fixed exchange rate. You are showing your age.

But the really obscene claim by the government is that the GST is going to fix unemployment. A GST is no solution to unemployment. The United States does not have a GST, but it does have one of the lower levels of unemployment among advanced countries. On the other hand, Germany, France, Spain, Italy, despite having GSTs, have high rates of unemployment, averaging around 12 per cent. Canada introduced a GST in 1991, but its unemployment rate remains high at 9.1 per cent.
Small businesses will benefit—another myth.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Minister, in allocating federal parliamentary representatives to the Constitutional Convention, why did the government decide to appoint 12 coalition delegates and six opposition delegates? Why has the government ditched the convention of the past 25 years—the entrenched principle of appointing equal representation between government and non‐government parties? How many of the Leader of the Opposition's nominees for the 36 appointed delegates were accepted by the government?

—Some of that information I will need to seek, but I presume that the coalition got more representatives because there are many more in the coalition. I would have thought that was as deeply entrenched as any other principle—that, if you want the numbers to reflect the numbers serving in the parliament, I think it will work out pretty much as—
—The will of the people.

—The will of the people, as my colleague Senator Alston says. It is an attempt to get some reflection of what the people's choice is. The people chose what?—40 more coalition representatives in the House of Representatives than you have. I suspect, without checking the numbers—and Senator Faulkner will tell me if I am wrong—that the numbers from the Senate are probably equal. In the House of Representatives, I would expect there to be considerably more from the coalition.

—As Senator Hill checks the proportions, he will probably be able to establish that, in fact, the parliamentary parties' representation is not broken up between the two houses. And can you assure the Senate that all the appointed delegates are Australian citizens?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is one of those matters that I should seek further information on.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well I didn't do the appointments; I obviously cannot assure you of that, but I will check on the facts.
—I draw senators' attention to the presence in the President's Gallery of our former distinguished Tasmanian colleague the Hon. Michael Tate. Welcome to the chamber and welcome back to Australia.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Will the minister outline the excellent latest results, released today, by major Australian companies and industry associations in reducing greenhouse gas emissions under the government's greenhouse challenge program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. In fact, today has been an exceptionally good day for the environment. First, we had this government deciding that Holsworthy should no longer be considered as a site for Sydney's second airport, on environmental grounds; in other words, based not just on instincts but on an objective assessment of sound science which, in effect, ruled out Holsworthy. I think this will demonstrate to all Australians the importance that this government attaches to achieving high environmental standards, which is what we have said all along. We are a pro‐development government but developments have got to meet the highest environmental standards, and we have demonstrated that today.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also a good day today because a number of major Australian companies have reported on their first year of activities under the government's cooperative greenhouse challenge process. Honourable senators will recall that this is a process in which Australian companies joined with the Australian government voluntarily to reduce greenhouse gases.

Reports have been received today from BHP, Rio Tinto, Shell and ICI, as well as from a number of major industry organisations. And the reports are very good. BHP, for example, forecast that they will save eight million tonnes of CO2 by the year 2000, keeping their emissions to 1995 levels even with increased production.

In the last 12 months, BHP have reduced their greenhouse gas emissions per tonne of coal from their New South Wales operations by 18 per cent and from their Queensland operations by 28 per cent. They should be commended. In the past 12 months, 52 projects were completed by Rio Tinto, which saved 563,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions. They have also committed themselves to a further reduction of 677,000 tonnes. ICI have saved an estimated 240,000 tonnes. Shell completed all their 1996 actions, which saved 6,000 tonnes of CO2. They are working towards savings of over 230,000 tonnes of CO2 in 1997.

Furthermore, as I said, industry organisations have been at the fore. Six electricity companies have now concluded cooperative agreements and a further 20 are expected to sign such agreements. That was reported to us today by their organisation. The pulp and paper manufacturers also report progress by their companies.

What is happening, therefore, is that Australian companies—corporate Australia—are rising to the challenge and voluntarily putting in processes that produce a better greenhouse outcome. That is very important in Australia meeting its fair share of the international responsibility to produce a better greenhouse outcome. It is a demonstration that this government is working towards achieving a good goal; a goal of contributing to a better greenhouse outcome consistent with maintaining economic growth and jobs—something that the other sides of this parliament have been unable to understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How important is it that other companies take an active role in Australia's greenhouse response? Is the minister aware of any confusion over the differences between the greenhouse effect and the hole in the ozone layer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is important that other companies join the challenge, particularly small to medium companies. Senator Parer, through his department, is taking a lead in encouraging them. Yes, it is also important that we clarify the misunderstandings that still exist. I am sorry, for example, that Senator Cook is not here today because while I was surfing the Hansard of last week I found him, when he was speaking of Mr Howard not going to UNGAS, asking why the Prime Minister was with Baroness Thatcher:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . when the world was gathered in earnest consideration of the effect of greenhouse emissions on the ozone layer . . .
He is confused. I will send him a copy of the ACF press release, which says:
A hole in the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect, for those who wanted to know the difference but were too afraid to ask.
It sets it out in simple terms. I am sure it will be helpful to Senator Cook. He might help educate his colleagues in that regard.

—Is it not a fact that the Newspoll survey that you mentioned shows 52 per cent of young Australians in favour of a republic and only 26 per cent against?

—I think it is an introduction to a question that ought not to be used. I would ask you to withdraw it and continue with your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer to the government's major reform of the Australian financial system announced yesterday. Would you please outline the benefits of these reforms for all Australians, especially those to rural and regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for that important question. The government's response to the recommendations of the financial systems inquiry, I think it is true to say, have been widely praised and endorsed. This is not surprising because they are good reforms. They are good for competition in industry, good for customers and good for all Australians, especially those in rural and regional Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The reforms will deliver billions of dollars of benefits for Australian businesses and consumers. The reforms are also built on the advantages of the existing arrangements, in preserving their basic goals of safety and stability. They help Australian consumers and businesses enjoy the benefits of new technologies and world best practice in the financial system and maximise the international competitiveness of our financial services industry. These benefits and others will flow to all Australians, including those in small business and those in rural and regional Australia.

As many honourable senators will know, the government supports Credit Care, an initiative to help establish credit unions in small towns where banks do not operate. A particularly pleasing aspect of the reforms to the payments system is that they will improve the capacity of credit unions and building societies to provide a full range of services to their customers. More intense competition between different financial institutions will benefit people throughout Australia.

As I have mentioned, the response to our initiatives has been overwhelmingly positive. Let me go through some of the responses that have already come to the government's attention. The Credit Union Services Corporation said, `The credit unions applaud the Wallis reforms. Credit unions are primed to lead a new wave of competition against the banks in the nation's $250 billion personal finance sector.' Aussie Home Loans, which is well known to senators in this chamber, has welcomed the government's response to the Wallis inquiry and will now investigate expansion into a number of new financial services activities, including the taking of deposits. The ANZ Banking Group said it praised the federal government's response to the Wallis inquiry recommendations, in particular the establishment of a new payments system to control risk in the financial system. Westpac said that the federal government's response represented `a bold set of policy decisions which potentially places Australia at the leading edge of change.'

The Life Insurance and Superannuation Association—better known to many as LISA—with a number of other groups, including the Investment Funds Association, strongly supports the government's response to the financial systems inquiry. The Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies said, `The building society industry is very positive about the Treasurer's announcement implementing the Wallis report.'

And so it goes on, with responses from the National Australia Bank, the Commonwealth Bank and last—but not entirely least—from Senator Sherry. Senator Sherry supports in principle the basic regulatory thrust of Wallis, but he did say, `We reserve our right to scrutinise the detail.' And, I have to say, that is as about as good as it ever gets from Senator Sherry. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know this—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ray has asked a question, and Senator Hill is entitled to answer it.

—This is extraordinary. You could be forgiven for believing that the government had appointed all the delegates to this convention. ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

—I will be a member of this convention, I am pleased to say, and, if Senator Ray is right about his assessment of the views of Dr Craven, I can assure him that I will be representing a different point of view. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray, as a reputed numbers man, could count the numbers and find that that is impossible.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No; if you add up the appointees of the government you will find it is impossible to achieve that outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too bad.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a day off. I presume the Dr Greg Craven from Western Australia is the Dr Greg Craven—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, just—
—Order!

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I am sitting right behind Senator Hill and have found it impossible to hear the answer he is giving. He was asked a question.
