—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to the Wallis inquiry response yesterday and to the Treasurer's comment when the report was first released in April that the small business banking market was uncompetitive. Is the minister aware of the survey by the ASCPA showing that small businesses face interest rates three to four per cent higher than for household customers? Has he read this week's Economist magazine, which shows that Australian businesses still face the highest real interest rates of any OECD country? Why, then, has the government refused to endorse the Wallis inquiry recommendation that small business be given access to the Banking Ombudsman scheme? Why has the government not yet endorsed the recommendation of the Reid fair trading committee to give small businesses legislative protection against unfair business conduct by banks? Will the government move to reverse its decision to stop subsidising small business loans through the Commonwealth Development Bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The senator has raised about four or five questions, and I will seek to respond to them. First, let me make a general comment. If we followed the policies that the Australian Democrats have relentlessly pursued, interest rates for small business would be far higher.
—Why?

—The question was: why? Because you have resisted every effort at fiscal consolidation in this country. One of the main reasons why there has been downward pressure on interest rates is the government's success in bringing the budget back into balance.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Murray, the first point I would make is that under your policies interest rates for small business would be higher. The second general comment I would make is that I know you have a particular interest in small business—I welcome that, and I support that—but the trouble is that you belong to a party which is anti small business.

Let me instance a couple of examples, Senator Murray. In relation to the unfair dismissal legislation, which was particularly designed to help small business, we are finding it impossible to get appropriate support from you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. It goes to relevance. Whilst I find all these misrepresentations interesting, could the minister answer the four questions I asked him on the Wallis inquiry?
—Senator Kemp, I draw your attention to the thrust of the questions as you develop your answer.

—The thrust of the question related to the interest rates available to small business and policies to assist small business. I would have to say that I am directly responding to that. The problem is that Senator Murray is showing signs of having a bit of a glass jaw. The trouble is that the Democrats are running a two-track policy. You come into this chamber and pretend you are supportive of small business, when many of the actions that you pursue in the chamber are anti small business.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think the Assistant Treasurer needs assistance with relevance. I will repeat the question: why has the government refused to implement the Banking Ombudsman scheme? Try to answer the question, Assistant Treasurer.
—Senator Kemp, I invite you to—

—There were actually five or six questions raised, so it is incorrect for Senator Murray to pretend that there was one question. What I am pointing out to Senator Murray is that, despite whatever efforts he makes in his party room, the Democrats relentlessly pursue policies that are anti small business. Of course, we can instance the recent debate in this chamber on the CGT rollover relief for small business, and we can instance the attitude that they took on that particular issue. So do not come in here and pretend that you are pro small business. Under your policies interest rates would soar. We are the party of small business. You are not.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Assistant Treasurer, it is a pity you are such a nice fellow because, really, that was a foolish answer. I would like you to move from blatant misrepresentations to just ordinary misrepresentations. If you are the party of small business, why do 80 per cent of small businesses now say that the economy is in recession or worse? If you are the party of small business, why have you not introduced the Wallis inquiry recommendation that small business be given access to the Banking Ombudsman scheme?

—It is absolutely incredible, I have to say, Senator Murray, that someone as nice as you could ask such silly questions. How can you say, on this day of all days—the day the national accounts figures have been produced and which show a very good growth in the economy; continued acceleration of growth—that things are looking grim in the economy? You are absolutely dead wrong. Let me tell you that under our policies we will continue to give particular emphasis to the needs of small business and we will continue to fight on behalf of small business against the arraigned forces, regrettably, of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. We are in this chamber to support small business because, in many ways, small business will be the engine room of growth in this economy. (Time expired)
—My question is addressed to Senator Hill as the minister representing the Prime Minister.
—Tone that shirt down a bit.

—It is not that different from the one Senator Newman is wearing. Minister, can you guarantee that the appointment of Ms Julie Bishop, a managing partner of Clayton Utz, Perth, as a non‐parliamentary delegate to the Constitutional Convention is not a pay‐off by the Prime Minister who, when in opposition, was a paid consultant to Clayton Utz on industrial relations matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is astonishing today that what the Labor Party—and I suspect Senator Ray—has orchestrated is an attack on a few individuals who have been appointed to the convention. I have just been looking at this list of who has been appointed. It includes Mr Djerrkura, somebody by the name of Bill Hayden, the Reverend Peter Hollingworth, Digger James, Helen Lynch, the Hon. Richard McGarvie, Donald McGauchie and Dame Roma Mitchell. Are you saying these are all Liberal fronts, Senator Ray? What a load of nonsense! What you have done, and rather crudely I might say, is pick out one or two individuals, attack them personally and slur the names of everyone involved in this.

ANSWER.PARA: This seems to me to be a good representative range of appointees by the government.It was interesting that, when it was announced, the leader of the Labor Party, Mr Beazley, did not seem to find much wrong with it. It is in this chamber, where they play the man differently, that it comes out; that you decide to pick on a few individuals, to degrade the process and all of those who have been appointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I reckon that is pretty poor politics. If you want to own up that it is your little trickery, you can do so. Mr Beazley took a different position from Senator Bolkus who, of course, condemned them without reflection. Mr Beazley said, `I think you will have to wait and see what the outcome is. It seems to have either something of a pro existing order or agnostic hue to the delegation but, on the other hand, many of them are distinguished Australians.' I thought the Adelaide Advertiser said it pretty well in its editorial, as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: We observe that the Prime Minister has done a good job and a mildly surprising one.
That surprised me.

Any temptation to stack the appointed list with monarchists seems, as far as published views of the participants are known, to have been resisted. There was a sensible balance of men and women, a thoughtful weighting for the Aboriginal population and due and proper recognition of youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I take a point of order. I have waited two minutes for the minister to answer my direct question. He did not do that. He has not once mentioned the name of Ms Julie Bishop who was the person I asked the question about. I resent the implication of the minister that I was trying to reflect on Ms Bishop or any other of the delegates that have been selected by the Prime Minister. If there is any reflection, it is against the Prime Minister. I ask the minister why he does not answer the question that was directed to him about the Prime Minister?
—There is no point of order.

—There was Lois O'Donoghue, Sir Arvi Parbo, Archbishop George Pell—are you going to attack them as well, Senator? This is what I can tell you about Julie Bishop: West Australian, Managing Partner of Clayton Utz, Perth; Chairwoman, WA Town Planning Appeal Tribunal.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am interested in the fact that the minister went through part of the biography of Ms Bishop. Why did the Prime Minister, when releasing the biography of Ms Bishop—or you, Minister, when you referred to it now—not reveal the close links that Ms Bishop has to the Liberal Party in Western Australia? Isn't it true that this is just another example of the emerging pattern in which the government has concealed the Liberal Party connections of a substantial number of the appointed delegates to the convention?

—I note that Archbishop Peter Hollingworth is described as Archbishop of Brisbane. There is nothing about his political allegiances—surprise, surprise! I have given you all the information I have on Julie Bishop. I have no idea how she votes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —At page 5683 of Hansard , the Assistant Treasurer gave me a response from the Treasurer to a question by me. I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . concerning those families affected by recent changes to the youth allowance that may have to allocate an increased share of their taxable income to supporting their children.

. . . the Government will not make tax exempt what is taxable income. The Government does not have a policy of introducing concessional tax treatment to the taxable income of those who may lose entitlements for direct outlay benefits.

Would the minister advise the Senate whether such policy of not compensating for legislative changes will apply to the GST, if it is introduced, thus ruling out any proper compensating reduction in the income tax payable by families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that you have at last joined the tax reform debate, Senator. I am certainly pleased—I think it was your first flurry into the tax reform debate—
—Don't you remember 1990‐91?

—Don't I remember 1990-91? I will have to go back and glance at my files. I think it would probably help if I made some points clear to you, Senator. We are essentially a party that believes that there does need to be major reform of the tax system. We are not sure where the Labor Party stands on that. I am looking closely at Senator Sherry to see if I can get the slightest hint of whether he supports tax reform or not. Senator Sherry's head remains dead still. Senator Sherry, could you just nod: do you support major tax reform in this country? I think he nodded; I am not altogether clear.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it clear that the debate is about a number of things. It is about less personal tax. Obviously, as in the six principles that were outlined by the Prime Minister, we will look at a number of issues, including the issue of a broad based indirect tax to replace some or all of existing indirect taxes.
In answer to your specific question, let me refer you to principle (d), as outlined by the Prime Minister. I think this will give you great comfort. It says:
there should be appropriate compensation for those deserving of special consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, wow!

—We have just heard the voice from the back bench. Senator Collins, on behalf of this party, I express our thanks for all your help in the Northern Territory. Thank you, Bob. Can we get a commitment that, with the next election in the Northern Territory, you will go back and run that campaign too? Thanks for your help.

ANSWER.PARA: I come back to your question, Senator Harradine. I am sorry that I was diverted by Senator Bob Collins. In the principles outlined by the Prime Minister there is the principle of compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. As to my entry into this debate, I refer the minister to the dozens and dozens of questions on notice that I have asked of the Treasurer. Is what you are saying now in conflict with what you said on that date that I quoted—that is, that the government will not make tax exempt what is taxable income? Why is increasing the tax threshold to take account of dependent family members treated as making tax exempt what is taxable income? Your response to me, if I may so, is in conflict with the statement by the Prime Minister.
—It is not in conflict with the statement by the Prime Minister; it is actually the statement made by the Prime Minister. He said:

BREAK.PARA: consideration should be given to a broad based, indirect tax to replace some or all of the existing indirect taxes;
there should be appropriate compensation for those deserving of special consideration.

I think you were worried about whether compensation would be considered. I think that I have given you those assurances that you were seeking. I will look at the other aspects that you have raised and see whether there is anything further that I am able to say on that matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Agency Agreement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, will you table the proposed new agency agreement between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and its senior officers? Does that agreement allow senior officers to repackage up to 50 per cent of their salaries, thereby avoiding income tax, the new 15 per cent superannuation tax and the Medicare levy surcharge? Is it a fact that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has been informed by the Australian Taxation Office that such repackaging is acceptable? How does this approach sit with the Treasurer's statement of yesterday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The government takes such measures as are required to prevent legitimate taxation liabilities being avoided.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to get a detailed answer for the senator from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I understand that this is the second government department, on top of Prime Minister and Cabinet, which has been issuing these new guidelines with respect to salary repackaging to dodge, in some cases, taxes you have introduced. Don't you see it as absurd and a total contradiction of the Treasurer's statement yesterday and, indeed, of the crackdown by the tax office on these sorts of procedures?
—I would dispute whether that is a supplementary question, but the answer is surely no.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Senator Alston. Will the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the Australian National sale process? How will the sale revitalise the Australian rail industry and ensure long-term jobs, especially in regional Australia, and end the massive subsidy which Labor poured in to an inefficient rail business which had no hope of breaking even? What has been the response from interested parties regarding the announcement of the sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important and historic event that we celebrate with the successful sale of AN, as announced by the minister last week. As Senator Calvert has suggested, it will completely revitalise the rail industry and provide for long-term jobs across Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three components. The Great Southern Railway Consortium, which purchased AN's passenger business, has given a commitment to no ongoing taxpayer subsidies, as have the other two consortia. It has also given a commitment that existing passenger services will not only be maintained but refurbished, upgraded and expanded. There is a $14.3 million capital investment program over six years, which of course means more jobs for South Australia.

The Genesee and Wyoming Consortium, which bought the South Australian freight and the Australian Transport Network, which purchased Tasrail, similarly have given commitments to upgrading and maintaining levels of employment. A total of $62 million in capital investment for freight in South Australia over a five-year period will clearly again mean more jobs for that state.

It is quite clear that the sale price of $95 million, with the consortia contracted to a further high level of capital expenditure over the next four to six years, is a breathtakingly good result for South Australia and Tasmania, and for the rest of Australia. This is against the background of that lot opposing tooth and nail this whole proposal, despite the fact that you had the workers, you had the unions, you had the people of South Australia and you had the media in that state, and I am sure in Tasmania, together with all of the parliamentary leaders of that state, making it abundantly clear that this is what they wanted. But, no, all we got was this churlish negativism which characterises Labor's approach to almost every issue—in other words, utterly opportunistic, trying to find fault, carping with every proposal that is put up.

The height of hypocrisy of course was that Lindsay Tanner came out and said, `Ninety-five million dollars is not enough. We could have got more.' They did not suggest we could have got two bob for it when we were proposing to sell it in the first instance. All they were doing was opposing it. It is a great result.

It is fascinating to find that Senator Woodley seems to have come on board the train at the last minute, because I know he had some great wobbles in the course of the committee hearings and clearly was expressing very serious concerns about the whole concept. But ultimately, of course, he came on board and he told ABC radio, `I've got to say I'm really pleased; I mean, I'm really thrilled about it actually.' All I can say is that, with his newfound conversion to privatisation, it is a pity that he was not the Democrats' spokesman for telecommunications. We could have saved ourselves a lot of trouble. We could have had you on that committee inquiry. You had an open mind, which clearly others did not have, and we might have got there a lot quicker than we did. But, nonetheless, despite the Democrats' and Labor's best endeavours, we got there on that one and we got there on this one, and we are delighted to have that endorsement.

Perhaps the best endorsement of all is from Rex Phillips, the Public Transport Union state secretary in South Australia. He said, `Trade union officials don't usually praise Liberal politicians. I might even vote Liberal at the next election.' I hasten to add that, with Senator Schacht on the Senate ticket, he probably does not have much choice. But, nonetheless, it gives you a pretty good indication of how out of touch this lot really are and what a great result this has been for South Australia, Tasmania and the rest of the country—indeed, for everyone except the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Newman in her capacity as adviser to the Prime Minister on the status of women. Minister, were you consulted on the question of why the Prime Minister's women in sport awards were not held last year? Did you agree with them not being held? Will they be held this year? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —We should first of all set the record straight: I am not the Prime Minister's adviser on the status of women. I am the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In our government the Prime Minister takes an active role as the minister responsible for the status of women. He is very interested in the issues and he has met with women on a level which was never seen from the previous government. We have 58 per cent, nearly 60 per cent, of the women in this parliament on our side of politics and the Prime Minister listens to women in his party, as he listens to the women in the country. Only last week, with a two-day round table—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—Try to have a shot at answering the question.
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—For two days last week the Prime Minister met with delegations of women from around Australia. First of all the Australian Council of Business Women, who had a very good meeting with the Prime Minister and—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Could I ask you, Madam President, whether you consider Senator Newman is even attempting to answer the question that was directed to her by Senator Crowley? It was a specific question in relation to the Prime Minister's women in sport awards. It was a question about whether she was consulted, about whether she agreed to them not being held and about whether they would be held this year and it asked Senator Newman for an explanation. Could you direct her on this occasion, Madam President, to answer the clear question she was asked by Senator Crowley?
—This is the mob who wanted to take Sam Riley's award away from her.
—Senator Newman currently is dealing first with that aspect of the question which dealt with her status in this role. She has yet to come to the more precise details. I am sure that she will.

—The interjections we are getting from the other side are from a party that were prepared to try to take Sam Riley's award away from her—so much for their concern about women in sport. Let it be very clear that the Prime Minister has been meeting with women of all political colours and with a variety of special interests. Last week, on the second day of that round table, he met a delegation of 10 people, who represented 47 national women's organisations, who came to Canberra to consult with the government—not just the Prime Minister, not just me, but Minister Reith and Minister Kemp.

ANSWER.PARA: Although the Australian Labor Party might not like this, the record is that women's organisations are saying that issues are on the agenda and are being addressed by this government, and that they are getting a good hearing. Those opposite do not like to hear that. Only today my colleague Senator Alston announced the appointment of Mrs Linda Nicholls as chairman of the Australia Post board, a senior position by any government standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. You might recall, Madam President, that I mentioned in my previous point of order that Senator Crowley had asked Senator Newman a very specific question about the women in sport awards. It may be very interesting for Senator Newman to canvass what is happening in Australia Post and a range of other issues, but don't you believe, Madam President, that at this stage of her answer, having been on her feet now for over two minutes, it is reasonable for you, presiding in this chamber, to direct the minister just to have a crack at answering the question that Senator Crowley asked?

—I would not dream of suggesting that the minister should have a crack at answering the question; I would expect her, in accordance with the standing orders, to answer the question as it has been put to her. A crack at it would not seem seemly.

—This government takes women's issues much more seriously than that. That is why this government has made a number of senior appointments of women who have great ability and who have got there on their merits. I point out that a woman heads up the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency—my appointment—which has a budget of something like $40 billion and over 20,000 employees. I have a huge list of women who have been appointed to positions on their merit by this government. When we came into government the percentage of women who were on Commonwealth boards and committees was 30.5. I guess the Labor Party will be sad to know that as at 30 June this year the proportion of women on Commonwealth boards and committees appointed by this government was 31.6 per cent. It has gone up. We intend for it to go higher again.

—I take a point of order, Madam President. I ask again that you direct Senator Newman to answer the question that was asked of her. It was a specific question. It was a clear question. Senator Newman has rabbited on now for three minutes. She has not attempted to answer the question, as I believe you well know, Madam President. I ask you to direct her to answer the question.
—I draw your attention to the question, Senator, and ask you to continue.

—I am addressing the question, the subliminal part of the question, which implied that somehow this government was not interested in women. Having appointed Helen Williams as Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Af fairs, Moira Scollay to be the Privacy Commissioner, Anthea Tinney to be head of the Environment Protection Group—
—I take a point of order, Madam President. Could I ask you to direct the minister to answer the non-subliminal part of the question? Let's have a go at that.

—The minister has leeway to answer the question as she has interpreted it. She is answering that aspect. I agree that she is not dealing specifically with the point raised. If Senator Crowley is not happy she can raise it in a supplementary question.

—Former Senator Margaret Guilfoyle headed up a review into the Social Security Review and Appeals Tribunal. Professor Judith Whitworth has been appointed Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer. Penny Wensley has been appointed as Ambassador to the United Nations. Elizabeth Alexander is a commissioner of the National Commission of Audit. Elizabeth Evatt has been appointed to the UN Human Rights Committee. Sirena Bratton has been appointed as Director of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.
—Order! Senator, your time for answering the question has terminated.
—Oh, what a pity, Madam President. I have a lot more yet.

—I will have another shot at a concrete answer to a subliminal interpretation. I am interested to note, Minister, that you seem to be able to tell us what is going on in Senator Alston's portfolio, but not what is going on in your own area of responsibilities. Would you also like to know that in regard to those commissions that you boast about, such as the Australian Council of Businesswomen, I was there when they made their recommendations. They asked for a register of women, and strength for the Affirmative Action Agency, both of which you have just cancelled. Will you answer that question too? Would you also like to have another shot at this question: were you consulted at all about the Prime Minister's women in sport awards and, if not, why not? If you are so hot to trot on other appointments, why not on the women in sport awards? Have you had the courtesy of being consulted over the government's response to the report, An illusory image , on the media coverage and the portrayal of women in sport in Australia 1996? Finally, Minister, as you are boasting a list of appointments, can you say why you have not replaced the women's sports adviser? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very persistent, I know, but I have not finished my list yet, Madam President. We appointed Susan Milliken as Chair of the Australian Film Commission, Fay McGuigan and another woman to the Supermarket to Asia Council, Merran Kelsall as Director of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, Helen L'Orange as the Chief Executive Officer of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, and Clair Gross to the Small Business Deregulation Task Force.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said all that, can I ask whether Paul Keating when Prime Minister ever spent an hour meeting with the women of Australia, the national women's organisations? No, he did not. Carmen Lawrence as minister did not stay for their meetings. She would turn up perhaps for the introduction and then she left. She did not chair the meeting. She did not stay for two days. So you have no right to criticise us at all. I am invited to comment on a lot things across portfolios—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, in response to your claim that universities have overenrolled, the Vice‐Chancellor of Monash University has said: `That may be, but not at my university'. In fact, the vice‐chancellor at the university has withdrawn 720 publicly funded places and will lose 1,100 places to federal funding cuts. Many of these places are being offset by up-front fee paying students. The dean has said: `We'd be crazy not to replace government places with full fee places.' Does the minister agree that universities faced with these cuts to operating grants would be crazy not to replace HECS places with full fee paying places?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for yet again giving me the opportunity to make the government's position clear on a number of matters, not the least of which is the introduction of the option for universities to charge full up-front fees next year. Senator, you were for a limited period of time at the estimates committee hearings and I am sure you have had the opportunity to go through the Hansard s subsequent to that. You will understand that, because there is the slightest suggestion from Monash that they could in one way or another rejig their figures to maximise their opportunities for fee paying students over and above the limitations that parliament agreed to, we would be amending the regulations that were to cover that area to make it absolutely certain they would not be able to do that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you did not like the decision, but this parliament decided that universities would have the option, once they had filled their government funded places, of selling additional places, with two requirements on that. Firstly, they could not exceed 25 per cent and, secondly, they must have filled the government funded places in each course before they could sell places. If you have further statements made by Monash subsequent to those that were raised in the Hansard, I would be very happy to have a look at them. I am absolutely predetermined on a course to ensure that universities in no way subvert the government's intention in this respect.

I believe that the changes that we have made will in fact do that: they will ensure that universities follow the government's intention. But, if you have some views subsequent to my having made that clear, I will have another look. I do not accept for one minute, Senator, that I think anything further needs to be done but, if you think something further needs to be done, then by all means come around and make it clear what you think ought to be done, because we are determined to ensure that the government's and parliament's intention is not subverted in any way.

Let me turn to the question of cuts. You, Senator, are among the people who have tried to convince existing and potential students that universities have suffered real cuts. I do not think you were at the estimates hearing, Senator, when we demonstrated by way of graph the changes. Senator, I notice you are ducking your head. You are slightly embarrassed that some people on the estimates committee were so stupid that words would not do—we had to show them a picture. And we showed them a picture. What did the picture show, Senator? It showed what these people opposite, the guilty party, did to funding per student when they got into government in 1983.

Funding per student is one of the indicators of quality. That is what gives a university the capacity to employ staff and buy equipment and all the sorts of gear that are required. And what did they do to funding per student? They cut it from $12,000 and shoved it down to under $11,000 and then slowly brought it back up again.

What have the changes we have made done to funding per student? They have kept it at or above 1996 levels. Funding per student in the next four years under the coalition government is higher than in any of the previous four years under the guilty party's government. So do not come in here to try to misrepresent what we have done with universities. Universities have more money this year than they had last year—and you know that. They had their plans for future money cut—not their actual money this year. They have more money this year than they had last year and you would do well to build your reputation by starting to tell the whole truth and nothing but the truth about these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I am aware that these facts are on the public record so I draw your attention to the comments from both the Dean of Law and the Vice‐Chancellor of Monash University. Minister, are you really saying that you do not believe that universities are substituting HECS funded places for up‐front full fee paying places? Do you accept that Monash is not alone? In fact, Adelaide University plans to substitute up‐front fee paying places where HECS places are due to be cut. Coinciden tally, similar numbers are going to be replaced—up‐front full cost fees instead of government funded HECS places.

—Senator Stott Despoja, I have not had a discussion with the Vice‐Chancellor of Monash. I have indicated to you that, if there is any material subsequent to that which was raised at the estimates, I am happy to look at it. I do not believe any further changes need to be made. With respect to Adelaide University, I cannot conclude completely from your comments, but I am tempted to conclude, that you simply do not understand what they are trying to do. Mary O'Kane is an excellent vice‐chancellor. I am sure she will give you the time, if you want it, to walk you through it so that you do not have the embarrassment of having to come and ask me what your university is doing. You ought to know. I think I do. If you do not want to ask me, go and ask Mary O'Kane. I am sure she will tell you.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Allison asked me a question about an Australian Customs Service IT outsourcing matter. I have received the following information from the Australian Customs Service, which I seek leave to incorporate in the Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The information read as follows—

On Monday this week Senator Allison asked Senator Alston whether he was aware that a clause in the IT outsourcing specification for the Australian Custodies Service insisted that PC suppliers could only be used if they currently shipped 250,000 Pcs per year. Senator Allison asked Senator Alston if he was aware that Australia's largest PC supplier shipped less than a third of that number and would, like all other Australian suppliers, be excluded from tendering.

In response Senator Alston told Senator Allison that the Customs Request for Tender did not preclude small suppliers from bidding for the provision of Pcs. However, Senator Alston emphasised that the Government would require acceptable standards to be maintained during the life of any contract.

In a subsequent question yesterday, Senator Allison said that the provision to allow smaller suppliers to offer Pcs `as specifically not available to Ipex, our largest PC supplier'. She said that while a contract manager could be appointed to vary the requirement for 250,000 Pcs per annum, in this case no such arrangement had been made.
She went on to say that `multi-national outsourcing vendors have already been told by the Customs Service that their bids would not be accepted using Australian suppliers'.
That latter assertion is not correct.

The Australian Customs Service is currently evaluating tenders from three potential prime contractors and all three contractors have confirmed in writing today that they have received no such instruction from the Customs Service.

In relation to the rest of Senator Allison's question, she either misunderstands the Customs Information Technology Outsourcing contract, or has misread a letter from the Customs Project Manager to Ipex.

PC suppliers, including Ipex, were not invited, nor were they eligible, to bid to be prime contractors for the Customs IT outsourcing. Only those vendors on the PE68 Common User Contract who had the capacity to manage the full range of Customs IT were invited to bid for the total project on a prime contract basis.
Equipment suppliers (including PC suppliers), software suppliers and other service provides will be involved in the project as sub-contractors to the prime contractor.

Customs tender (RFT) and the published evaluation criteria emphasised the importance of involving Australian industry and small to medium enterprises. All three vendors under consideration have involved Australian companies either as subcontractors or as partners or have tendered Australian made equipment.
The Customs outsourcing tender has not yet been decided nor any contract let. No decision has been taken on the supply of a specific PC under the outsourcing contract.

The contract, when awarded will not specify a particular brand of PC, rather it will specify criteria consistent with the RFT. The prime contractor win be free at any time during the contract to supply equipment meeting Tier 1 or Tier 2 criteria or to offer any other equipment, including Ipex, for Customs approval.
The Project Manager for the Customs tender wrote to Ipex on 30 July stating, inter alia, that:
`in the interest of accuracy, I need to remind you that I did not confirm the acceptability (or otherwise) of your equipment for the ACS'.

Mr Box was simply making it clear to IPEX that he had not approved them as a supplier at this stage—indeed it would be premature to do so before the RFT was evaluated and a prime contractor selected. It would be up to the prime contractor to submit IPEX to Customs for approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) to questions without notice asked by Senator Bolkus, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) and Senator McKiernan today, relating to appointments to the Constitutional Convention.

At a time when bipartisanship was necessary, at a time when a sense of inclusiveness was necessary, what have we got from the Liberal Party, from the government, in the appointments of delegates to the constitutional convention? We have got a self‐indulgent exercise in stacking. Undergraduate Liberal faction fighting is what we got instead of statesmanship. I never thought you could be so blatant, Senator Minchin, and I just cannot understand how you thought you would ever get away with this. You have stacked the appointments, you have frustrated the will of the electorate, you have deceived young people, you have ignored migrants, you have done over progressive Liberals and you have ignored prominent worthy Australians. You have appointed your own. But not from all of you—more particularly you have appointed a preponderance of people from the ruling faction of your coalition, from the dries.

No‐one says there are no republicans appointed; no‐one says there should be no Liberals; no‐one says there should be no Young Liberals. What we do say is that in your appointments you have not reflected the will of the Australian public. Of those who have made up their minds on the republic, some 62 per cent support Australia becoming a republic. You say that you have appointed one‐third republicans, one‐third monarchists and one‐third don't knows. But scratch beneath the surface of the don't knows and what do you find out? You find out a very shabby, shallow attempt to conceal the real attitudes of those who are presented as don't knows.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Minchin, this is a case of the Prime Minister not just appointing some of his own. It is not a case of Caligula appointing one horse; it is a case of Caligula appointing a whole stable. And the whole stable comes from your side of the Liberal Party.

The process was flawed from the start. We made that point here. We wanted a joint parliamentary committee to vet the process. Senator Minchin himself acknowledged that there would be no public servants involved in it. He would not give us any indication of the process. The appointments would be made by politicians and by political staffers: all the Prime Minister's men sitting in the bunker of the Prime Minister's office, paranoid as they are.

Nowhere is this stacking more obvious than when we come to youth delegates. Already we have seen that three at least of the youth delegates appointed come not from the Young Liberals but from a conservative part of the Liberal organisation, Liberal Students. So the progressive Liberals, the rank and file in many parts of Australia, have been ignored. They have been ignored and passed over for what? They have been ignored and passed over for a condemned rorter in Queensland, a delegate in the ACT who presents herself as a sex machine, and what have we got? The progressive Liberals involved in the debate have been ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, I think the reflection that is made on a person the way Senator Bolkus did then is out of order.
—I withdraw that but I will table the document.
—Is leave granted to table the document?
—No.

—All right, I will not table the document. So what have we got? We have got members of the Liberal Students organisation. And, just by coincidence, who is their patron? No other than Senator Minchin. BREAK.PARA: Not only have the young people of Australia been deceived in what they want to see Australia's future as being. At a time when we needed statesmanship we did not get it. The general public has also been deceived. They were promised by this Prime Minister a heavy dose of democracy. As I say, some 62 per cent of those who have made up their minds on the republic support Australia becoming a republic. But what do they get instead: maybe a third of those appointed by the government support the republican position. As you say, Senator Minchin, one‐third may not, but, as you scratch the surface in respect of that one‐third of don't knows, we find that they are more and apparent as monarchists.

Youth have been deceived. Migrants have been deceived. Migrants wanted representation. What did they get? They got Professor Blainey. So many prominent and worthy people across Australia have missed out. Where are the likes of the people who have been involved in the debate so far: the Paul Kellys the Professor McIntyres, the Constitutional Centenary Foundation? Where are ex‐Prime Ministers like Fraser and Whitlam, the ex‐Premiers like Greiner and Wran—all passed over, and passed over for what? For friends of the Liberal Party. Ms Bishop from Western Australia. Prefer her over constitutional lawyers like Carsten and Charles and others, and ex‐Governors‐General like Sir Ninian Stephen and Anthony Mason. Why weren't people like that chosen, legally eminent people? Why were they passed over for unknowns from the legal profession in WA? TALK.START.PARA: —Today in question time and now from Senator Bolkus we really have seen the most extraordinary display of sour grapes by the Labor Party. Senator McKiernan from Western Australia, and Senator Ray, made the mistake of referring to a Western Australian appointee—a female who happens to be the managing partner of Clayton Utz or `Uts', depending on where you come from. Senator Ray asked us why, out of the 20,000 legal firms in Australia, we chose this particular firm. They have not even read the whole list.

One of the appointees is Mary Imlach from Tasmania, a partner in the firm of Jennings, Elliott. Senator O'Brien, as a former President of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, would be well aware that that firm does a lot of trade union work in the workers compensation area. But you swept that under the carpet—you do not want to mention that. But having said that to the Senate, let me say that Mary Imlach is a woman of integrity, as is that law firm, and I do not begrudge the fact that Senator Minchin submitted her name, being associated with that legal firm that is involved in looking after a lot of trade unions. Mary Imlach will do Tasmania and Australia proud at the Constitutional Convention, as I am sure Julie Bishop will as well.

Where the senators opposite have descended into this guttersniping of the personalities, they could not even read the list properly. They said there was not enough information about the people's backgrounds. They clearly did not read the background of Mary Imlach, otherwise they would not have made the mistake of saying that, out of the 20,000 legal firms in this country, only one was chosen. In fact two were chosen: the firm of Jennings, Elliott in Tasmania.

BREAK.PARA: We really have exposed the Labor Party yet again. They cannot get their facts right. Next to the name of the Hon. Mr Bill Hayden, AC, we were not told that he was a member of the Labor Party. Why were we not told in the biographical notes? If you were so concerned that people's political affiliations were put down, you should have been concerned about why that was not written next to the Hon. Bill Hayden's name. The fact is that we have treated everybody equally.

I do not know where this campaign is coming from, quite frankly. Laurie Oakes, in his article in this week's Bulletin, talks about a Mr Parker, who is the Canberra lobbyist for the republican movement, who says that it is basically a very fair selection of people. So the republican movement seems to be very happy. Overall, they say, the breakdown of the appointed delegates to the convention `clearly gives the Australian republican movement a very comfortable base.'

It is quite obvious that the republican movement are happy with the appointments. No journalist in this country has asserted that there has been a stacking of this convention. No editorial has suggested that. But the ALP, which cannot keep its eye on the main game, come in here trying to attack individuals that have been appointed on a fair and bipartisan basis.
Time is short, but let me say that Ben Myers from Queensland is a good and honourable citizen of this country and he will do Australia proud. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Alston.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In claiming to have been misrepresented I would point out that half a quote is half a truth, and half a truth is a lie.
—And half a minister is what you have in Senator Alston.

—Exactly. Senator Alston said that I had stated on Adelaide radio that I was pleased with the government's decision. That is half—in fact it is less than half—of what I really said. I said that I was pleased that the government had read the Senate inquiry report, had taken notice of the recommendations of the Senate inquiry report and had written the concerns that we raised into the sale agreements. However, I also questioned why the government had not taken the parliament into its confidence but rather had bypassed the democratic process in the whole issue.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have from Senator Alston is really less than half a quote. Not only did I say I was pleased the government had read the Senate inquiry report, I also said that this government should be aware that previous agreements between governments and private enterprise had fallen over. I quoted the DuPont example where $60 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party!

—I am not saying which party—of taxpayers' funds had been lost. I do not have the full transcript but if the minister supplies me with the full transcript I am prepared and happy to make further comment. There is no doubt that the minister quite deliberately misrepresented what I said and gave the opposite impression to the Senate about the issues that I had raised in that particular interview.

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order, Senator Woodley has imputed a motive on Senator Alston's part on two occasions during this personal explanation. Senator Woodley concluded by saying that Senator Alston deliberately misrepresented the situation and so, knowingly, misrepresented a situation in this parliament and that, I submit to you, is unparliamentary. Further, earlier on in his commentary, he made a comment to the effect that what Senator Alston said was only half a statement which was therefore half the truth which was a lie, and that should also have been withdrawn. I thought I would let the first one go through to the keeper but as he said it twice in the one personal explanation it is appropriate that he be asked to withdraw on both counts.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would have to support Senator Abetz in what he describes as a submission to you in a point of order. I too have listened very carefully to what Senator Woodley has said. He indicated that Senator Alston has only told half the truth. I think Senator Abetz has a strong case because half the truth is normally a hell of a lot better than what we get from Senator Alston.
—There is no point of order, Senator Faulkner. Senator Woodley, if you were imputing motives to the minister I would like you to withdraw.
—I am not prepared to withdraw.
—You are withdrawing the implication that the minister lied, I take it, though? Are you prepared to do that?
—Yes, I certainly withdraw that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Madam Deputy President, to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to my question to the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) today, the Assistant Treasurer clearly said that I and the Australian Democrats had not supported fiscal consolidation and fiscal restructuring in the Australian government's budget. That is a misrepresentation of our position during the Labor government's regime—and that is clearly recorded in Hansard —and of our support for about $6 billion worth of adjustments in the 1996 budget. Accordingly, I note the Assistant Treasurer's deliberate misrepresentation of our position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a brief statement in relation to the matter I raised with Senator Vanstone after question time today. After question time I raised the issue that, during the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee's consideration of estimates on 19 August of this year, Senator Vanstone had given a commitment to Senator O'Brien in relation to the South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd issue—which has been a matter of some interest and a series of questions at both the Senate legislation committee and two question times in the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone gave a commitment to Senator O'Brien on 19 August that she would provide the senator with more considered views within a couple of weeks, with a range of answers to questions that had, effectively, been placed on notice. Without wanting to place words in the minister's mouth, the spirit of what Senator Vanstone offered was a report to the Senate on this issue. I could have raised this matter yesterday because it did occur on Tuesday, 19 August, but I thought it was appropriate to raise it today, to allow the minister to provide information to the Senate on this issue.

I do point out that this is a matter of some significance. It involves some $2.8 million of public money. There has already been a payment of some $2.2 million to a company. That has been confirmed by both the minister and officers of her department. There is a range of outstanding issues which I do not want to labour during this very brief contribution, but I think it is appropriate that the minister provide that information to the Senate now, because it is an issue of great concern to the opposition and to opposition senators and it is an issue which has had quite a significant airing in other jurisdictions—in other parliaments—and has also been the subject of commentary in the media. I believe it is appropriate that the minister now have an opportunity to respond in full to those concerns, because of their significance both to the parliament and in the public mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—To put this matter in context, I think it is appropriate to read into Hansard the exchange we had at the estimates committee hearing. Before doing that, I will indicate a number of things.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I first heard of potential problems with the South Pacific Cruise Line contract and the department's activities in that respect, it has always been my view that the amount of money involved was substantial, that it did need to be watched carefully, that it was unusual, to say the very least, and that it would require both the fullest reporting and the most appropriate reporting, not necessarily to the estimates committee itself but to parliament—maybe through the estimates committee or otherwise.
Senator O'Brien did ask a number of questions about that. On Tuesday he put this question:

Given what has come before the committee today in relation to the South Pacific Cruise Lines contract, has the minister a view as to the appropriateness of the actions of the department in relation to entering into the contract with South Pacific Cruise Lines?
That was the question I was asked: what was my view about the department entering into a contract with South Pacific Cruise Lines? My response was this:

Senator, I have some concerns about the contract as it stands, but I think I need some more advice before I can make a conclusion as to the appropriateness or otherwise of how we ended up being in that position. It is a matter of concern—but just give me one second, if you would not mind.

And, if Hansard was a video, that would show me turning to a deputy secretary and consulting him about how long it might take to get to the bottom of this. I then came back and continued with the answer:
Senator, within a couple of weeks I could provide you with more considered views.

I could go on, but I could, equally, put a full stop there and make the point that what I said was, `I could come back within a couple of weeks and give you more considered views.' We can argue about the strength of that as an undertaking, but it was certainly my view at the time that I would be able—

TALK.START.PARA: —And further on?
—Senator, I am coming to that. If you want to draw me to some further points, I am happy to go to those.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CARR

TALK.START.PARA: —You said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I will get all that information and I will come back to you with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to continue, Madam Deputy President, but I am not happy to continue if I am continually interrupted. I ask for the protection of the chair in this matter. Senator Faulkner has raised a serious matter. He, presumably, is interested in it. There are other opportunities for other senators to contribute if they want. Nonetheless, I went on and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just to give you an indication of the information that I want—
not that which I am being pressed for by the estimates committee but what I want to get on this matter—

I have been advised that up until very near to the signing of the contract, the department was negotiating with and believed it was going to make a contract with William Angliss. Presumably, you would not find that so exceptional because that would be a contract with the training agency to provide certain training.
It was very near to the signing of that, I am advised, that William Angliss proposed the substitution of the other party—
that is, for your benefit, Madam Deputy President, South Pacific Cruise Lines—

to be the party with whom we contracted. There is no doubt we agreed to do that, but it was not a case of someone coming in off the street. Sometimes one might gather that by the references to a former bankrupt being a director. It was not the case that someone came in off the street and said, `I've got a good idea,' and the department just loosely entered into a very expensive contract. But I do need to get the dates and a better outline of it before I can make any further remarks—
which is in itself a qualification—
It is not an ideal situation—
and I do not resile from that at all; it is not—
but it may, in fact, work—
I am still in a position to express that view—
I do not want to prejudge it in any way whatsoever. But it is a situation which causes concern.

Senator O'Brien then says that it may work and he outlines some of his concerns which relate to the cost of training. He rightly identified that this does seem to be an unusually high cost per person of training. I do not think I need to go into the particular words there except to interpose where he says:

I hear what you say and I look forward to the detail about entering into this contract if, indeed, the negotiations have gone right up to the point of signing and then the names have basically changed as to who the—
and then I say:
The parties have changed, yes. I will get all that information and I will come back to you with it.

I stand by that. I will, but I do not want to come back without having the full information on this. I have some but not enough. I am not yet satisfied that I can adequately and properly report to Senator O'Brien, the Senate or the estimates committee.

If it is of any satisfaction, which I doubt that it is—not to me but to other senators—I had a discussion with the secretary to my department on Thursday last week and indicated my dissatisfaction with the flow of information to me about this matter and that it should be perfectly clear from this Hansard that I had a very strong interest in it and that I wanted to get to the bottom of it. My office was subsequently given a number of cut‐off points for when the matter would be reported on to me, which were not all met but nonetheless I have received a preliminary report indicating that there are more matters that need to be resolved.

I have subsequently written to the secretary and indicated that I want a date by which the secretary can say these matters are resolved as far as the department can do that, and give me that information, and I will then conclude whether that is the end of the matter or not. Senator Faulkner, Senator O'Brien, Senator Evans—he had some interest in this; I am not sure whether he asked me questions about this matter, but he was certainly there when it was raised—and others can be absolutely confi dent that when I have all the information they will have every piece of it they need to make a proper assessment of what happened—absolutely.

In addition to making that absolute commitment, I just point out that it is not as simple as Senator Faulkner indicates. I did say I could come back—I point out that I did not say that I would, but my clear intention was that I would—but indicated subsequent to that that I needed to get further information before I could.

Let me add, though, that I am advised that the training in relation to hospitality has been completed. I understand William Angliss believes that all of the trainees who completed their training—there were a few dropouts—are now in a position to compete for jobs in the tourism industry around the Gold Coast et cetera and that there is now land based training in relation to safety. The matter of sea based training I think is a matter that I cannot usefully comment on without having more information in front of me.

I cannot usefully comment on the cost per person of the training at the moment other than to say that I can agree with Senator O'Brien. The cost seems to me to be exceptionally high, but I say that almost intuitively in that I cannot tell you I have got out every training contract, had a look and satisfied myself that there are not any others as high. But it does seem a very large amount of money on a per week basis.

I think my concerns are basically the same as Senator O'Brien's. I indicated to him I wanted a chronology of how this happened, of how we suddenly ended up negotiating a contract with one party and in fact signing with another—another that you could not, as I understand it, argue had a long and reliable background but was seeking to go into a new and exciting venture in tourism. I think everyone is entitled to at least a chronology of how we ended up in that position and certainly an explanation vis-a-vis the cost. They are Senator O'Brien's interests, as outlined to me.

I have subsequent interests, and I would imagine Senator O'Brien and any member of the estimates committee would have them, and they relate to accountability for how it happened and how quickly or slowly information comes forward from people involved not only to me but even to the head of my department and to the departmental secretaries. I am interested in how easy it is for them to get the relevant information.

I suspect this matter may be an interesting case study in a number of respects, but I can only repeat for you, Senator Faulkner: as soon as I have information that I think I can rely on and I am able to say to you that it is all the information you need to make a judgment, I will most certainly bring it forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The reason I sought leave to make a statement on this matter is to hopefully obviate the need for us to have a suspension of standing orders and deal with this in a more adversarial way. I am hopeful that we can sort this out.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of issues that arise from the contribution that Senator Vanstone has just made. Senator Vanstone would recall that in the Senate chamber in question time on Wednesday last week Senator O'Brien asked her a question in relation to that further expenditure of moneys to this particular company in relation to this training.

What I do think would have been appropriate, Minister, in these circumstances is for the Senate to have been provided before today, but certainly by today, with an answer to that question. I do not believe that that is a matter that would require an enormous amount of effort on the part of your department and, given the sensitivity and the significance of the question that Senator O'Brien has asked of you, I believe the Senate is entitled to a quick response.

I put it to you on that particular point that you might consider providing the information in relation to that aspect of Senator O'Brien's questioning which you took on notice on 27 August. You indicated at that time that you would come back with a chronology of events; you acknowledged that in your earlier contribution. You then said:

BREAK.PARA: If there have been subsequent events to that that I do not now know about, I will certainly add that to the explanation I give you.

I appreciate that you made that point but I do think, in relation to this particular matter, that that is an essential piece of information going to the expenditure of public moneys and the Senate is entitled to an early response.

I also believe the Senate would need some understanding from the responsible minister as to when this information could be provided to either the Senate or to the relevant legislation committee dealing with estimates for the minister's department. The minister, in her earlier contribution, has not given any indication to the Senate of what time frame she has in mind and I think, in making an assessment of this as far as the opposition is concerned, it is reasonable for me to request the minister to make a clear and categorical statement in relation to that today.

When Senator Vanstone indicated that within a couple of weeks she could provide us with more considered views, the opposition took what she said at face value. It is possible, it does happen at times, that material is harder to bring together than one could imagine from the discomfort of the opposition benches. I also say very clearly that, regularly, much greater demands were put upon the then Labor administration in this chamber. I think there is a rather generous acceptance on the part of opposition senators in relation to the commitment and the time frame that was given here. I think Senator Vanstone would have to acknowledge that that has been the case. At a minimum, I think we need to understand today precisely what the minister has in mind.

The other issue I would canvass with the minister and ask for a response on—so we can perhaps save a little time at a later stage—is the issue of the possible reconvening of the Senate estimates committee on this issue. Senator Vanstone may indicate to us that this information will be able to be made available before the end of this sitting period; that is, some time within the next 28 hours. I do not know the answer to that question. I would like to hear from Senator Vanstone what the answer is.

If that is not the case, Senator Vanstone, then I would put to you very seriously that, at a mutually agreed time during the two‐week break between the next sittings of the parliament, at a minimum it would be appropriate, in my view, for an agreement that the Senate estimates committee reconvene and deal with this matter. If that does not happen it would be well over a month before the information would be made available to the Senate; and that simply is not acceptable. I hope, given the apparent seriousness of the issues that have been raised, the minister shares my concern in relation to accountability on this issue.

I put as clearly as I can, and with as much goodwill as I can muster, those three points to Senator Vanstone. Before we move to some sort of more adversarial approach on this matter in the chamber today, I ask the minister to respond to those specific matters that I have raised. Depending on the nature of those responses, we might be able to deal with this in a way that suits all interested parties in the chamber—both the opposition and the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I understand Senator Faulkner's concern with respect to this matter. I think he describes his contribution as being with as much good grace or goodwill as he can muster.
—Which is a pretty substantial amount of goodwill.

—I appreciate that, but I also understand that Senator Faulkner must be looking at the Hansard and wishing that the word `could' was `will' and wishing that the qualification following it was not there, and perhaps wishing that I did not have the same commitment as he appears to have with respect to resolving this matter. SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the three points you have raised, they relate to when there will be an answer to Senator O'Brien's further questions raised last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I actually said to you that I think an answer is required to that particular aspect of the question today. I think that ought to be made available today. It is just a short answer.
—The point I want to make is that it may not be a short answer. I perhaps have got to the point with this where I want to chase every rabbit down every burrow.
—Minister, please continue.

—I am happy to give the senator an answer, but he swings around on his chair and turns his back to me. I think he is slightly distracted and I should give him the courtesy of waiting until he is free.
—I would like you to address me.
—Not all of it may be available today, but I could easily give an undertaking to give such information as is available to me today. I do not think I can give you an unqualified answer today.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give you an example of the sort of thing I am concerned about. I have not yet got enough information before me with respect to the cost of training to absolutely satisfy myself, for example, that there are not some travel costs built into the cost of training. So when the senator asserts that we, the department, are flying people to wherever for sea‐based training, I think I can say, but I will check that as well, that my natural inclination on the basis of the information I have is that we, DEETYA, are not. But if I said that to you and you later found that it was built into the cost of training, you may feel entitled to come back and say that I did not give you a full answer.

I can give you such open, on the face of it, answers as are available, but until I have got to the very bottom of it all, I do not think I can give you an unqualified answer with respect to that. Certainly in relation to any further moneys being expended, I should easily be able to get that. That is not a problem.
In relation to the other material, I really do need to speak to the secretary to the department before I can give you an absolute commitment as to when I can get all of that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you would not be able to provide that information again today. Just the date when this will be completed, surely.

—I have indicated, through you, Madam Deputy President, that I have written to the secretary and I have asked for a date by which he will give me what he regards as a concluded matter. But I also indicated in my earlier contribution that that may not be the point at which I regard it as concluded. I simply cannot tell you that until I see the information.

SPEECH.PARA: But what might save some time, if Senator Faulkner is happy to agree, is that I will go away and speak to the secretary to the department and I will come back and negotiate with whomsoever is nominated on the other side as being the appropriate person to negotiate and give them whatever information is relevant in an unqualified way and such other information as is appropriate. I obviously do not want to give out information that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of negotiating; it is a matter of laying it down in the parliament, that is all. By all means, feel free to make informal contact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. On 19 June 1997 Senator O'Chee reported to the Senate on the committee's concerns with these instruments, which related to possibly unfair provisions, administrative decisions which may not be subject to external review of their merits, and inadequate notification of rights. The relevant ministers have now provided the committee with information which meets its concerns. The committee is grateful for this cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the committee's correspondence concerning these instruments.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: The Hon Peter Reith MP
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to Defence Determination 1997/16 which provides for the reimbursement of costs of advertising a home for sale.

The Explanatory Statement advises that these costs may be reimbursed, but that where more than one agent is engaged reimbursement is limited to the costs charged by the agent who actually sells the home. The Committee suggests, however, that there may be circumstances where this provision could operate unfairly if, for instance, an agent is engaged to sell a home and, for some reason, such as the death or bankruptcy of the agent or if the agent loses his or her licence, the member has to employ another agent to make the sale. The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether there is a discretion to waive the rule in appropriate circumstances and, if not, that the Determination will be amended to provide for this.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
25 July 1997
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer again to your letter of 7 May 1997 about Defence Determination 1997/16.

In my interim reply of 27 May, I indicated that the Department of Industrial Relations was consulting the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and other appropriate organisations to obtain background information relevant to your request for advice.

It transpires that no case of the kind you portray has ever arisen in the 17-year history of the Home Purchase and Sale Expenses Allowance (HPSEA) scheme. Moreover, the negligible risk could be minimised if members exercised reasonable care and responsibility in selling their home. Even if such circumstances did arise, it is likely that a member could reach a mutually acceptable outcome with the agent who effected the sale. The terms of contract between the member and an agent who was unable to effect a sale could also be relevant.

These points lead me to the view that there is no practical prospect of a member's rights being adversely affected by the Determination. I am therefore not persuaded that inclusion of a specific discretion to admit the cost of advertising a home with more than one agent could be justified in terms of the additional burden of complication (and thence inefficiency) for ADF personnel management.

In matters of this kind, attempts to cover the full range of eventualities (however remote) need to be moderated with regard to the wider benefits of keeping the rules simple and the indirect administrative costs within bounds. In the past, public sector personnel legislation has generally tended towards over-prescription, and this has directly contributed to under-achievement. In my preface to the discussion paper `Towards a best practice Australian Public Service', I identified "the complex array of outdated, rigid and cumbersome regulations" as a key performance inhibitor. I am reluctant to add to any such difficulties that the ADF may be facing.

Nevertheless, the principal determination on HPSEA does contain a general discretion authorising the Chief of the Defence Force to approve payment of the allowance in circumstances not otherwise provided for. I attach a copy of this provision for your Committee's information. The power has existed for some years and because of its prescriptive wording, it is not entirely clear that it would be flexible enough to meet the contingencies you envisage.

In order to put this beyond doubt, the discretion has been modernised in a form recently developed by the Office of Legislative Drafting for use as a general discretion in Defence determinations. At the same time, this step advances my portfolio's agenda of simplifying public sector personnel legislation wherever possible. A copy of the amending determination is also attached.
I trust that this meets your Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
PETER REITH
Minister for Industrial Relations
25 June 1997
The Hon Alexander Downer MP
Minister for Foreign Affairs

Dear Minister
I refer to the Quarantine (General) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 85, which introduce a system of infringement notices for minor quarantine offences.

Regulation 85 defines an infringement notice offence to mean a contravention of a minor nature. There is no further indication of what is minor, which would thus appear to be left to the discretion of the quarantine officer. The Committee accepts that it may be difficult to define the circumstances which are to be regarded as minor in the context of the Regulations. However, your advice would be appreciated.

There appear to be no AAT review provisions relating to the decision of an officer under rr.86 (serving an infringement notice), 88(b) (refusing to withdraw an infringement notice) or 90 (allowing a further period for paying the prescribed penalty). The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether independent review of these decisions is available and, if not, of the reasons for this.

Regulation 89 sets out the matters which must be included in infringement notices but does not require the infringement notice to include the beneficial consequences of a person paying the administrative penalty. The Committee considers that it would be appropriate to amend the Regulations to require notice of these to be given.

Regulation 89(1)(e) provides that if a person on whom an infringement notice is served does not wish the matter to be dealt with by a court then the person must pay the penalty before leaving the clearance area. Regulation 90, however, provides that a quarantine officer may allow a further period for payment. There is no requirement that notice of the advantageous provisions of r.90 be included in r.89 notices and the Committee considers that this should be done. In any event, the Committee considers that the Regulations would be more fair if they provided as of right for a period of 28 days within which payment may be made. Similar provisions are included in other instruments providing for administrative penalties, such as the recent Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations.

The Explanatory Statement is uninformative and, in some cases, slightly misleading. For instance, `Regulation 87 requires the person being served with an infringement notice to provide their name and address and to show evidence of the person's identity'. In fact, r.87 merely confers a discretion on a quarantine officer to require a person to give their name and address and to prove identity.
The Committee would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
