Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 25 June 1997 in which you raised some issues about the proposed introduction of a system of infringement notices for minor quarantine offences at airports by way of the Quarantine (General) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No. 85 which was tabled on 13 May 1997.
The Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the Amendment was, by necessity, general in nature and therefore it may further your understanding of the amendment if I provide some more detail.

As a first step the following additional background on the environment in which the proposed Quarantine Infringement Notices (QIN) system will operate may be of assistance. I will then address the specific issues you have raised.

As you will know the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) provides quarantine clearance of aircraft and their passengers arriving from overseas. This year about eight million tourists and returning Australians are expected to enter Australia through our international airport terminals and prior to arrival each passenger must complete a declaration about any items which may present a quarantine risk (foodstuffs, wooden items, plant and animal origin material etc). On arrival passengers then choose to leave the baggage hall either via the green exit channel if they believe they have nothing to declare or to present themselves at the red exit channel with items they wish to declare for examination.

AQIS has been aware for some time from spot checks in green channels that some passengers deliberately do not declare items of quarantine concern for many reasons including getting out of the airport quickly or smuggling. Recent surveys of green channels at all international gateways have shown that a worryingly high average of 35 per cent of green channel passengers are carrying items which should have been declared. While this is of concern, what is more disturbing was the finding that six per cent were carrying items of major quarantine significance. In 1995/96 this meant that about 180,000 passengers entered Australia carrying items of such quarantine concern that, if they had been declared, they would have been seized and destroyed. I am sure you will agree that this situation is completely unacceptable.

There have been a number of responses to this situation which have included additional quarantine detector dog teams, the introduction of modern X-ray equipment at some airports and the development of an education campaign part of which is the introduction of a new in-flight video for airlines to inform incoming passengers of their obligations under the Quarantine Act 1908. The QIN system proposed in the Amendment is a part of this package of responses and is modelled on the system currently operated by the United States Department of Agriculture and was first suggested as being feasible and desirable in Australia by the National Audit Office.

At this point I must emphasise that Quarantine Officers already exercise considerable discretion and where it is clear that a passenger has made an honest mistake or genuinely does not understand his/her obligations, he/she will, as is the case now, be let off with an explanation and a warning. The QIN system targets the passenger who has deliberately made a false declaration simply to gain a quick exit from the airport or to avoid the risk of confiscation of goods such as a food delicacy or the cutting of a favourite plant. By far the greater number of passengers are in the former category.
Many of those in the latter category have in the past only been warned when detected because prosecution has been impractical. They will now be processed under the QIN system.

It is also relevant to note that prior to the development of the system, AQIS research demonstrated that the vast majority of arriving passengers have access to sufficient funds to pay a fine of the magnitude proposed. This research verifies the US experience which also shows that almost all passengers served with a notice elect to pay by cash or credit card before leaving the airport.
Initially, the QIN system is to be used at Australia's eight international air terminals although it is possible it will be extended to cruise ship passengers at some future time.

It is therefore against this background of an unacceptable problem with green channel passengers which has dictated a more assertive approach to quarantine border integrity at airports that I will address the specific concerns you have raised in your letter.
What is a "minor" breach of the Quarantine Act?

Each month Quarantine Officers seize about 11,000 items of quarantine concern from arriving passengers but only an average of four to six of those seizures will result in prosecution action being commenced. This is because the majority of seized goods are in small quantities (say, single pieces of fruit or single wooden items) or the passenger is only visiting Australia for a few days. Prosecutions are only undertaken if the amount of quarantine material is large (eg, a suitcase full of raw meat or plants), of extremely high risk or where there has been a deliberate attempt to smuggle and the passenger is in the country long enough to allow action through the courts to proceed.

The proposed arrangements are designed to address those offenders who purposely fail to declare items or who make a false declaration (eg declaring a wooden item for inspection but carrying live plants secreted in a suitcase). These types of breaches are currently not pursued through the courts largely because of time constraints and a lesser quarantine risk with offenders only losing the items they were carrying rather than having to pay a more substantial penalty. It is believed that the institution of a genuine, well publicised, on-the-spot fine system will deter passengers from attempting such acts in future and will eventually lead to a significant decrease in the number of passengers making false declarations.
Independent review of decisions made by a Quarantine Officer under Regulations 86,88b or 90.

An administrative review is not proposed as the QIN system is based on similar systems for dealing with minor transgressions (such as traffic infringements) where a person has the choice of either paying the on-the-spot penalty or, if they wish to challenge the matter, electing to have the matter heard by a court.
Inclusion of the beneficial consequences of a person paying the administrative penalty on the Infringement Notice.

I agree with your suggestion. Both the Infringement Notice and an information sheet provided to QIN recipients will include information on the choices they have and the beneficial consequences of paying the administrative penalty before leaving the airport.
Allowing a further period to pay (r90) being included in the r89 Notices and providing a right to pay within 28 days.

The main reason behind allowing a Quarantine Officer to make a judgment about allowing further time to pay a QIN is if there is a genuine reason why the person cannot pay at the airport (no cash or credit cards or no relative or friend meeting them able or willing to pay). However, as mentioned, the US experience with its quarantine infringement notice system indicates that it is very unusual for a person not to have sufficient cash or a credit card to pay the penalty. Consequently, it is expected that extensions of time to pay will be very infrequent. The fact that Quarantine Officers have this discretion is printed on both the QIN and the information sheet.

Including a right to pay within 28 days as a feature of the QIN system, as is the case with other schemes, is also viewed as impractical because of the peculiarities of the circumstances. If the offender is a returning Australian there is a good chance that they do not live in the city of arrival and there would be an unacceptable administrative burden on AQIS to follow up on offenders. More importantly, the green channel surveys showed that about half of potential offenders were short term visitors who were only in the city of arrival for two or three days and then either left the country or moved on to other areas of Australia. I am sure you will understand the administrative difficulty of following up on those visitors.

The QIN system will only be implemented after extensive training of Quarantine Officers. This training will specifically emphasise the importance of fully informing alleged offenders of their choices to deal with the matter, and the implications of those choices. This will ensure the system is administered sensitively while still providing an effective method of dealing with those passengers who are found to be in clear breach of Australia's quarantine requirements while serving as a strong deterrent to other potential offenders.
You will appreciate that I am anxious to resolve these queries quickly and move on to implementing the QIN system.

I trust this response has adequately addressed your queries. I would also like to offer the services of senior staff from the Quarantine and Exports Division of AQIS to brief you or your Committee on the special circumstances addressed by the QIN system. In this regard you should contact Mr Peter Buckland, National Manager, Border Programs on 06 2725365 (fax 06 2723276). Officers of that Branch would also like to offer you and your Committee an opportunity to observe quarantine processing of arriving international passengers at Sydney Airport so as to assist their understanding of the environment in which the proposed system will operate and to see at first hand the issues it will address.
Yours sincerely
JOHN ANDERSON
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 67th report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible threats of legal proceedings against a senator and other persons , together with a volume of submissions and documents and transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
On 23 August 1995, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:
(a) whether threats of legal proceedings were made against persons in respect of their provision of information to Senator O'Chee in relation to matters raised in the Senate by Senator O'Chee;
(b) whether a threat of legal proceedings was made against Senator O'Chee in respect of his activities as a Senator; and
(c) whether contempts were committed in respect of those matters.
In giving precedence to the motion, the then President drew attention to the complexity of the issues involved in the reference. In particular, he drew attention to the:

. . . very significant question of whether actions taken against persons in respect of their provision of information to members of Parliament may constitute a contempt, in the words of section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, as conduct which "amounts, or is intended or likely to amount, to an improper interference with the free exercise by a House or a committee of its authority or functions, or with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member".

As the report indicates, in addressing this issue the committee also addressed other wide ranging issues, such as the right of a person to take legal action versus the duty of the Senate to protect the provision of information, sub judice questions, and the scope of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. In dealing with the questions, the committee sought its own advice and also received submissions from organisations such as the Queensland Law Society and the Law Council of Australia. Legal representations were also made on behalf of one of the persons involved in the inquiry.

In taking into account the important principles raised in all submissions, the committee wishes particularly to emphasise the need to protect the integrity of parliamentary proceedings, a need that is directly analogous to protection of court proceedings, while accepting the necessity to ensure comity between the executive, legislative and judicial arms of governance, and the role of the courts in the interpretation of legislation relating to parliamentary privilege. This report reflects the committee's judgment as to its own capacities, and those of the Senate, to ensure that the necessary separation between legal and parliamentary functions has been preserved.

The findings of the committee, one of which involves a finding of contempt against a person, are at page 25 of the report. The reasons for all findings are explained in the report. After I have completed these comments, I shall give the appropriate notice of motion to endorse the findings.

The committee goes on to make some observations arising from its terms of reference. While there was some opportunity to address the question as to the extent to which protection should be extended to consultations between constituents and senators, and to information held by senators in the performance of their duties as senators, the committee decided not to do so at this stage.

This is particularly because questions as to the scope of subsection 16(2) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 are currently before both the Queensland Supreme Court and the High Court of Australia—the first time that the extent of this element of privilege has been considered by the courts. Following the outcome of the two court cases, the committee undertakes to seek from the Senate a general reference to establish whether it should make any recommendations as to any further legislative initiatives which may be required to clarify the scope of parliamentary privilege.

Before completing my remarks, I wish to pay a special tribute to three senators involved in this inquiry. Honourable senators will no doubt recall the untimely death of Senator John Panizza, who was in Cairns to attend a public hearing of the committee. I wish again to place on record our appreciation of his commitment to the Senate and the committee.

This report also marks the last contribution of Senator Bruce Childs to the work of the committee. Senator Childs has been a member of the committee since 4 May 1983 and was its chairman for three years from 1984 to 1987. Although he was unable to attend the rescheduled public hearings of the committee, and therefore did not participate in subsequent deliberations on this reference, he was actively involved in the inquiry to that point, and indeed has been involved in all but six of the 67 reports which have been made by the committee since its establishment in 1966—a record which I am quite sure will never be broken.

Finally, on behalf of the committee, I wish to congratulate Senator Chris Ellison on his elevation, first to parliamentary secretary and then to Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. Senator Ellison joined the committee four years ago as a newly elected senator and his contribution to its work has been invaluable. We are particularly grateful that he continued on as member of the committee to complete this inquiry.
I seek leave to give notice of a motion.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty‐eight years ago today, in 1939, Robert Menzies, Prime Minister, announced that Australia was again at war. United, Australians fought to protect our way of life and many gave their lives for a cause they believed in passionately. They fought under a national flag that was unveiled 96 years ago today at the Exhibition Buildings in Melbourne. While the flag identifies Australia, the values that our people fought for are far more symbolic of Australia: self‐reliance and courage, cocky confidence, matey egalitarianism that recognised the inherent worth of each individual, loyalty to one's nation, anti‐authoritarianism and a desire to take the mickey out of anyone pompous or conceited.

SPEECH.PARA: Today these values are under attack and we may lose our national identity.
Do our young people have a sense of self‐worth and respect for the worth of others? Record levels of youth suicide suggest that they do not.
Do our young people have confidence, cocky or otherwise? Survey after survey suggests that they do not.

Do they have self‐reliance? The looking to others, whether it be government or business or parents, to solve their problems, the country's problems or indeed the world's problems suggests they do not.

A veil of hopelessness has descended on many of our young people as they look to drugs to create the psychedelic illusion of a better place or merely to dull the senses so the monotony is more bearable.

The national effort and unity in the second world war was even more remarkable because it followed almost immediately after the Great Depression. Imagine our Australia today, after years of recession and economic challenges. Are the underlying values in our community and belief in ourselves strongly enough held to create the ethos to fight and to risk death to defend them, or are we too despondent to care?

What is the cause of this despair? I suggest we need to look back to the second world war and the creation of the welfare state. In trying to put in place a safety net, we have created a security blanket that many refuse to give up. We have bred an entitlement mentality; a culture of dependency. This assertion of rights without countervailing responsibilities is destructive of cohesion in society and ultimately destroys the individual as well.

I stand on this side of the chamber because I believe in Liberal philosophy that asserts the worth of each individual. Liberals declare a society is only just and licit if it respects the rights of each individual. What is sometimes forgotten is that we also require each individual to do the same, and in so doing create a society built on an intricate web of rights and responsibilities.

In this year's budget papers the amount allocated to social security and welfare expenditure is $52,316,000,000. This is by far the largest area of government expenditure, dwarfing spending on education at $11 billion and on health at $20 billion. In fact, it represents 40 per cent of the federal budget. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that there are 8,400,000 workers in Australia. The social welfare budget works out at about $6,200 a year per worker, or $120 a week per worker.

It isn't possible to wave a magic wand and have social welfare expenditure disappear entirely. Lest anyone think I am some sort of anti‐welfare troglodyte, I do believe that there are a lot of Australians in genuine need and there is an obligation on all of us to provide for those who cannot take care of themselves.
However, the safety net is not intended to be a comfortable hammock slung across two palm trees swaying gently in the breeze.

It is a national disgrace that some young people choose unemployment instead of working in what they see as menial jobs. In a recent 60 Minutes program, a young person said it was beneath him to work in McDonald's because he had a degree. Tell that to Charlie Bell, the managing director of McDonald's, who started in the job this person refuses to take. This culture of conceited superiority is really one of childish, selfish dependency on others. I would like to say to these young people and the other young people of Australia: the measure of your worth is not where you start in life, it's where you end.

BREAK.PARA: My family encouraged me to be self‐reliant and independent. As a teenager I worked in a range of part‐time jobs, from packing boxes in a factory to selling eggs door to door. In all those jobs I never saw myself as a failure or a victim. I had belief in myself; I knew I would do better.

In the 1980s I worked for the community sector in the western suburbs of Melbourne—firstly, at my local church and then in an innovative employment skills and placement program. I worked with tens of thousands of people stripped of dignity because they were unemployed. They were angry at an education system that had not taught them to read and write properly, let alone prepare them with the skills required by employers. They were disheartened by the constant churning through vacuous training programs that were designed merely to keep them out of the unemployment statistics.
My concern about the ease with which people get and retain social security payments is more about the impact it has on their sense of self-worth than the impact it has on our federal budget.

It used to be that the social welfare system provided temporary financial support while people got back on their feet. Now social welfare is a lifelong entitlement which traps people in poverty. Various benefits such as health care cards, transport concessions and family assistance mean that the real value of social welfare payments is far greater than an equivalent wage or salary. There is insufficient incentive to get part-time or temporary work because complex rules designed to prevent abuse act as barriers.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants, for example, has found that a family wage earner on $30,000 a year is worse off than a family wage earner on $20,000 a year because of the top‐up of government benefits. What sort of mindless system do we have where a $10,000 a year pay increase makes you worse off? Yet this is the system after 13 years of Labor neglect.

The Monash University Centre for Population and Urban Research has disclosed that 32 per cent of all Australians are dependent in whole or in part on government welfare. The report saw the increasing dependency on welfare as a function of the restructuring of society and, in turn, higher income inequality. However, from my experience, I would argue that the relatively easy availability of welfare is a key factor in increased welfare dependency. When retrenched and given a choice of seeking less palatable work or going on welfare, the sums work out in favour of going on welfare. As we all know, with such rapid technological progress and workplace changes, once you are out of the work force your skills rapidly devalue and it is hard to get back in.
Based on the Monash report, the Bulletin magazine, in its inimitable way, thundered in July:

Where would you expect to find the nation's highest percentage of people on welfare? In some derelict mining community or rust‐bucket factory town? Try Tweed Heads, NSW, gateway to the beachy, boozy Gold Coast where 53.7% of the population exist on hand‐outs.

With statistics such as those reported in such a sensationalist fashion, it is no wonder the Australian tax paying public is getting jack of it. Clemenger Advertising reported last month on a study where 71 per cent said they were really concerned about dole bludgers and 70 per cent were really concerned about rich people getting welfare.

There is a common thread in all this. As citizens we expect, and I believe rightly so, that those in receipt of welfare benefits do something to reduce or remove their reliance on welfare. The term `workfare' was coined in the United States to refer to the concept of reciprocal obligations associated with the receipt of welfare benefits. By and large, most countries have implemented schemes designed to coax people into work and away from benefits.

In the USA the Republican Congress and the Democratic President have put in place historic bipartisan reforms that set mandatory time limits on the receipt of most welfare benefits. Decades of social welfare orthodoxy that started with the New Deal in the Great Depression have been jettisoned. The Economist magazine reports that the reforms are working and more people are finding work, many for the first time in their lives.
More has to be done to encourage the positive aspects of self-reliance and entrepreneurialism. These are not new concepts. In 1945 Robert Menzies said:
Only from genuinely free, progressive, diligent and encouraged individuals can a really powerful nation be built.

Australia's longest serving Prime Minister identified the most important task this nation faces. It all begins with our children, our young people, our future. Parents, the education system and community leaders must take on the responsibility of inculcating our children with a sense of self‐worth and personal obligation to society. It is out of such values that optimism and commitment to self‐improvement are born.

Last week I took a group of year five and six students on a tour of Parliament House. I asked them what they saw as the major issues affecting Australia. They replied: drug use, youth suicide, homelessness and poverty. My eight‐year‐old nephew worries about environmental degradation. My niece of ten worries about escalating crime. What happened to the innocence of youth?

Our young people deserve hope. Modern Western society is regarded as the pinnacle of human development and progress. Surely we can do better than having 40 per cent of our children living in poverty and 30 per cent of our people dependent on government.

As we look to the third millennium, we can start admitting that the time of big government with handouts for all is over. We need to look to ourselves first and develop again those values that our diggers so epitomised when they made the ultimate sacrifice: self-reliance and courage, cocky confidence, matey egalitarianism that recognised the inherent worth of each individual, loyalty to one's nation, anti-authoritarianism and a desire to take the mickey out of anyone pompous or conceited.

There is no greater challenge facing this country than the development and encouragement of our young people, to nurture these values in their lives. I commit myself, through the course of my parliamentary career and beyond, relentlessly to pursue this end.

Madam President, it has been said that it is easy to look tall when you stand on the shoulders of giants. As I end my first speech in this house, I am reminded of the incredible debt of gratitude I owe to many people.

Whilst still at school, in 1975, I joined the Young Liberal Movement. I was fortunate to meet possibly the most outstanding political figure outside of this parliament in Michael Kroger. His guidance and support over two decades have been, as is everything about Michael, warm hearted and generous. Michael Kroger's term as President of the Victorian Division of the Liberal Party is legendary, and his enthusiasm and optimism transformed the party. Of course, back in the 1970s, Michael teamed with Peter Costello, who is clearly the most outstanding political figure of his generation in the parliament—and I am delighted that the Treasurer is here today.

In over two decades in the Liberal Party, I have met many dedicated and wonderful people who serve our country both inside and outside the parliament. One of them is here today: the Hon. Maree Lukins is the youngest female ever elected to the Victorian Upper House. She has paved the way for all young women who choose to combine motherhood with a parliamentary career.

I hope one day that the advent of a new female MP will not be a moment for reflection on female representation in the parliament. However, while a female MP is no longer a novelty, we are still under‐represented. It took 17 parliaments before Dame Enid Lyons and Dame Dorothy Tangney were both sworn into parliament on 21 August 1943. In her maiden speech Dame Enid said:

I believe, very sincerely, that any woman entering the public arena must be prepared to work as men work; she must justify herself not as a woman but as a citizen; she must attack the same problems, and be prepared to shoulder the same burdens.
Dame Enid was right, and I believe all 22 former and 25 current female senators would agree.

With my colleagues Senators Troeth and Patterson, I am the third female senator out of five senators representing the Liberal Party for Victoria. It is the first time a major political party has had a majority of its representatives as women. This goal has taken nearly 100 years for women to reach.

The Victorian Division of the Liberal Party is the rock on which Menzies built the most successful political party in Australia. I am proud to be a member of that division and I am honoured that they have chosen me, without quotas and on merit, to replace Senator Jim Short.

It is fitting that the Victorian division is the first to achieve the milestone of having a majority of its senators as women. The Victorian division has had continuous female representation in the Senate since 1950. Dame Ivy Wedgwood was succeeded by Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in 1971, and my colleague Senator Kay Patterson in turn replaced Dame Margaret in 1987. This unbroken chain of 47 years is a record that will never be beaten because we will keep stretching it year by year.

The Hon. Jim Short resigned from the Senate on 12 May this year after a distinguished record of service, firstly as the member for Ballarat in the House of Representatives, then as a senator for Victoria and as a shadow minister where he made many friends in our diverse multicultural communities. Following the 1996 election, he served as the Assistant Treasurer and helped put in place the process of financial consolidation.

Jim Short not only believed in the highest standards of conduct for ministers, he lived those beliefs. With grace and with dignity, he resigned his position as a minister over what many would regard as a trifling technicality. However, he believed that the standards of probity for those in public office are higher than for members of the general community.

On 13 May, the day after Jim Short resigned, the parliament of Victoria appointed me to fill the casual vacancy and I was sworn in on 14 May. I am not sure if a two-day turnaround is a record for replacing a senator, but it is pretty fast and it is indicative of the `can do' approach of the Victorian government, led by Jeff Kennett. The transformation of Victoria from industrial rust‐belt wasteland to a growing services and information rich economy is due to the visionary approach of the most successful Premier in Australia today. I am honoured to have worked in the Kennett government as a senior public servant before being appointed to the Senate.
As I conclude today, Madam President, I would like to thank you, the officers and staff of the Senate and my Senate colleagues for your gracious welcome and assistance.
I would also like to thank my staff team—Sonia, Di, Catherine and Leanne—for their loyalty, friendship and commitment.

To my family and friends: I am conscious of the sacrifice that you will make in the years ahead. I thank you now both for your understanding and for your love and support which enable me to stand in this place today.
Finally, I would like to pay tribute to my husband, Giuseppe de Simone: I admire and respect you more than words can say. Thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I present the report of the committee, entitled Working Holiday Makers: More Than Tourists , together with submissions, transcripts of evidence, minutes of proceedings and a report prepared for the committee entitled, Working Holiday Visas: A Comparative Study . I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I am aware that the report was tabled in the other place earlier this week. I endorse the comments made by the chair of the committee, Mrs Gallus. What is more, I endorse the emphasis Mrs Gallus put in her tabling statement on the content of the report. Similarly, I endorse the remarks that my colleagues in the other place made when they spoke to the report. I refer to the words of Mr Duncan Kerr, Mr Stephen Martin and Ms Teresa Gambaro. I understand all three members of the committee will no longer be serving on the committee. I thank them for their cooperation in developing this report. It was great fun working with them—we worked very well and very hard together—and we will miss them as the committee continues with its deliberations. We wish them well in their new roles.

I congratulate my colleague Mrs Gallus, the chair of the committee. She chaired the proceedings exceptionally well. She gave everybody a fair go—particularly the witnesses—and we listened to and took into account all that was put before us in developing the report.

Mrs Gallus paid tribute to the committee secretariat in tabling the report the other day. She referred to Andres Lomp, the committee secretary; Catherine Cornish, the senior research officer; Gabrielle Jess, the research officer; and Denise Picker and Sophia Konti, the administrative officers; and thanked them for their contribution to the work of the committee. I, from the Senate side of the committee, endorse her remarks and, in turn, thank all of the named individuals for their assistance through the inquiry and in developing the report.

Special thanks was attributed to Mr Christopher Dorrian, who was seconded from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs for the duration of the inquiry. He greatly assisted the committee in developing the report and I join with Mrs Gallus in thanking Mr Dorrian for his assistance.

BREAK.PARA: I am not going to repeat the words that Mrs Gallus used in the other place the other day because I endorse them, and there is no need to be repetitious. I will refer to some of the comment that has emanated from the media and other places since the report has been brought down. I will refer, in the first instance, to the Sydney Morning Herald, which featured on its front page a small column, entitled `Backpackers to face visa curb' and referred us on to page 3, where the article was headlined, `Backpack tourists "taking our jobs"', under the by‐line of Tony Wright.

Tony, you got it wrong, mate; you got it wrong. The committee was not about limiting backpackers or attacking backpackers for taking Australians' jobs. We did not do that and I will point out—and it is probably an appropriate moment now—the distinction between working holiday‐makers and backpackers. At 1.25, the report says:

The phrase `working holiday maker' (abbreviated to `WHM') is used to describe those individuals who are the holders of a working holiday visa. During the inquiry, some people referred to working holiday makers as `backpackers'. It is important to note that the terms `working holiday maker' and `backpacker' are not interchangeable. The tourism industry definition of a backpacker is anyone who stays in a backpacker hostel. This can include holders of visitor visas and holders of working holiday visas. The important difference between the two is that people who hold working holiday visas are eligible to undertake work in Australia, while people who hold visitor visas are not eligible to work. Estimates suggest that over 200,000 backpackers travelled to Australia in 1995‐96. Among that group would have been a significant proportion of the 40,237 people granted working holiday visas in 1995‐96.

Tony Wright, you have got it wrong. I hope you can right the wrong that you have done in the way you have misled people. I had some telephone calls on that matter yesterday after the article appeared.

Backpackers are not necessarily working holiday‐makers. Working holiday‐makers are a very privileged group in our community. Not only have they got the right to come in and enjoy our wonderful country, but they have got the right for a limited period of time to work while they are here.

That matter leads me on to the news release from the Tourism Council Australia, authorised by Mr Bruce Baird. One would expect someone who is getting nearly half a million dollars a year in a salary package to at least know what they are talking about when they issue press statements like this. If Mr Baird did not authorise this press statement, in which he is quoted, I would expect that there would be some blood on the floor within the Tourism Council Australia because of what is in the news release. It ends with this comment:
`The tourist industry believes strongly that there should be no limit to the number of holiday visas issued and that the cap should be lifted as soon as possible,' Mr Baird said.

Mr Baird has got it dreadfully and frightfully wrong, and I hope he is not deliberately seeking to mislead in putting the statement forward in the way that he has done. Of course there is no limit—no cap—on the number of tourist visas issued in Australia. There was no proposal from this committee or, to the best of my knowledge, from any other parliamentary committee for a cap on the number of tourist visas. No proposal whatsoever. We certainly have not mentioned it in our report. We have proposed in our report that the cap that is on the working holiday‐maker visa be continued for a further three years and that it be reviewed after a period of three years.

I could agree with most of what else is in Mr Baird's press statement because, to a great degree, it does reflect the reality of things. He talks about the contribution that working holiday‐makers make to Australia. He goes on to make one point, though, that the reports claiming that working holiday‐makers are taking away jobs from Australians is a gross exaggeration. He talks about the survey that was done of TCN members. We had some of the TCN members make submissions to the committee. I will quote from a small part of one, 3.47, in the report:
`Many of the large duty free companies in the Japanese tourist market, for example, advertise in Japan for young people to come to Australia on working holidays.'

I would suggest to the Senate that that is clearly a breach of the spirit of what these working holiday‐maker visas are about. Mr Baird ought to know that some of his members are undertaking this type of activity. I hope that he will make himself aware of it and that he will not be putting out misleading press releases of this nature in the future.

Attention was drawn to the fact that the tourism industry is in decline and we all agreed that the working holiday‐maker is an integral part of the tourism industry. Let me reflect on the increasing numbers that have come into Australia under the working holiday‐maker visa program over the last few years. In 1993‐94 the number increased by 15.0 per cent over the previous year, in 1994‐95 it increased by 19.6 per cent over the previous year, in 1995‐96 it increased by 13.8 per cent over the previous year and last year, 1996‐97, it increased by some 24 per cent over the previous year. The minister, in a recent announcement, said that the figure for this current financial year is going to increase by 10 per cent over the last financial year. All in all, this is almost a 100 per cent increase in just over four years. So I do not really think too much attention needs to be drawn to a slowdown in the growth of working holiday‐makers. Rather, it would be one of the boom areas in the tourist industry.

Finally, I would like to reflect on an article that appeared in yesterday's West Australian. It is not something that I was aware of and perhaps, on reflection, the committee may not have given enough emphasis to the fact that working holiday‐makers may be taking more jobs away from Australians than we are aware of. The article was headed `Foreign guides lead many tourists astray' and it was by Hal Crawford. It read:
When Perth tour guide Henry Yap overheard a group of tourists being confidently informed that the vast body of water lapping at the base of Mt Eliza was a lake, he knew there was something wrong.

The lake that he was referring to was, of course, the Swan River, which runs through Perth. That is a serious miscalculation, but the more serious one was an anecdotal piece of information that was given to the committee of how a Japanese tourist guide was asked why people were stopping and being silent at 11 o'clock on 11 November. Of course that is Remembrance Day, but the guide could not tell him and that is an indictment on the industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to comment on the report of the Joint Committee on Migration. I, like Senator McKiernan, wish to thank the committee secretariat, who were always extremely helpful and hardworking in the preparation of this report. I also wish to pay tribute to my colleague Mrs Gallus, as chair of the committee, for the way that she handled it.

SPEECH.PARA: This inquiry was a most interesting inquiry to be on in that what would look on the surface to be a relatively simple situation turned out to have some quite complex layers of employment aspects and tourism aspects. The way in which we are prepared to display the culture and working atmosphere of Australia to visitors to our shores was also a complex issue.

The working holiday visa program enables young people to come to Australia for 12 months and to work for each employer for not more than three months. Some aspects of this situation concerned us greatly. Like Senator McKiernan, I was disappointed in the way that the media tended to treat this, particularly those articles he pointed out by Tony Wright in the Sydney Morning Herald of Tuesday, 2 September and by Ben Mitchell in the Melbourne Age. Both tended to stress that this program takes jobs away from young people.

Leaving aside for the moment the aspect of the tour guides in Cairns, evidence provided not only in this inquiry but also with respect to previous aspects of this question tended to say that the working holiday‐maker program was not a threat to local jobs and conditions. While the committee certainly put forward in its recommendations that we would never want the working holiday‐maker visa program to be a threat to local jobs and conditions, and that it should not be used as a substitute for labour market problems, almost every witness we had argued that working holiday‐makers tended to move from job to job in seasonal type work so that they were not actually taking away jobs from young people in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: It has been stressed, particularly in the Riverland area of both South Australia and Victoria, and by the Northern Victorian Fruitgrowers Association, that the seasonal positions that they require are only available for short periods of time. In paragraph 340 of the report, the Victorian Fruitgrowers Association is quoted as saying:
`At no time during our peak season are there enough Australians to fill the positions available.'

That aspect of the working holiday‐maker program was repeated again by the Swan Hill Rural City Council and by the Riverland Horticultural Council—that working holiday‐makers are an essential aspect of the labour market that they are providing. The vacancies in the duty‐free shops in Cairns and the tour guide program for Cairns are probably different aspects of the question and are considered in detail in the report.

It is important to realise that the working holiday‐makers bring enormous benefits to Australia and receive enormous benefits from their visits to Australia. Largely, the money they earn here, they spend here. It is being put into the local economy, and this provides a great boost for rural economies. The holiday‐makers experience enormous social and cultural development as they move around Australia and work in different occupations. The program is an important component of the tourist industry, particularly in northern New South Wales and Queensland, and it promotes mutual understanding between Australia and other nations.

I am extremely pleased that the minister has seen fit to comment favourably on those aspects of the report which indicate that this program is to continue. One of my sons is at present in England, experiencing the benefits in reverse, as he is a working holiday‐maker in England. I would heartily commend the program to young people in Australia and to young people abroad who wish to experience Australia at first hand. This was a most satisfying inquiry to be a member of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to add my commendations of the secretariat of the committee which worked on this report and also to thank my colleagues here for their contributions—as well as colleagues in the other place. Like Senator McKiernan, I will not go over the substance of the report because that has been done more than adequately in the other chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was going to do is what both Senators Troeth and McKiernan have done, and that is to draw attention to some of the sensationalist media reports that have accompanied the release of this report. I was quite dismayed to see the exaggerations in some of the articles. Some of those people who were involved in this reference as witnesses or who provided submissions have rung my office in the last 24 hours to voice their displeasure. I am glad that the record has been set straight today.

It was a privilege to be involved as a Democrat member in this inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, and I commend the work of not only the secretariat but all the members, including the chair of the committee, Mrs Gallus, and the deputy chair, Senator McKiernan.

I have a few words to say on the report. I note that when the working holiday program first became subject to capping, it was initially capped at around 33,000 places. That cap then rose to 42,000, and the present Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, raised the cap to 50,000. It has now risen to a provisional target of around 55,000. So I think we should note that the present minister has seen that it is fitting to allow a substantial increase in the number of working holiday visas issued in this country.

The committee has rightly identified that such numbers need to be tightly targeted, but I think the current government is at times a little confused about its migration policy rationale in this country and specifically in relation to the offering of visas. When it comes to current migration visa classes, we note that there have been changes to regulations allowing families and partners to access visas to this country. However, there has not necessarily been a change to regulations relating to those visas which involve an exchange of money.

However, I do endorse the current numbers that have been coming to this country under the working holiday program. For the record, it is important to note the committee's statement once again, and that is that `working holiday‐makers are an important source of supplementary labour for those industries which require short‐term casual workers—the horticultural industry, for instance. In many instances, their presence is critical at peak times.'

The report goes on to say that, although statistical evidence indicated that the overall impact of working holiday‐makers on the Australian labour market is minimal, the committee has identified that they have a significant impact on specific industries. Again, for various reasons, it was very difficult for the committee to assess the actual impact of the working holiday program on those industries. I reiterate the concerns voiced by my colleagues, Senator McKiernan and Senator Troeth, that some of the media reports were sensationalist in claiming that the impact of the working holiday visa program was adverse or huge.

Perhaps what we have is a microcosm or snapshot of the economic impact of migration on Australia generally. As many commentators have noted—and I think I can include in that category a former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser—immigration, by increasing the demand for goods and services, can contribute to employment opportunities for Australians and to the economic value of the nation. That is certainly something that we picked up through this inquiry.

I noted that in the previous debate on migration policy Senator Vanstone said, `But don't the Democrats want to cut the levels of migration?' I would like to state, for the record, that the paramount concern of the Democrats is not necessarily what impact immigration has on employment or economics, because we have seen the benefits of migration in those areas, but what its impact might be on our natural environment. Unfortunately, the committee's terms of reference did not necessarily include that environmental consideration, but I know that there were members of the committee who kept that in their minds as the committee progressed.

Of particular concern to me was the potential for abuse of young workers—young female workers particularly and above all those from non‐English speaking backgrounds. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to recommendation 34(d) in the report which recommends that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs review—in conjunction with other relevant Commonwealth agencies—the information that is provided to those people on working holiday visas and ensure that that information:

. . . identifies clearly the relevant authorities or agencies which working holiday makers should contact if they require information or experience difficulties while in Australia, particularly in relation to employment

I, for one, would like explicit information about the unlawfulness of sexual harassment to be included in such information, and I hope the minister will take that and the concerns of the Australian Democrats in that regard on board.

This is a fair and balanced report, as most of my colleagues have mentioned. I commend it to all honourable senators for their consideration and I urge the government to implement its recommendations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

that State and Territory Governments, in co‐operation with the appropriate retail trade associations, expand their education programs directed at retailers

Primarily a State/Territory Government issue; substantial work already being done at State/Territory level. Commonwealth prepared to establish best‐practice models for use by State/Territory jurisdictions. Commonwealth also seeking to educate retailers on provisions of its own tobacco control legislation

that, as it is virtually impossible to prevent access by children to cigarette vending machines, these types of vending machines be prohibited in all States and Territories (opposed by dissenting report)
A State/Territory Government issue; Commonwealth prepared to pursue the issue through appropriate forums, including MCDS

Primarily State/Territory law enforcement agency issue

That a system of substantial fines be introduced in all States and Territories to discourage the sale of tobacco products to minors

Appropriate programs to be explored by the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group in the context of the National Tobacco Strategy

Appropriate programs to be explored by the Department of Health and Family Services and the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group
that funding be provided by the Commonwealth Government for programs to address the problem of tobacco use amongst people from non‐English speaking backgrounds, including older people
Appropriate funding mechanisms to be explored by the Department of Health and Family Services and the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group

BREAK.PARA: The most important duty of any government is to protect and improve the general health and well‐being of its citizens. One way a government can promote the health of the population is to minimise the use of substances known to be detrimental to health.

Tobacco is such a substance. Over 50,000 studies have been undertaken over the past several decades, in many countries, which confirm that tobacco use has a demonstrably deleterious effect on human health, and that nicotine is an addictive substance. More recent studies indicate a relationship between exposure to environmental tobacco smoke and the incidence of a number of diseases.

To date, the tobacco harm minimisation strategies of the Commonwealth have incorporated legislation and regulation affecting advertising, voluntary agreements with the industry regarding substance levels in tobacco products, educational programs and campaigns, the levying of excise on tobacco products and the banning of smoking in all Commonwealth‐owned buildings. With a view to reviewing the level of industry regulation and exploring potential cost‐recovery mechanisms for the community, the Senate Community Affairs Reference Committee was directed to inquire into the Tobacco Industry and the Costs of Tobacco‐Related Illness.

The Senate Committee presented its report to Parliament in December 1995. The report explored a number of issues which affect the health of Australians generally, and a number of groups in our society specifically. The Committee made 39 recommendations with a view to minimising the deleterious effects of tobacco through a range of Commonwealth, state and territorial government initiatives.

The Senate Committee fulfilled its obligation to provide a complete list of possible options for future action on tobacco control. The report furnishes the Government with a valuable exploration of potential mechanisms for recouping and reducing the significant costs of tobacco use to the community. The report also raises for discussion many possible avenues for further regulation of the tobacco industry, with the goal of reducing community use of this substance.

With the Committee's task completed, it is now incumbent on the Government to assess the feasibility of these initiatives as part of national strategies to reduce the uptake and prevalence of tobacco use in Australia.

Many of the Report's recommendations address issues most appropriately dealt with at a state or territory level, particularly those relating to education and intervention programs. While it is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth to develop or fund community‐level initiatives, the Federal Government will continue to play its part in facilitating interstate co‐operation and collaboration on these issues through appropriate forums, such as the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy.

The Report also includes many recommendations for further regulation by the Commonwealth. The strategies proposed are largely untested and, therefore, the benefits must be regarded as potential rather than guaranteed. Problems do not necessarily vanish with the passage of a law. Additional regulation needs to yield a clear and demonstrable benefit, be enforceable and have minimal incidental disruption or side‐effects.

In assessing the viability of each recommendation, the Government has sought to give due consideration to its commitment to deregulating business with a view to ensuring greater competition and efficiencies. Bodies such as the Office of Regulatory Review and the Small Business Deregulation Task Force are now prompting Government to justify the necessity, appropriateness and basis for regulation, and to ensure that there is a rational connection between the regulation and end to be sought. The fact that the validity of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 is being challenged in the High Court by a major tobacco manufacturer illustrates the need for all legislation to be defensible in terms of its net benefits to the public. For this reason, the Government will seek further expert advice on the potential for a number of the proposed regulatory reforms to contribute to reductions in smoking uptake and tobacco consumption.

Wherever possible the Government, in conjunction with advisory bodies such as the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group, will use the findings of the Report to guide future research and the development of policies to further the aims of the National Tobacco Strategy.

The Senate Community Affairs Reference Committee's December 1995 Report on the Tobacco Industry and the Costs of Tobacco‐Related Illness made the following recommendations on the passive smoking issue:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That smoking not be permitted in enclosed places, including office, factory, shop or other work sites, shopping centres, restaurants, theatres, hotels and sporting venues."

"That in respect of offices, shops, restaurants etc., outdoor or separately ventilated indoor spaces be made available for smokers, but that staff not be compelled to work in, or service, these areas."

A number of States and Territories have moved towards legislation governing smoking in public places. In particular, NSW, WA and SA have made progress in this area. The Commonwealth is prepared to work with other jurisdictions to develop guidelines addressing passive smoking and promote best practice in legislation in this area.

BREAK.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has undertaken substantial legislative measures to combat the impact of passive smoking on the public.

All Commonwealth offices have been made smoke‐free over the past decade. In 1987 the Air Navigation Act 1920 was amended to ban smoking on domestic airline flights. In 1996 this ban was made effective on all Australian carriers flying anywhere in the world, and on overseas carriers flying within Australia. In 1988, a ban on smoking in buses and coaches registered under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme was introduced. 1992 saw the banning of smoking in all airport buildings operated by the Federal Airports Corporation. Smoking on all interstate trains was banned in 1993.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That nicotine transdermal patches (nicotine patches) be listed in the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits; but that they only be prescribed as part of a structured smoking cessation program".

The Commonwealth does not endorse the recommendation at this time. Action on this recommendation should be delayed pending the outcomes of the review of cessation models and techniques. Funding for smoking cessation therapies, including nicotine replacement, should also be considered in the context of the Commonwealth's overall funding priorities for reducing tobacco related harm.

BREAK.PARA: In September 1993, Marion Merrell Dow, a manufacturer of nicotine patches, applied to list its brand of patches on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). As the nicotine patches satisfied the effectiveness and cost criteria of PBAC's statutory charter, the PBAC formally recommended PBS listing. PBAC advised that nicotine patches were most effective through a structured program and recommended that only four weeks supply be made available, instead of the usual 10 weeks, as patients would not be incurring the cost of buying cigarettes and could therefore fund the remainder of the course themselves.

In October 1994, the Federal Government considered PBAC's recommendation. The Federal Government was concerned that subsidising nicotine patches on the PBS could cost as much as $100 million a year and that the there was potential for reduced effectiveness and waste if patches were made available on the PBS rather than through a structured program. Because of these concerns, the Federal Government decided not to list nicotine patches on the PBS.

On 14 June 1995, the former Federal Minister for Human Services and Health announced the decision to fund a review of best practice smoking cessation Models. The review will evaluate the current smoking cessation programs and the appropriate role of nicotine replacement therapies within these cessation programs. This review was endorsed by all jurisdictions at the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy meeting in June 1995. Further, a literature review has recently been produced which examines cessation models and techniques, and the role of nicotine replacement therapies within such activities. The literature review will be disseminated and will inform the wider review of cessation models.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.3 MONITORING THE PROVISIONS OF THE TOBACCO ADVERTISING PROHIBITION ACT 1992
In regard to incidental and accidental advertising, the Senate Committee recommended the following:

"That the provisions of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 relating to incidental or accidental broadcast or publication of tobacco advertisements be strictly monitored and enforced by the Department of Human Services and Health."

BREAK.PARA: The Government is currently considering a scheme for the routine enforcement of the incidental and accidental provisions of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 . In addition, the Government will seek to acquire the data and information necessary to inform any possible future changes to the legislation pertaining to incidental and accidental advertising.

In 1973, the Commonwealth amended the Broadcasting and Television Act to phase out tobacco advertising on television. Print media advertising has been banned since 1990. The most recent legislation, the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act), came into effect in July 1993. The purpose of the Act is "to limit the exposure of the public to messages and images that may persuade them to start smoking, to continue to smoke or to use, or to continue to use, tobacco products". The Act does not intend to override existing State and Territory legislation, but rather to operate in concert with it. Effectively, the Act applies in its entirety only to those jurisdictions which do not have their own tobacco advertising control legislation—namely, Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.
The Act contains the following advertising exemptions:
. Section 14: The accidental or incidental broadcast of tobacco advertisements; and
. Section 19: The accidental or incidental publication of tobacco advertisements.
The overall intention of the exemptions is to safeguard legitimate commercial and political freedom of speech, whilst continuing to allow the operation of the prohibition on tobacco advertising.
A number of health groups have indicated their belief that these exemptions weaken the Act by undermining its prohibitions, and as such should be removed altogether.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Research into the impact of the exemptions

BREAK.PARA: The Department proposes to commission an independent study into the level and degree of both incidental and accidental advertising (Sections 14 and 19 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act ). The study may also examine paid advertisements which appear in imported periodicals. Such advertisements are currently exempted from the ban by Section 17 of the Act.
The results of the study will enable the Department to establish a baseline or measurement of current levels of advertising in films, television and overseas periodicals.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.4 SPONSORSHIP OF SPORTING AND CULTURAL EVENTS

BREAK.PARA: In seeking to replace Tobacco Industry sponsorship of major sporting and cultural events, the Committee sought to both eliminate current legislative provisions allowing for such sponsorship, and to create a Commonwealth‐generated fund to replace this sponsorship funding.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 be amended to remove the provision for the exemption of publication of tobacco advertisements in association with specified sporting and cultural events of international significance and that this be phased in by the year 2000."

"That the Commonwealth Government establish a national health promotion foundation or other appropriate national body to provide an alternative source of sponsorship funding to that provided by tobacco companies for major sporting and cultural events."

BREAK.PARA: The Senate Committee recommended that funding for the proposed body come from an increase in the tobacco excise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Because States and Territories may rely heavily on the financial benefits of hosting high profile sporting and cultural events, the Commonwealth Minister for Health and Family Services will retain the power to exempt such events from the ban on tobacco advertising. The Federal Government will, however, more rigorously assess future proposals from sporting organisations which apply for exemptions from Australia's tobacco advertising laws.

A health promotion foundation could be established through increases in tobacco excise to replace a certain proportion of tobacco company sponsorship. The Commonwealth Government does not, however, currently adopt a policy of revenue hypothecation in the manner of some states. All revenue from tobacco excise is channelled into consolidated revenue.

Further, given that similar ventures to that proposed by the Senate Committee have been implemented in a number of states, it must be determined whether a similar Commonwealth Government body would unnecessarily duplicate functions.

BREAK.PARA: Australia is the venue for a number of sporting and cultural events that are of international significance, with competitors drawn from many countries and a worldwide audience. Many of these events or competitions have sponsorship arrangements both internationally and locally which involve tobacco advertising.

The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act) contains a number of exemptions. Section 18 of the Act gives the Minister for Health and Family Services the power to exempt certain international sporting or cultural events from the general ban on tobacco advertising provided certain conditions are met.
An exemption may only be granted if the Minister determines that:

PARA.TAB: a) the event is of international significance and;
b) Australia would be likely to lose the event if the Minister does not specify it as one that is exempt from the general ban on tobacco advertising under the Act.

BREAK.PARA: The legislation requires the Minister to make decisions on a case by case basis, having considered all the information presented, and with regard to the objectives of the Act.

In deciding to exempt an event, the Minister may limit the impact of the exempted tobacco advertising by setting conditions on the type, level and nature of tobacco advertisements permitted in association with the event.
As of August 1997, 28 exemptions have been granted under Section 18 to events of international significance.

In September 1995 the former Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr C. M. Lawrence, announced the commencement of an independent review of the Section 18 exemption. This review recommended the gradual phasing out of the exemption.

Given the Minister's discretionary powers in granting an exemption under Section 18, however, it was decided that an actual amendment to the legislation would be less desirable than a simple tightening of the provisions for exemption. Further to this policy, applications for exemptions will face greater scrutiny than they have previously. Since announcing this policy, the Minister for Health and Family Services has denied three separate applications for exemptions. Previously, all but one application had been granted an exemption.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That the current testing procedures for cigarette yields be reviewed by an appropriate independent body to determine whether these procedures accurately reflect the actual levels of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide inhaled by smokers; and that the printed material contained on cigarette packs on tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide yield levels reflects this information".

The current procedure for testing tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide levels is of international standard. It may not, however, accurately reflect levels delivered to smokers. Testing to determine the actual levels of tar, nicotine, and carbon monoxide inhaled by smokers is probably not feasible. The Commonwealth will seek expert advice on the appropriate means for ensuring that smokers are informed about the limitations of cigarette testing.

BREAK.PARA: The levels of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide levels in cigarettes are not currently subjected to government regulation. However, four tobacco companies and one tobacco supplier are signatories to a Voluntary Code in Respect of CPM (Tar) Nicotine and CO Labelling on Cigarette Packaging. This Code specifies maximum levels of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide for cigarettes and has been adhered to by all local cigarette companies.

The Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) are commissioned by the Commonwealth to conduct the Cigarette Testing Program which determines the average yield of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide in cigarettes. In 1993, AGAL upgraded the cigarette testing methodology to the current (1991) ISO 3308 international standard. This is the most up‐to‐date internationally approved methodology for cigarette testing. AGAL conducted tests of the thirty most popularly smoked brands of cigarette in Australia in 1996. The results of these tests have been published and are currently being widely disseminated.

In addition, tobacco manufacturers are required to declare the average yields of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide on the side of cigarette packets for consumer information purposes. Strengthened health warnings and accompanying explanations are also required on cigarette packets to help educate smokers about some of the health effects of tobacco.

Research indicates that for each individual smoker the depth of inhalation, the duration of holding the smoke, how much of the tobacco stick is smoked etc. will vary. It would therefore be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to design a methodology that would determine the actual levels of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide inhaled by smokers since it would most likely be different every time. Also, the amount of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide that is absorbed by a smoker could vary from cigarette to cigarette.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.6 SCHEDULING OF NICOTINE AS A POISON

"That, while the Committee favours the listing of nicotine in tobacco prepared and packed for smoking as a Schedule 7 poison by the National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee, it believes that further investigation of the implications of this proposal should be under taken by the Council of Australian Governments and the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council".

The Commonwealth does not endorse the listing of nicotine prepared and packed for smoking as a Schedule 7 poison at this stage. The Commonwealth strongly agrees that further investigation of the implications of the proposal should be undertaken through an appropriate forum.

BREAK.PARA: Nicotine is currently scheduled (Schedule 7) in the Standard for the Uniform Scheduling of Drugs and Poisons (SUSDP) which is used by the States and Territories to schedule poisons under their Poisons legislation (the Poisons Schedule itself has no legal force). Schedule 7 poisons are poisons which require special precautions in manufacturing, handling, storage or use, or require special individual regulations regarding labelling or availability. The nicotine prepared and packed for smoking is exempted from scheduling in the SUSDP.

There have recently been a number of calls from major tobacco and health organisations (such as the Australian Medical Association(AMA) and the Australian Council on Smoking and Health (ACOSH)) for the removal of the exemption for the nicotine in smoking tobacco. The removal of the exemption is argued for on the grounds that it would assist in the achievement of, strengthened health warnings, generic packaging, display of ingredients/additives, restriction of sales and distribution and alternative tobacco advertising controls.

In October 1995, the WA Branch of the AMA and ACOSH prepared a submission to the Western Australian Poisons Advisory Council (WA PAC) proposing that the Committee remove the exemption for tobacco in Schedule 7 and develop regulations to permit its placement in an alternative Schedule. This matter was considered by WA PAC at their February 1996 meeting, and will receive further consideration later this year, when additional information and the opinion of learned colleagues is obtained. Advice from WA PAC indicates that any decision on the issue would be referred to the National Drugs and Poisons Committee (NDPSC) of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council

Legal advice obtained from the Attorney General's Department indicates that agreement by the NDPSC to remove the exemption for nicotine in smoking tobacco would subsequently require legislative enforcement by individual States and Territories. The further achievement of conditions for the sale of the nicotine in smoking tobacco, such as generic packaging would require specific incorporation of labelling/packaging and availability requirements.

From a policy perspective, further consideration would need to be given to the impact of the conditions which could be applied to smoking tobacco nicotine as a Schedule 7 poison. In addition to the impact on tobacco availability and consumption, consideration would need to be given to the impact of the restriction of sales to pharmacists on other small businesses and on the perception of pharmacies as a provider of health products.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That the National Health and Medical Research Council assess the health effects of tobacco product additives, including determining whether additives potentiate the effects of nicotine".

"That a list of the ingredients added to tobacco products be provided annually to the Commonwealth Government, on a confidential basis, by those tobacco companies whose products are available for sale in Australia".
"That a list of the ingredients in tobacco products, and their effects, be distributed (in an appropriate form) with all tobacco products sold in Australia".

A previous MCDS task force on this matter concluded that the health effects of tobacco additives are insignificant compared to the natural constituent substances of tobacco itself. The Commonwealth would also argue that there is greater public health benefit by requiring that the major harmful constituents of tobacco smoke and their health effects are provided on all tobacco packaging. The Commonwealth will, however, ask the NHMRC to assess international and locally available evidence as to the effect of additives on nicotine levels.

The Government supports recommendations 10 and 11, subject to investigation of the legal and commercial implications of such additional regulation, and a determination of the best method of disseminating such information to the public.

BREAK.PARA: In 1991, the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy (MCDS) commissioned a Task Force on Tobacco to investigate a number of issues including pesticides and additives in tobacco. The Task Force examined research by the Health Department of Victoria which concluded that the health consequences of potentially dangerous substances added to tobacco are likely to be insignificant when compared to the harm caused by the naturally occurring toxic contents of tobacco itself. The National Health and Medical Research Council advised the Task Force that it would not be prepared to set maximum levels for pesticides and additives as it was concerned that smokers could mistakenly believe that tobacco products which conformed to such standards were safe.

In April 1992 the MCDS endorsed the recommendations from the March 1992 Report of the Task Force on Tobacco. MCDS specifically agreed that no further action be taken concerning the labelling of pesticides and additives in tobacco and that should further evidence come to light that tobacco products contain significant quantities of pesticides and additives the issue would be reopened.

Concerns regarding additives were renewed following the release of a New Zealand study in March 1994. At the MCDS meeting of 30 September 1994, Ministers were advised that the Commonwealth had commissioned the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) to conduct investigations into the toxicology of cigarette additives (based on a literature review) and the feasibility of obtaining information of the toxicity of specific additives.

AGAL's review concluded that a substantial number of additives are either natural products, inorganic salts or other substances that find extensive use in the food industry. AGAL noted however, that there were some organic additives that may be toxic or produce toxic or noxious products, particularly on combustion. At the June 1995 meeting of MCDS Ministers were informed of AGAL's report and reaffirmed the 1992 MCDS decision that the health risks from additives are considered to be insignificant compared to the toxicity of tobacco smoke itself and that no further action need be taken unless further evidence comes to light.

The Trade Practices (Consumer Product Information Standards) (Tobacco) Regulations currently mandate that information on the major natural constituents of tobacco smoke—tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide—appear on retail packages of tobacco products. The Commonwealth does not, however, require tobacco companies to provide information on the ingredients added to tobacco products (although lists have been provided in the past by Philip Morris Limited).

Industry representatives have indicated that, while they are willing to provide information on additives to the Government on request, they are concerned that the provision of specific brand formulae to the public would compromise proprietary commercial information. These legal and commercial sensitivities will need to be considered in any regulation mandating disclosure of tobacco product additives to the general public.

Further, an appropriate means of disseminating such information to the public should be determined before the Commonwealth embarks on further regulations. In New Zealand, information on the ingredients of tobacco products is required to be provided on an annual basis by tobacco manufacturers and importers, and is available to the public on request.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Citing evidence that increases in cigarette prices had a demonstrated impact on juvenile smoking, the Committee made the following recommendations:
"That the National Health and Medical Research Council appoint a sub‐committee to review the current weight‐based excise system."

"That the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments ensure that there are regular real increases in the levels of excise duties and business franchise fees levied on tobacco products; and that the revenue from these taxation increases be directed to tobacco control and health promotion activities".

The Commonwealth will refer the proposal to review the current weight‐based excise system to the National Health and Medical Research Council for investigation and report. The Council's review will incorporate appropriate consultation with other stakeholders, particularly Commonwealth agencies involved in the administration and collection of the current excise system. A decision on the future direction of the tobacco excise will take into account the Council's recommendations.

As a result of the recent High Court decision on tobacco franchise fees the Commonwealth has, at the request and on behalf of the State and Territory Governments, increased its tax on tobacco to replace charges now of doubtful constitutional validity. All of the revenue collected by the Commonwealth under these arrangements will be returned to the States and Territories (after allowing for Commonwealth administrative costs).
As noted in response to Recommendation 6, the Commonwealth Government does not follow a policy of revenue hypothecation. All revenue from tobacco excise is channelled into consolidated revenue.

BREAK.PARA: Health groups have expressed a belief that the current method of levying tobacco excise, which is based on the weight of cigarettes, has contributed to the emergence of "budget‐priced" cigarettes.
