To date, investigations by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) have shown that there was no significant difference between the weight of cigarettes used in budget packets compared to standard packets of the same cigarette brand.
Subsequent representations from health advocacy groups, however, suggest that further research into the merits of a stick‐based system may warrant consideration.

In the 1995 Federal Budget it was announced that tobacco excise levied by the Federal Government would be increased by 10 per cent from mid‐night 9 May 1995. In addition to this tax increase in May 1995 both the New South Wales and Victorian State Governments also announced increases in tobacco licence fees. This followed the significant tax increases implemented by the Federal Government. The first of these was a 3% increase in the 1993 Federal Budget; this was followed by four 5% increases levied at six months intervals. The cumulative effects of the tax increases has increased the price of a packet of cigarettes considerably.

There has been some concern that the price increases are having the greatest impact upon those people on low incomes. It has been claimed that many pensioners and other low‐income earners who are unable or unwilling to stop smoking are suffering significant financial hardship, and are going short on food and other necessities. Thus there have been calls for the Government to assess the social implications of increased tobacco taxes.

Against this argument, it is clear that smoking itself places unequal burdens of disease and other costs on disadvantaged groups. There is no evidence that low income earners are going without food or clothing as a result of their tobacco habit. People on low income are more price sensitive that those on high incomes; therefore tax increases could be seen as having a progressive impact overall.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That national education programs be developed for primary and secondary school students and that these programs be regularly revised; and that these programs be based on the most recent research and evidence of the socio‐economic, environmental, behavioural and personal factors identified as encouraging the take‐up of tobacco use by young people, and the continuing use of tobacco by young people. The Committee further recommends that these programs include information on the dangers of passive smoking, particularly for young people."

"That primary and secondary teachers, who will teach or are teaching health courses that include anti‐smoking units, be funded by the Commonwealth Government as part of the National Drug Strategy to attend teacher education and in‐service training sessions."
"That school‐based smoking prevention programs be encouraged and expanded; and that they be taught each year from at least Year 4 (about 9 years of age) to the end of secondary schooling."

"That no smoking be permitted (including smoking by students, staff, parents and visitors) on any school premises; and that students who are found in breach of this be counselled, and supported through drug education and `Quit' smoking programs."

"That the minimum age for the purchase of tobacco products be 18 years in all States and Territories; and that the States and Territories investigate the feasibility of making it an offence for persons under the age of 18 years to purchase tobacco products."
"That an appropriate form of proof‐of‐age identification be automatically required for young people purchasing cigarettes."

The Commonwealth is already undertaking substantial work in relation to national tobacco and drug education and support programs for teachers and students through the National Initiatives in Drug Education program.
School regulations and minimum ages for purchasing are within the jurisdiction of State and Territory Governments.

BREAK.PARA: The National Initiatives in Drug Education (NIDE) project is a two year, $3.2 million Commonwealth endeavour funded through the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund. The project promotes collaboration between the Commonwealth, States and Territories, and involves health, education and police officials, as well as parents, students and drug education agencies.
NIDE has produced a range of initiatives, including the following:
. Healthy Lifestyles CD ROM: An interactive multi‐media education initiative, due to be distributed to primary schools in March 1997. This CD ROM will include tobacco‐related information;

. Professional Development: Commonwealth Funding to States and Territories. These funds have been used to train teachers in drug education, and to develop educational resources. Tobacco‐related health risks are addressed by this initiative; and
. Pre‐service Training: proposed Commonwealth Funding to Universities to train future health professionals in drug‐related issues.
NIDE also provides the policy framework and benchmarks for additional education initiatives involving either direct Commonwealth action, or Commonwealth funding for State and Territory activities.

In addition, the Commonwealth is in the process of establishing a new funding arrangement with States and Territories in the form of Public Health Partnerships. It is anticipated that these partnerships, together with more subject‐specific public health agreements, will provide a framework for addressing the provision of Federal funding for State and Territory‐based public health initiatives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That additional research be undertaken into the efficacy of generic packaging of tobacco products as a means of addressing the problem of juvenile smoking".

The Commonwealth is addressing the issues of youth smoking through a sustained multi‐faceted approach, which includes health warnings on packaging to improve consumer, including youth, knowledge of the health effects of tobacco consumption. The Common wealth will commission further investigation of the efficacy of generic packaging as a means of enhancing the impact of package warnings.

BREAK.PARA: Between 1991 and 1994, while consideration was being given by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy (MCDS) to the issue of health warnings and tobacco labelling, the issue of generic packaging was raised. In its final report in 1992, the MCDS taskforce on tobacco stated that the recommendations of the Centre for Behavioural Research in Cancer on packaging and labelling of tobacco products be adopted, including:
. the introduction of strengthened health warnings, explanation of these health warnings, and contents information; and
. the introduction of standard packaging for all tobacco products with specified package composition, colour, finish, print font and point size.

A decision was made in 1993 by MCDS that, rather than pursuing the issue of generic packaging, Governments would use a wide range of strategies to focus public attention on the health effects of smoking, including strengthened health warnings on tobacco products. A national system of strengthened health warnings was subsequently introduced in 1994 by the Commonwealth under the Trade Practices (Consumer Product Information Standards) Tobacco Regulations.

A number of health groups have recently called for the introduction of generic packaging for tobacco products in both submissions to the Commonwealth and to the Senate Inquiry on the Tobacco Industry and the Costs of Tobacco‐Related Illness.

In response to the mounting interest in generic packaging, the Commonwealth obtained advice from the Attorney General's Department on the legal and constitutional barriers to generic packaging. This advice indicates that the Commonwealth does possess powers under the Constitution to introduce such packaging but that any attempt to use these powers to introduce further tobacco control legislation needs to be considered in the context of the increasingly critical attention being focussed on the necessity, appropriateness, justification and basis for regulation by such bodies as the Office of Regulatory Review, the High Court, and Senate Standing Committees. In addition, further regulation needs to be considered in the context of Australia's international obligations regarding free trade under the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade (GATT), and our obligations under international covenants such as the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property, and the Agreement on Trade‐Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS).

To date, generic packaging of tobacco products has not been implemented anywhere in the world. As such, there is no international experience of the effect of generic packaging on consumer behaviour. In addition, there is limited primary research on the potential effect of generic packaging on the factors underlying or relevant to the uptake and cessation of tobacco consumption.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Senate Committee received a number of submissions from health groups which suggested that point of sale advertising may be one of the contributors to high youth smoking rates. With a view to combatting youth smoking, the Committee recommended the following:

"That comprehensive restrictions on the size, placement and format of point‐of‐sale advertising of tobacco products, similar to those applying in New South Wales, be applied in all States and Territories."

The Commonwealth is currently examining the possible tightening of point of sale advertising in those jurisdictions where Commonwealth point of sale provisions apply—namely, Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. The Commonwealth is also prepared to undertake a leadership role in coordinating State and Territory activities involving point‐of‐sale restrictions.

BREAK.PARA: The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act) bans most forms of advertising. However the legislation currently permits, among other things, point‐of‐sale advertising (Section 16).
In summary, the regulations under Section 16 provide that a tobacco advertisement must:
. be within the boundaries of a shop; and
. not be affixed to the outside wall, window or door of the shop; and
. if placed on a window, face the inside of the shop.

Currently Commonwealth legislation permits point of sale advertising where there is a State or Territory law dealing with such advertising and that law permits the advertising. In Queensland and the Northern Territory, where no State or Territory legislation exists, Section 16 (2) allows for point of sale advertising, subject to regulations made under the Act.

The New South Wales and Western Australian Governments have both enacted point of sale advertising legislation which is more stringent than the Commonwealth's regulations, with regulations limiting the size of the advertisements and requiring the display of a health warning. Legislation in Victoria and South Australia, however, is much less restrictive and as in Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory, point‐of‐sale advertising in these jurisdictions appears to have become much more prominent since other forms of advertising have been banned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: As part of its report on the Tobacco Industry and the Costs of Tobacco‐Related Illness, the Senate Committee made the following recommendations:
"That there be a reduction in the number of retail outlets permitted to sell tobacco products and that:

EMPHASIS.TAB: as an interim measure, tobacco products be isolated from other products for sale in all outlets currently selling tobacco products; and

in the longer term, those retail outlets permitted to sell tobacco products be restricted to licensed premises and tobacconists; and that this be phased in to minimise any disruption to small business."

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That the licensing systems in all States and Territories provide for the suspension or revocation of a license where retail outlets sell tobacco products to minors."
"That State and Territory Governments, in co‐operation with the appropriate retail trade associations, expand their education programs directed at retailers."

"That State, Territory and Local Government increase the level of funding and personnel devoted to the enforcement of laws restricting the supply of tobacco products to minors; and that increased resources be devoted to the prosecution of retailers that contravene such laws."
"That State and Territory Governments institute routine systems of random compliance checks to monitor the sale of tobacco products to minors."
"That the Commonwealth Government encourage the States and Territories to improve the effectiveness of their enforcement and monitoring programs; and that:

. as part of their monitoring system the States and Territories provide statistics annually to the Commonwealth on the number of complaints and prosecutions against retailers selling cigarettes to minors; and
. the States and Territories run a publicity campaign that informs the public of the appropriate bodies to which they can direct complaints regarding the sale of tobacco products to minors."
"That a system of substantial fines be introduced in all States and Territories to discourage the sale of tobacco products to minors."

The Government does not endorse recommendation 25. The imposition of a further regulatory burden on small businesses at this time runs counter to the Government's establishment of a Small Business Deregulation Task Force—a body constituted for the specific purpose of reducing the high level of compliance costs imposed by government.
Recommendations 26, 27, 29, 30 and 32 are not relevant to the Commonwealth's responsibilities. The Government does, however, support these recommendations in principle.

The Government fully endorses recommendation 31. The Commonwealth is prepared to assume a leadership role in this regard by coordinating State and Territory activities, establishing best‐practice models and acting as a clearing house for research relevant to State and Territory health officials. Monitoring of progress on enforcement of sales to minors regulation in each state and territory could be an important component of the new Public Health Partnerships.

BREAK.PARA: The Senate Committee indicated that licensing in the States and Territories had thus far been poorly administered, and was primarily a revenue‐raising function rather than a component of an integrated health strategy.

The Philip Morris tobacco company responded to recommendation 25 by circulating a letter to retailers, informing them of the substance of this recommendation and urging them to lobby their elected officials. This resulted in expressions of considerable concern from small‐business owners.

The Commonwealth does not regulate the licensing of businesses. All States and Territories require licences for either tobacco retailers or wholesalers. In New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, there are provisions for the suspension of licenses to retailers.
Business licensing is a State and Territory Government responsibility.

At a National Tobacco Sales to Minors Conference held in Sydney in August 1996, New South Wales health officials outlined their comprehensive sales to minors strategy. The response to this model from health officials from other states and territories was enthusiastic, and assent was given to the idea that the Commonwealth should establish best practice models for addressing tobacco retail issues. The Commonwealth will seek to develop this leadership role through the National Tobacco Strategy, which is currently being developed through the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Senate Committee made the following recommendation:
"That tobacco products be removed from the basket of goods used in the calculation of the Consumer Price Index."

The Australian Bureau of Statistics has consistently adopted the policy that moral or social decisions should not skew or distort data. As tobacco is still a significant item of expenditure in at least one in five Australian households, removing it from the basket of goods would be contrary to the principles governing the composition of the CPI.

BREAK.PARA: Several health groups, including the Australian Cancer Society and the National Heart Foundation have argued that tobacco should be removed from the basket of goods used in the calculation of the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

The argument is that removing tobacco from the CPI would provide an incentive for governments to raise excise, unlike the current arrangements where an increase in the retail price of cigarettes is reflected in the CPI and, consequently, in the inflation rate.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics has, for some years, published a consumer price index which excludes changes in the price of alcoholic beverages and tobacco. The Anti‐Cancer Council of Victoria has recently proposed that this index be used for the determination of wage, pension and benefit increases. It is argued that this would have the same effect as excluding tobacco from the CPI, without distorting the integrity of the basic index as an economic indicator.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Senate Committee made the following recommendations:
"That the distribution of non tobacco‐related products associated with the sale of tobacco products be prohibited."
The Commonwealth is currently considering the possibility of regulating the distribution of such products in the states and territories that do not have existing legislation.

BREAK.PARA: Health groups have expressed concern about certain promotional activities being conducted by tobacco companies, in particular the use of giveaways with the sale of tobacco products.

Legislation prohibiting the distribution of non‐tobacco products with the sale of tobacco products already exists in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia. Therefore this issue is restricted to those states and territories without applicable legislation, namely, Queensland, Tasmania, Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory.

Examples of giveaways that were cited to the Senate Committee included cricket calenders, t‐shirts, lighters, key rings and caps. It has been argued that many of these items have appeal to young people and would contribute to their decision to take up or continue to smoke.

In addition to concerns relating to children and adolescents the Senate Committee were also presented evidence of promotional activities being undertaken amongst Aboriginal communities in Northern Territory.

Tobacco companies have dismissed claims that promotions are aimed at adolescents. Philip Morris have argued that giveaways are a market ing tool targeted at existing tobacco consumers and designed to "reinforce our consumers' brand loyalty, and to attract smokers of opposition products".

Further, it should be noted that the former Minister for Human Services and Health, the Hon Dr C. M. Lawrence MP, committed the Commonwealth to pursuing the issue of value‐added promotions following the June 1995 Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy meeting. Further to this commitment, the Federal Government has been seeking to obtain relevant research to inform future policy on this issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Senate Committee received a number of submissions from health groups which suggested that vending machines are a contributor to high youth smoking rates. With a view to combatting youth smoking, the Committee recommended the following:
"That, as it is virtually impossible to prevent access by children to cigarette vending machines, these types of vending machines be prohibited in all States and Territories."
The Commonwealth is currently considering this recommendation in the context of the range of strategies designed to reduce youth smoking rates.

BREAK.PARA: In Section 16 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act), vending machines dispensing tobacco products are considered to be a place where tobacco products are offered for sale to the public. As such, regulations made under the Act regarding point of sale advertising apply to vending machines. Under Regulation 8 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Regulations, a tobacco advertisement may be attached to a vending machine that contains tobacco products only if the advertisement does not extend beyond any of the extremities of the machine itself.

Commonwealth regulations governing vending machines have been made under the Act, and as such affect only advertisements which may appear on or near vending machines. The Commonwealth does not in any way restrict the placement of tobacco vending machines.

Most States have enacted some form of regulation over tobacco vending machines. In the ACT and South Australia, vending machines are restricted to licensed premises. In New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia, vending machines are limited to both licensed premises and staff amenities areas. In Tasmania they are restricted to areas supervised by an adult. In Queensland, only vending machines operated directly by tobacco companies are regulated; these machines are limited to licenses premises, staff amenities areas and areas supervised by an adult. The Northern Territory has no restrictions on the location of vending machines.

As the ACT and South Australian regulations regarding vending machines are the most restrictive, the Commonwealth is prepared to suggest that these serve as best‐practice models, and to promote their adoption by other states and territories in the context of the MCDS.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Aware of the high use of tobacco amongst certain social groups, and particularly Indigenous Australians, the Committee recommended the following:
"That strategies continue to be developed to address the special needs of `at risk' groups in the community, such as lower socio‐economic groups, to reduce the incidence of smoking in those groups".

"That funding continue to be allocated by the Commonwealth Government for the development of appropriate programs and strategies to address the problem of tobacco use for `at risk' groups in the community."

"That strategies, sensitive to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural values, be implemented to address the problem of tobacco use in Aboriginal and Islander communities, and that these strategies include:
close liaison with Aboriginal and Torres‐Strait Islander community‐based health organisations, especially the Aboriginal Health Services; and
the dissemination of culturally appropriate information on tobacco use throughout Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities."
"That further research be conducted to examine the problem of tobacco use by Aboriginal people in urban areas."

"That funding be provided by the Commonwealth Government for culturally appropriate programs and strategies to address the problem of tobacco use in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, as part of a broader health strategy."
"That strategies, sensitive to the cultural backgrounds and values of people from non‐English speaking backgrounds, be implemented to address the problem of tobacco use in these communities."
"That funding be provided by the Commonwealth Government for programs to address the problem of tobacco use amongst people from non‐English speaking backgrounds, including older people."

The Government remains committed to furthering the health of at‐risk groups within our society, in particular Indigenous peoples. Policy initiatives dealing with social target groups need to be informed by detailed research and close consultation with communities. As such, the Commonwealth will develop appropriate strategies for addressing the tobacco‐related health risks of Low Income, Non‐English Speaking and Indigenous communities.

BREAK.PARA: Both the National Health Policy on Tobacco and the Tobacco Harm Minimisation component of "Health Australia" were initiated to improve the health of all Australians by eliminating or reducing their exposure to tobacco in all its forms. Further to these goals, the Commonwealth is aiming to ensure that all groups receive accurate and culturally appropriate information, education and services about the health effects of tobacco use.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Indigenous Australians and Tobacco Use: Research

BREAK.PARA: Smoking amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is a major health problem, and further action is clearly needed to address this issue. Available research indicates that over half of all Indigenous Australians smoke—a figure twice that of the national average. This research also indicates that awareness of this problem is generally poor, with less than two‐thirds rating it as a serious problem among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

Further to the goal of promoting the Commonwealth as a coordinating body for health‐related research and best‐practice models, the Department of Health and Family Services will seek to assemble and disseminate appropriate research to those agencies best positioned to utilise such information to maximum effect. In addition, the Minister for Health and Family Services recently endorsed the establishment of a Substance Misuse Committee which will report to the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Council. This Committee is comprised of key stakeholders in the area of substance abuse amongst Indigenous Australian communities.

The Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group is also preparing to undertake a major education campaign targeting Indigenous Australians further to its larger National Tobacco Campaign. This campaign will be undertaken in the context of a national indigenous smoking strategy, which is to be developed under the auspices of the Ministerial Tobacco Advisory Group in conjunction with Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "That the Commonwealth Government investigate the implications of withdrawing tobacco from the list of duty‐free goods".

The Commonwealth has already investigated this proposal in responding to the 1993 review of the Australian Customs Service. There is currently little evidence that the elimination of the duty‐free status on tobacco products would have a direct health benefit. Moreover, given the likelihood of a negative impact on the tourism industry and other non‐health related areas, the Government does not support any withdrawal of the duty‐free status for tobacco products at this point.

BREAK.PARA: Health groups have expressed a belief that the current practice of granting duty‐free status to tobacco products for international travellers is inconsistent with the Commonwealth's overall tobacco harm minimisation strategy.

The purpose of duty‐free concessions is to facilitate the arrival of international travellers. Australia is a signatory to both the 1954 New York Convention and the 1968 OECD Convention. These deal with tourism and travelling, and include provision for minimum levels of concessions, including a tobacco products allowance.
The concessions enable the efficient processing of incoming travellers with duty free purchases within the specified limits, without the need to assess duty or sales tax.

The Australian Tourism Commission has advised that creating a welcoming environment at international airports is an important element in an overall tourism strategy. Implementing an assessment process for all passengers carrying tobacco products is therefore inconsistent with Government objectives of facilitating and encouraging tourism traffic.

Further, international travellers are increasingly aware of the duty free concessions in various destinations. While it is unlikely that the inability to purchase tobacco products duty free would directly affect potential visitors' perceptions of Australia as a destination, their level of satisfaction with shopping opportunities may be affected. This would particularly be so in the case of visitors from our important source markets in North Asia, where smoking is culturally acceptable.

The 1993 Report into the Review of the Australian Customs Service recommended that "in light of its general policy of discouraging the sale of tobacco products, the Commonwealth consider withdrawing tobacco products from the list of duty free goods". In its May 1994 response to this report, the Commonwealth concluded that no change to the tobacco duty free concession was warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the government's response to the Community Affairs References Committee report into the tobacco industry and the cost of tobacco related illness. To put it mildly, this is a very disappointing response. Indeed, it is a response for which we have now waited some 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly disappointing given recent developments in the United States. Just last week, tobacco companies agreed to pay the Florida state government $US11.3 billion in compensation, and the United States federal government is pursuing a national settlement of some $US368 billion. In the United States we have for the first time tobacco companies admitting that their product, when used as it is designed to be used, is harmful, is addictive and causes fatal illness.

They are not making these admissions out of the goodness of their hearts. They have done their sums. We have seen them for years cynically manipulating the truth about their products, but now they have decided that the writing is on the wall. Indeed, the writing on the wall is written so large that not even the tobacco companies can refuse to read it. They have worked out what it might cost them if they keep going through the litigation process and have decided that it would be cheaper for them to enter into arrangements with the state and federal governments. In the end, it will cost them a lot less to simply get it over and done with and agree to make the payments.

This is why some United States anti‐tobacco groups are saying that the industry is being let off too lightly. Even if this is the case, what is important is that these settlements have come about through governments having the courage to take on this industry and do the hard work, the hard slog, of going through the processes and actually starting to get back some of what it is costing the public, particularly in health costs. Some of the damage that is being done by these products is actually being recouped.

Why isn't the Australian government showing similar courage? We only have to look at the number of hospital beds available and the cost to Medicare to know that it is an enormous cost to us through our public health system. But, no, this government is not even prepared to take up the recommendations of the Senate committee. They do not involve it in any litigation. They do not involve it in any real hard decisions. But, no, it has decided that basically this is mostly for the too‐hard basket.

I think it is particularly important that governments such as the Australian government take a lead. We know what is happening in Asia and, if developed countries do not take a lead, it will be even more difficult for many of the Asian countries to stand up against the giant tobacco companies. We know that, as we gradually make it a little more difficult for sales to go ahead in this country, the tobacco companies focus more on Asia. They are putting their energy and their efforts into selling tobacco in developing nations.

BREAK.PARA: We also know that these countries are facing massive health costs as a consequence of the very strategic and deliberate push by tobacco companies into these new markets. Indeed, figures from just last week's anti-smoking conference in Beijing show us, for example, that one in four Chinese people smoke and that 500,000 people are now dying each year in China from tobacco related illnesses and that this is set to substantially increase.

Tobacco companies are using and indeed trying to increase their sponsorship of sporting events as a way of pushing their products into countries like China. Australia has a particular role to play because those events that we are exempting, those very events that we are letting have sponsorship, are being shown in China and in Asia. Surely, our role in that cannot be ignored. This is why the response from the government is so disappointing. I believe the government has missed a golden opportunity to get rid of tobacco sponsorship once and for all.

The government has also released today the much awaited Rassaby report. Again, it has been sitting on that for more than a year. The report was commissioned by the then health minister, Dr Carmen Lawrence, in 1995 to review section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act; that is, the section which allows exemptions to the ban on tobacco advertising for major cultural and sporting events.

The major finding of the Rassaby report is that section 18 be repealed, with the repeal taking effect from the year 2001. This is in line with recommendation No. 5 of the Senate committee report that section 18 be phased out—we said for the year 2000. As you can see, there is very little difference there.

But not even the two reports combined can sway this government. I would suggest that we have actually wasted our money commissioning the Rassaby report when it can be so easily put on the shelf and its recommendations put in the too‐hard basket. I believe the government has chosen to ignore the Rassaby report's conclusions that tobacco sponsorship of glamorous international sporting events is a powerful marketing tool which does have an impact on the smoking habits of Australians, especially adolescents. Surely we all understand now that it is during adolescence that a lot of the damage is done. These are the very people who are most at risk from the damage caused to one's health by smoking.

The Rassaby report also concluded that section 18 events have relatively small impact on the national economy. The report basically says that the national government, acting in the national interest, has an obligation to place the health of Australians ahead of the relatively small economic benefits generated by these events. Of course, we all know what happened. We all know that pressure has been applied by some state governments—and I can think of one in particular that is very keen on its grand prix. Really, what we have here is a political decision, not a health decision—a decision that is purely and pragmatically political and has nothing to do with the health of Australians, particularly young Australians.

The irony is that we could well lose many of these sporting events to Asia anyway. They have the potential to generate significantly larger audiences than we do and, also, many of those countries have very few, if any, restrictions on advertising. However, I wish to make it clear that there are several Asian countries doing a really good job, Thailand being one of them. Thailand now has some quite significant restrictions on advertising. So sporting events are quite likely to go offshore anyway and this government has missed a golden opportunity to stand up to the tobacco industry.

This particular failure is compounded by the government's refusal to take up another very crucial recommendation from the Senate committee report: the recommendation to establish a national health promotion foundation, funded through the money that the federal government collects by way of tobacco taxes. Through that we could provide an alternative form of sponsorship, particularly for some of those events that are not so well known, for some of those events that are relatively small in size in terms of the audience that they attract.

If the government cannot see its way to repealing or phasing out section 18 exemption, then surely the very least it should be doing is setting up an alternative source of funding and sponsorship. VicHealth—the Victorian government's version of such a foundation—has been extraordinarily successful. It was the first one of its kind in the world. It is an idea that has now been copied by other Australian states. I think some 22 countries have now adopted this. Even the World Bank has endorsed it as a significant and very much approved way of raising money for health programs. But, no, it has been put in the too‐hard basket by this federal government.

Maybe it is about time this government had another look at the whole issue of hypothecation of taxes that are collected, whether they be alcohol or tobacco taxes, to put some of that money back into harm minimisation and into those particular sports that have relied on tobacco sponsorship. It is all very well to talk about education campaigns, which I think is this government's only response to the problem of young people taking up tobacco, but there are a lot of much tougher and much more important decisions that this government is avoiding. We do not just need to look at legal drugs to see how weak this government's response is to the whole drug issue. The ACT heroin trial is yet another example of where this government likes to put any hard issues. I think this government is really at a crossroads. It is time for it to reassess its approach to drug use and abuse in this country generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a bit of disappointment that I rise to comment on the Government response to the report of the Senate Community Affairs Reference Committee: the tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco‐related illness . One very good reason is that this report was actually tabled out of session in December 1995. That is 21 months ago. It has taken this government 21 months to reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine months is bad, Senator, but in 21 months you could have had 2½ kids. It is not the sort of administration that we would expect. We have been asking in Senate estimates since the change of government: when can we expect this response? We kept being told, from June or July of last year, `Soon.' Two Christmases have come and gone—the Christmas of 1995 and the Christmas of 1996—and we are getting awfully close to the Christmas of 1997, before this government response has been tabled. I am very disappointed, because the government has had that length of time in which to do something about it—to make a decision and initiate some action.

SPEECH.PARA: All we seem to be hearing is, `We do not agree with what the committee is recommending,' or `The government will seek to do things in the future,' or `We will refer.' Nothing has happened. We asked at the estimates hearings in August what consultation there will be. We were told that a lot of the recommendations related to state and local government amendments, legislation and jurisdiction. We asked what consultations had taken place with the states about this. We were told that informal discussions at an officer level had taken place, not discussions from minister to minister. There had been no correspondence minister to minister, it would appear.

I find that most disappointing because this is a problem that does affect all three tiers of government and their administration and jurisdiction. It is also a major problem and I suppose I should admit up‐front and early on in my speech that I do have a nursing background and I have seen people suffer the ill effects of smoking. I am a widow because my husband was a smoker; he also had a family history of heart disease. The two do not go together. Yet we have seen people still try to argue that they are not convinced that smoking causes health problems. It is not, fortunately, argued in this document.

It is quite apparent when you travel in Asia that the tobacco companies are still operating in a laissez-faire type atmosphere. There is still lots of advertising and there is still a lot of promotion work done over there. Of course they are going to take a lot of their work over there and move there. I was in Nauru during the break for a CPA presiding officers confer ence. Alpine must be the most commonly smoked cigarette over there because there was lots of advertising—big billboard advertising—for Alpine of the sort that we do not see in Australia. There were clothes that had `Alpine' written on them. There were give‐aways and the accompanying paraphernalia that goes with smoking, all with `Alpine' on them. These are the sorts of things that have been outlawed in this country or are being worked on.

It is of major concern to people in this country, as Senator Lees said, just what activity is taking place in the Asia-Pacific region. We now know that China has started to do something about it. They are seeing alarming increases in the number of deaths from lung cancer. They attribute that to smoking. Having visited China, I can tell the Senate that smoking is a very common occurrence. If you go into a briefing or a meeting, two things happen: you will be offered green tea, which is lovely, but you will also be offered a cigarette. That was a couple of years ago. That sort of thing is all-pervasive. It gives an imprimatur of approval—that there are no problems with it and it is an acceptable thing to do.

It is with some concern and disappointment when I read through this response that I find that the government has not initiated a great deal. It says that it is going to do things in the future. It has already had 21 months. This government has had 18 months to do something about this and they have not done anything. I find it most concerning.

On page 13 of the response is recommendation 1 and recommendation 2, which recommends that smoking not be permitted in enclosed spaces, et cetera, including outdoor areas or places needing ventilation. It talks about some of the things that the Commonwealth has done. In 1996 cigarette smoking was banned on domestic air flights. This ban was made effective on all Australian carriers flying anywhere in the world and overseas carriers flying within Australia. But all the other years of activities that took place on this particular issue relate to the previous government.

BREAK.PARA: Recommendation 3 recommends that nicotine transdermal patches be listed in the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits but they be only prescribed as part of a structured smoking cessation program. The government does not endorse the recommendation at this time. It says that acting on this recommendation should be delayed pending outcomes of the review of cessation models and techniques. That is fine. It goes on to give the background about the number of attempts that have been made to get it on to the PBS, but none of them have been since March 1996.

Recommendation 4 talks about incidental and accidental broadcasting or publication of tobacco advertisements being strictly monitored and enforced by the department of health. The government is currently considering a scheme for the routine enforcement of the incidental and accidental provisions, and they will seek to acquire the data information necessary. That is fine. They have had 18 months. What have they been doing?

When we get to the background, we see that it goes back to 1973. Labor was in government then. It mentions 1990. Labor was in government then. It also mentions 1992 and 1993. They were all times when Labor was in government. It seems that the conservatives do not want to do a great deal about this particular issue. I am most concerned about this.

There was one issue that I felt very strongly about in the report. I am talking about the recommendation that there be a reduction in the number of retail outlets permitted to sell tobacco products and that, as an interim measure, tobacco products be isolated from other products for sale in outlets currently selling tobacco products. In the longer term we were suggesting that they move towards restricted licensed premises and tobacconists. There are a number of others as well.

The government did not endorse recommendation 25 or any part of it. It was concerned that the imposition of a further regulatory burden on small businesses at this time runs counter to the government's establishment of the small business deregulation task force. It is a pity that they could not implement some of the recommendations out of the Reid committee report in the other place about small business.

My concern about nothing being done about this particular recommendation is, as I have said before and will continue to say, because I have grave concerns when I walk into places such as newsagents. They can have the gambling area—the lotto area and the lottery buying areas—down the back, separated off from the mainstream of their activities. That is not a problem. But they can have their tobacco products up with the lollies, the swap cards and all those sorts of things that appeal to children and to young adolescents and teenagers.

I have a great problem with the juxtapositioning of tobacco products with the products that appeal to younger people and to adolescents and children. I have had discussions with the merchants who say that they have no problem and they can see no conflicts with the juxtapositioning of them next door to one another. The government has totally disregarded this. It is not even going to look at some of the reasons behind it. I am most concerned. As I have said on other occasions, I know of shops where they are selling tobacco products on one side and on the other side they are selling ice-creams. I have a real problem with that. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the Economics References Committee report on outworkers in the garment industry. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT FROM THE SENATE ECONOMICS REFERENCES COMMITTEE ON OUTWORKING IN THE GARMENT INDUSTRY

SPEECH.PARA: The Government response to the report from the Senate Economics References Committee on Outworkers in the Garment Industry of December 1996 is provided in two parts. The first part responds to the report's recommendations and the second part comments on the conclusions drawn by the Committee in the report.
The recommendations and conclusions are numbered in accordance with their order in the Executive Summary of the report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government examine ways to clarify the employment status of outworkers in the garment industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. Clarification of the employment status of outworkers in the garment industry is complicated by constitutional limitations on the Commonwealth. In particular, the Commonwealth's constitutional power to legislate with respect to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State is inherently limited to matters pertaining to employees.

In legislating to limit the scope of an industrial dispute to allowable award matters under S89A(2) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (the Act), the Government has included the pay and conditions of outworkers as an allowable award matter, but only to the extent necessary to ensure that their overall pay and conditions of employment are fair and reasonable in comparison with the pay and conditions specified in a relevant award or awards for employees who perform the same kind of work at an employer's business premises. S89A(9) of the Act defines an "outworker" as an "employee, who for the purposes of the business of the employer, performs work at private residential premises or at other premises that are not business or commercial premises of the employer".

Notwithstanding the Victorian Government's referral of some industrial relations matters to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth has no greater power to legislate with respect to non‐employee outworkers in Victoria than it does with respect to such outworkers in other States. The specific matters referred by the Victorian Parliament are all, except for the matter of freedom of association, expressed in terms which relate to employees only.

Any Commonwealth legislation seeking to alter the employment status of persons who might otherwise (at common law) not be employees would need to depend on constitutional powers other than the industrial dispute power, such as the Commonwealth's power to legislate with respect to corporations, and would be limited in its scope accordingly.
As a result of these limitations, issues related to the clarification of employment status need to be considered in a co‐ordinated way by both Commonwealth and State governments.

There is already some legislation at state level which addresses this issue. Under industrial relations legislation enacted in both New South Wales and South Australia certain workers, including outworkers in the clothing industry, are deemed to be employees.

The progression of this issue needs to be handled carefully so as not to constrain flexible working arrangements in the garment industry. In particular, some workers in the garment industry do not wish to work as employees. Contractual, sub‐contractual and other arrangements can provide appropriate options for these workers.
The Commonwealth Government undertakes to bring the issue of clarification of the employment status of outworkers to the attention of relevant State Ministers through correspondence.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government consider reinstating an amnesty for outworkers for a period to allow community groups sufficient time to communicate with outworkers and to persuade them of its benefits. The Committee further recommends that funding from the TCF 2000 Development Package be made available for community groups to inform outworkers of the amnesty.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed. The Government does not believe that a reinstatement of the social security limited amnesty would be a viable or productive proposition. The rationale for an amnesty was that people be given a chance to comply with relevant laws prior to a new form of data‐matching being introduced. Data‐matching by the Department of Social Security commenced immediately following the end of the amnesty period, and has been underway since that time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government consider extending the cut‐off date for prior employment of the Labour Adjustment Program to a date in the future to be determined in consultation with the Union.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed. From 1993‐94 the Textile Clothing and Footwear Labour Adjustment Package (TCF LAP) take‐up rates were declining. A sunset clause relating to all the Labour Adjustment Programs (LAPs), introduced by the former Government from 1 July 1994, meant that anyone joining LAP‐designated industries after that date and subsequent ly being retrenched, was not eligible for assistance under the LAPs, including TCF LAP.

The Government determined, as part of its 1996 budget decisions, that the TCF LAP would be discontinued. Although the program ceased on 31 August 1996, there are a small number of clients being assisted under the program in 1997, as they were approved for that form of assistance prior to the 1996 Budget.

The various LAPs were industry based programs and retrenchment from a LAP‐designated industry automatically entitled a person to assistance under the program, regardless of need. Those retrenched from non‐LAP industries, including industries that were also restructuring, were not entitled to the generous assistance under the LAPs.

Persons retrenched from the TCF industry are able to seek assistance through the Commonwealth Employment Service. All jobseekers will be eligible immediately for assistance to overcome minor barriers to employment, for example through the provision of fares and job search assistance. Basic English, literacy and numeracy training will also be available for those who need it. Jobseekers who are at high risk of becoming long term unemployed and who are being case managed will be eligible for almost all labour market programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends to the Government that in evaluating proposals for expenditure from the TCF 2000 Development Package, consideration be given to the need for outworker projects similar to those carried out recently by the Union.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The TCF 2000 Development Package is a combination of enterprise improvement and industry infrastructure programs which aim to improve the competitiveness of TCF industries as the phasedown of tariffs continues until the year 2000. Post year 2000 arrangements are currently being considered by the Productivity Commission. Proposals for funding will be assessed against published criteria, while taking account of the desirability of supporting projects which demonstrate a variety of TCF activities.

The Government is mindful of the desirability of a demonstration project that encompasses outworker and sub‐contracting issues and will consider any such proposals against the program criteria. The Government has indicated that it would support an education project that assists the implementation of an industry Code of Practice that enjoys broad support. The Government believes that this would provide scope for a more effective project than one carried out by a single element of the industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends to all government agencies involved in clothing procurement that they consider whether outworkers are used in the manufacture of that clothing and, if so, whether they are able to enter into Deeds of Cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. Commonwealth buyers are required to use `best practice' in their purchasing, which includes doing business only with suppliers who comply with the law and relevant Commonwealth policies, including environmental, trade practices, social justice and workplace relations policies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that an industry `Homeworkers Code of Practice' should be adopted by all participants in the garment retailing and manufacturing process. The Committee regrets that further progress has not been made towards establishing a voluntary Code and undertakes to review progress towards voluntary regulation in a further 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The Government supports codes of practice, freely entered into by industry parties, as a means of reinforcing industry standards. Where appropriate, the Government will assist industry parties in developing and implementing codes of practice. The Government has indicated that it would be prepared to support an education project to assist the implementation of an outworker code of practice if industry wide agreement is reached.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends to the garment industry that it voluntarily adopt an agreed label declaring that the employment conditions under which the garment was made complied with legislative requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. As stated above, the Government supports voluntary industry agreements which aim at improving adherence to minimum standards.

The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the concept of a National Outwork Committee which would have responsibility, inter alia , for the initiation and allocation of funding for projects relating to outwork.

Noted. The Government has appointed a new TCF Advisory Board to provide industry based advice on a review of the TCF industries by the Productivity Commission. The terms of reference of the Productivity Commission's review include improving workplace practices.

The Government believes that there is merit in the parties themselves establishing consultative fora to develop initiatives to deal with issues of particular concern to the industry. This approach is consistent with the Government's view that the primary responsibility for improving workplace relations lies with the industry parties themselves.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Bureau of Statistics conduct a comprehensive survey of the number of home‐based workers across all industries. The ABS should carry out this survey in conjunction with the ATO and information gained from the Reportable Payments System on the number of outworkers.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part. The ABS periodically conducts a supplementary survey, Persons Employed At Home , as part of the Monthly Population Survey (MPS). The supplementary survey provides a reliable measure of the number and characteristics of persons employed at home in Australia by industry. This survey was last conducted in September 1995, and is next scheduled to be conducted in July 1999.

The measurement of the number of home‐based workers is somewhat problematical. The ABS survey defines persons employed at home as those who worked more hours at home than elsewhere in either their main or second job. Those who worked only some hours at home or who worked in someone else's home were excluded. Problems associated with measuring the number of outworkers in the Persons Employed At Home survey include the fact that the outworkers may be working in another person's home, outworkers may be concentrated in certain geographic areas and therefore not representatively sampled, and outworkers may not be willing or able to provide accurate answers to survey questions.

The ABS endeavours to respond to the needs of the users of ABS data, and regularly reviews the design of supplementary surveys. Development work for the July 1999 Persons Employed At Home survey will commence at the end of 1997, and is planned to address the problems associated with the measurement of outworkers outlined above, to the extent that is possible.

While, in principle, the Government has no objection to the ATO liaising with the ABS in order to accurately measure the number of outworkers, the Government is conscious of community concern about the transfer of information collected by the ABS to other government agencies such as the ATO. Despite legislative protections and the assurances the ABS gives regarding the protection of confidentiality, association between the ABS and agencies such as the ATO could impact on the high level of cooperation currently experienced across all ABS statistical collections.

The Government also notes that there are practical difficulties involved in the use of ATO information in the context of ABS surveys. The Reportable Payments System (RPS), which does not require an assessment of a worker's classification as an `outworker' or otherwise, is unlikely to provide further clarification of the numbers of outworkers involved in the garment industry.

The Government therefore considers that, on balance, the use of ATO information by the ABS is unlikely to provide a positive contribution to the overall levels of information regarding outworkers or other areas of home based processing.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government review federally funded arrangements for English language education with a view to increasing accessibility for migrants involved in outwork.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. As outworkers are predominantly overseas born with limited English language skills, usually work alone and are socially and industrially isolated, they present challenges for the delivery of Government training programs. It has been established that 95% of outworkers fall within the target group for the Workplace English Language Literacy (WELL) Program.

The WELL Program has encouraged projects to be developed addressing the particular issues relating to outworkers. There are currently four WELL Program projects being funded from 1996 and one in 1997 targeting outworkers. These projects are in NSW, Victoria and SA and are being managed by:
. Textile Clothing and Footwear Union (TCFUA) NSW;
. Textile Clothing and Footwear Union (TCFUA) Victoria;
. Linda Wyse and Associates; and
. Adelaide Workplace Education Service.

The TCFUA (NSW) has delivered a pilot Language Literacy and Numeracy training program based at the Cabramatta Community Centre, through the TCF Homeworker and Education and Learning Program. Twelve outworkers with little or no English speaking skills and beginner literacy levels were offered training by the Granville TAFE. Outcomes relate to improved awareness of Occupational Health and Safety, recording output, reporting problems with work and enhancing communication with employers. This project ran until mid 1997.

The TCFUA (Vic) received WELL funding in 1995 for resource development and to deliver language, literacy and numeracy training. The project from 1996 provided language and numeracy training to 48 outworkers in the areas of Springvale, St Albans and Sunshine/Footscray.

The Adult Migrant English Service (AMES) provided the training, which is directly linked to the National Clothing Production Certificate. Three courses were offered, each for a duration of 3 hours per week for 30 weeks.

The Lynda Wise and Associates project delivered language and literacy training to outworkers by flexible delivery modes. This project was expanded to include supervisors of outworkers at a factory in Melbourne's Western suburbs. It is anticipated that this training will precipitate a flow‐on effect to target more outworkers. A major success of this project has been entry into the factory marketplace where outworkers are working both inside and outside. The training was developed mainly around the Clothing Production Certificate with some workers concentrating on adaptations of modules from the certificates in Workplace Education.

The Adelaide Workplace Education Service (WES) project has recently been funded in 1997 following a previous project for outworkers in 1996. The previous project set out to establish networks of outworkers and initiate training either in groups or one to one. Based on these experiences strategies have been developed to address the difficulties in targeting outworkers. These strategies will be employed in the 1997 project.

There are difficulties in delivering training to outworkers which are not necessarily experienced in a factory situation. The various projects which have received WELL funding have tackled these difficulties with varying degrees of success.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government review educational arrangements in TCF industries for industrial relations and small business management.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The Commonwealth Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business delivers information and education services relating to industrial relations. These services are reviewed periodically in order to target particular groups and industries. In 1997 the Department delivered a program of approximately 170 seminars across Australia which focused on the obligations of employers under the Workplace Relations Act 1996.
An additional consideration in delivery of information and education services is the Government's pursuit of closer cooperative arrangements with State governments on industrial relations matters.
This is particularly relevant for the garment industry, where, apart from in Victoria and the Territor ies, most outworkers fall within the coverage of the State industrial relations jurisdiction.

Co‐operative arrangements with State government agencies will involve the joint delivery of information services and the dual authorisation of awards inspectors. Discussions have commenced with State governments to jointly develop compliance projects in sectors such as the garment industry where there are high levels of outsourcing.

The Commonwealth Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business is currently developing a compliance program for Victoria, following the referral of industrial relations powers by the Victorian Government to the Commonwealth. The particular circumstances of the garment industry will be taken into account in determining future targeted compliance activities.

One of the functions of the Employment Advocate under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 is to provide advice and assistance to both employers and employees on Australian Workplace Agreements, freedom of association and the Workplace Relations Act 1996 more generally. In fulfilling this function, the Employment Advocate has a particular obligation to provide advice and assistance to small business, and promote better work and management practices through Australian Workplace Agreements. In performing his functions, the Employment Advocate must have particular regard to the needs of workers who may be in a disadvantaged bargaining position, with the legislation specifically mentioning outworkers as an example.

The Government notes that the scope for improving workplace practices and the adequacy of the research and educational infrastructure in providing management skills are included in the terms of reference for the current Productivity Commission inquiry into the TCF industries. The Productivity Commission is scheduled to present its final report in September 1997.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee endorses the recommendations made by Worksafe Australia that:
. TCF industry parties continue and extend the steps already taken to work co‐operatively in order to improve the OHS performance of their industry;
. retailers and contractors in the TCF industry continue and extend the co‐operative establishment of agreed minimum standards covering the conditions applied to outworking;
. the TCF Development Authority give consideration to incorporating OHS criteria when determining funding for restructuring and training under the TCF 2000 Development Package; and

. the TCF Development Authority consider allocating funds under the Authority's Best Practice program . . . to develop . . . a framework in which to achieve improvements in workplace control over hazards and more appropriate contractual arrangements with outworkers.

SPEECH.PARA: In implementing its work program for 1997‐98 the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Worksafe Australia) is focusing on ways in which it could provide assistance to small businesses, including those in the TCF industry, to improve OHS outcomes.
The Government supports co‐operative voluntary efforts by retailers and contractors to maintain industry standards, including minimum standards relating to the employment of outworkers.

The TCF Development Authority was abolished in February 1996 at the expiry of its legislation. Any remaining activities have been transferred to the TCF Branch of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism.

The TCF 2000 Development Package is a combination of enterprise improvement and industry infrastructure programs which aim to improve the competitiveness of the TCF industries as the phasedown of tariffs continues until the year 2000. The best practice program, as an element of the package, is a competitive grants program aimed at identifying TCF firms that can act as role models to the rest of industry. Proposals for funding will be assessed against published criteria, while taking account of the desirability of supporting projects which demonstrate a variety of TCF activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that the situation endured by exploited children will only be ameliorated through an improvement in the employment conditions experienced by their parents. Having regard to Australia's international and national obligations to protect children from exploitation, the Committee suggests that Government consideration of this matter is warranted.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's major treaty obligation in relation to exploitation of children is Article 32 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) , which came into force for Australia in 1991 after ratification in 1990. Article 32 provides:

1. State Parties recognise the right of the child to be protected from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child's education, or to be harmful to the child's health or physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development .

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2. State Parties shall take legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to ensure the implementation of the present Article. To this end, and having regard to the relevant provisions of other international instruments, State Parties shall in particular
(a) provide for a minimum age or ages for admission to employment;
(b) provide for appropriate regulation of the hours and conditions of employment; and
(c)provide for appropriate penalties or other sanctions to ensure the effective enforcement of the present Article.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia fulfils this obligation by means of Commonwealth and State legislation addressing occupational health and safety matters, minimum school leaving ages, restrictions on child employment and employment of children in particular work. Industrial tribunals deal with wage rates.
More detail is spelt out in Australia's first report on the implementation of the CRC, which was tabled in Parliament in December 1995.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) has two current international labour standards which are relevant to child labour. They are Convention 29, Forced Labour, 1930 and Convention 138, Minimum Age, 1973 . Australia has ratified Convention 29, which addresses one of the worst forms of child labour, ie forced labour, and is not relevant to the current matter. Australia has not ratified Convention 138, which requires a statutory minimum age for employment of 15 years. Children aged 13 to 15 years may undertake "light work" under defined conditions, but employment of children aged under 13 years is prohibited (with the exception of artistic and similar performances).

In recognition of the limitations resulting from the prescriptive nature of Convention 138, the ILO has placed "child labour" on the agenda of its annual Conference in 1998 and 1999, with a view to adopting new international labour standards on the elimination of exploitative child labour in 1999. Australia will be taking an active role in the formulation of these new standards.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee concludes that enforcement by government agencies of compliance with award wages and conditions has declined considerably in recent years, being more reactive than proactive, and that this in itself has contributed to an increase in the level of non‐compliance.

SPEECH.PARA: As stated above, apart from in Victoria and the Territories, most outworkers fall within the coverage of the state industrial relations jurisdiction.
In general, government agencies take a balanced approach to compliance activities which involves
. resolving individual complaints through free and confidential advisory and investigation services—these services include, where appropriate, taking enforcement action in courts and tribunals; and

. conducting general and targeted information and educational activities aimed at improving the understanding by both employers and employees of their rights and obligations under legislation and awards.

The approach taken is regarded to be an efficient and effective use of government resources. There is no evidence to support that this approach contributes to non‐compliance with minimum standards in the garment industry.

The Government notes the acknowledgment by the Committee that there is some unwillingness on the part of outworkers to report non‐compliance and have government agencies involved in the circumstances of their employment. In undertaking compliance activities government agencies are conscious of the privacy concerns when people are performing work in their own homes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee strongly believes that the Australian Taxation Office could take greater advantage of the Reportable Payments System to fully investigate taxation avoidance in TCF industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government introduced the Reportable Payments System to redress non‐compliance in specific industries where there was evidence of significant tax evasion. The Australian Taxation Office will continue to make full use of Reportable Payments System information in its efforts to lift compliance levels in the clothing industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee will review the Government's position in relation to the ILO Convention on Home Work in 12 months time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee may be interested to note that the Government has certain obligations, in accordance with Article 19 of the ILO Constitution, concerning ILO Convention 177 and Recommendation 184 on Homework which were adopted by the International Labour Conference in June 1996. These obligations include the tabling of the texts of the two instruments in the Australian Parliament, together with a report on action proposed to be taken in relation to the two instruments. Australia is then required to report to the ILO that it has brought the instruments to the attention of the competent authority. As a federal State, Australia has until December 1997 to fulfil these obligations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that because a multifaceted approach is needed to eliminate exploitation of outworkers in the garment industry, the Government should move quickly to allocate funding identified in the TCF 2000 Development Package specifically for projects relating to outworkers, including those recommendations given above.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. Refer also to the response to Recommendations 4 and 6.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee undertakes to review in 12 months time outworking in the garment industry, with particular reference to the recommendations contained in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to this response I was, up until just after question time today, going to try to at least make one positive statement in relation to the response, and that was that it had finally been tabled nine months after we had reported in December last year. But, as Senator West has pointed out, some other reports take far longer. Senator Woodley's personal explanation cautioned me and I will concentrate on just the critique of the response to the report which I think is substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), in this response on behalf of the government, fails the TCF industry outworkers. The response to the committee's report is totally inadequate. The Economics References Committee produced a bipartisan report. The committee was originally chaired by Senator Ferguson in its inquiry. When we changed government, I took over as chair. But we maintained that bipartisan response in dealing with this very substantial issue, that being the exploitation of outworkers in the TCF industry. The bipartisan nature of this response—I should say tripartisan; sorry, Senator Murray—is perhaps most disappointing because of that context.

The committee put forward 11 recommendations to address the exploitation of outworkers within the TCF industry. The committee had received reports of serious cases of exploitation of workers, with incidents of wage rates of $2 per hour, verbal and physical abuse of workers, substandard working conditions, bribes, coercion and blackmail. But the government's response on an assessment of it as a whole is contemptuous of the work put in by all of the committee members across all of the parties. More importantly, it is contemptuous of the TCF industry outworkers. I can only hope, but I suspect I am wrong, that it is not a signpost of how this government is going to respond to the Productivity Commission's report with respect to the TCF industry and tariff reductions.

In particular, in looking at the government's response, I would like to highlight three main points where I think this response fails the committee, the industry, us all. Firstly, it fails to acknowledge that outworkers are being exploited. It fails to acknowledge just that basic point that this committee highlighted. However, it does—and I think in particular form for Minister Reith—highlight the desire not to constrain flexible working arrangements. So we can concentrate on that issue but not even acknowledge the several examples of exploitation that this committee found.

The response also fails to accept the urgent need for ongoing labour assistance programs. In the context of an overall industry debate, where even mainstream commentators accept the need for adjustment programs to deal with tariff reductions, and in this industry of all industries at this point in time, the government fails to acknowledge that need despite the recommendations of the committee.

The response also, most importantly, because it is also a signpost of a number of other issues, fails to acknowledge the important recent agreement between the Australian Retailers Association and the TCFUA, the union, to eliminate exploitation of outworkers in the apparel industry. It even fails to acknowledge that that agreement has occurred—that significant agreement in dealing with this problem, significant in terms of bringing the industry together to deal with that problem, significant in that this report concentrated significantly on that issue, and the minister fails to even mention it.

By contrast, Labor sees the resolution of outworker exploitation as fundamental to the future assistance arrangements for this industry. That is why this report is seen as a signpost with respect to how this government may deal with the TCF industry and tariff reduction. Labor has been working with key industry parties to achieve joint industry arrangements to deal with the outworker problem. Substantial progress has been made, as shown by the recent breakthrough with the Australian Retailers Association. As a consequence of this agreement, Labor believes that the funds should be allocated immediately to implement the code of practice—as the government has been foreshadowing for some time, but the government does not even seem to know that this agreement exists. Funds had originally been taken off the union and the government has been advising us for some time that it is prepared to look at allocating funds if the industry can come to some form of agreement. The agreement is there, but it is not even referred to in this response to the report.

This inadequate response comes as the government has slashed around $20 million of assistance per annum to the industry, with up to $3.8 million of the $7.8 million assistance package for the TCF industry not spent in the last financial year. Additionally, the government slashed over $15 million in funding to labour assistance programs in the TCF industry in the last financial year. The government has failed to address the substantial issues that were raised in this report and has demonstrated quite clearly in this report—and I hope it is not a signpost of what might arise in the next few weeks—that it has abandoned TCF industry outworkers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion. It is two years since former Senator Sid Spindler of the Australian Democrats referred the outworker matter to the Economics References Committee for inquiry.
