He did so because—despite the closeness of the Labor government of the day, which at that stage was 12‐years‐old, with the union movement—the outworker community had not been properly attended to in the structure of government policy and government expenditure. He recognised and was able to persuade both the coalition, then in opposition, and the Labor Party of the need for an inquiry. It was, as Senator Jacinta Collins has rightly said, conducted in a truly cross‐party basis. The senators and the secretariat worked very hard to produce what was in the end a good report. When Senator Spindler remarked on his Economics References Committee term of reference on the outworkers, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are rightly disgusted with child exploitation and slave labour conditions in other countries. However, here in our own backyard we are tolerating the exploitation of home workers, mainly women, mainly migrants, and, one suspects, also children in conditions which we have fought for decades to eliminate from Australia.

Senator Spindler and the Senate itself do not believe that Australian workers of any kind should not be given a fair go, should not be accorded the proper working conditions and the proper safeguards both from the Australian community's point of view and from the point of view of Australian law. He remarked that there were persistent reports of damage to health, of injuries, of long hours, of poor conditions and particularly of low pay. He said it is time that we as a society got to the bottom of what is happening. It is our belief that the committee did do that. By and large they reached a far better understanding than we have ever had before of the nature and conditions of those workers.

We move on two years later to wanting the government to get to a situation where it can advance the cause of outworkers appropriately. It has properly and rightly indicated that outworker matters, particularly those relating to children, are being pursued with increasing interest and force on the international arena. It is slow, but progress is being made. But within our own country we can afford to make far more rapid progress.

BREAK.PARA: It was the Australian Democrats who introduced outworkers for the first time into Australian law—maybe it is not so—certainly for the first time into the Workplace Relations Act, where we included outworkers as a specific category of workers who needed appropriate recognition. That, we thought, was an advancement and would give the minister and the government a mechanism by which they could start to accelerate improvements for this community of Australian employees.

However, I note from the government's response that it has indicated that the transfer of industrial relations responsibilities from Victoria to the Commonwealth did not include outworkers. Frankly, that is a surprise to me. I am disappointed to read that that is the government's interpretation of events. I would have expected the government to have included in its report, therefore, a commitment to persuading the Kennett government to pass amending legislation to put those outworkers across as well. I am not persuaded that the Kennett government would automatically say no. Why should it? It has indicated that it is prepared to pass over other workers. Why doesn't this government make an effort?

There are positive elements, of course. There are positive programs the government is embarking on in the training area. But I feel underlying the report is a defensiveness, an unwillingness to be proactive, a kind of passivity about the report. I do not necessarily have a problem with the government not being wholehearted about every recommendation. That is its right. But passivity of this kind, an unwillingness to be proactive, an unwillingness to be gung-ho and say, `We are going out there to make sure that as much as possible can be done' for what I would consider to be one of the weakest and most vulnerable of all Australian working communities is a great shame.

This report should be damned with faint praise for that feeling of passivity and for the lack of proactiveness and genuine concern and commitment to advancing the status of outworkers. I am confident enough in my colleagues in the Senate to know that they will not leave it there. They will take it back to the Economics References Committee within an appropriate time-frame to have another look at it and to apply more pressure on the government to be proactive, not to be passive, and to get on with advancing the cause of these workers. I say to my colleagues in the Senate who are of that mind: you will certainly have my support and the support of the Australian Democrats to keep applying the pressure in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not on this committee but the issue of the footwear, clothing and textile industries and their outworkers has been one of great concern to me for some time. I looked briefly at the government's response to the recommendations today. It does deserve, obviously, to be taken away and looked at in more detail. That is why I am happy to seek the leave of the Senate to continue my remarks later or hope that somebody does that today. We should all have a chance to look at the ramifications of this report in time to come back at a later stage when the legalities of the statements that have been made can be addressed more fully, because they are important. One that springs to mind is recommendation No. 1:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recommends that the government examine ways to clarify the employment status of outworkers in the garment industry.

That seems to be a fairly reasonable thing to ask—to clarify their status of employment. It is even mentioned in this response from the government—to put it in two words, the response from the government was `too hard'—that `clarification of the employment status of outworkers in the garment industry is complicated by constitutional limitations on the Commonwealth'.

Many of us listened to the debate on industrial workplace relations that took place here and realised that there certainly was a difference of opinion even within this chamber in relation to the constitutional obligations of the Commonwealth and the ability of the Commonwealth to act in relation to industrial relations. It is very interesting that the Commonwealth does act when they want to reduce workers' pay and conditions but when they need to protect workers' pay and condi tions they put their hands behind their backs. A very strange thing indeed.
What is interesting is that in this response from the government they mention that section 89A(9) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 defines an outworker as:

. . . an employee who, for the purposes of the business of the employer, performs work at private residential premises or at other premises that are not business or commercial premises of the employer.
Yet, their response was that it was too hard; they did not say that, but that is a paraphrase. The response continued:

In particular, the Commonwealth's constitutional power to legislate with respect to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State is inherently limited to matters pertaining to employees.
That is the irony. In the bill they have defined outworkers as being employees. So in fact it has argued its own case to a certain extent.

There may well be those people who still manage to fall between the cracks, and they may be those people who for various reasons are classified as independent contractors. But we know that the government has said that that is not what individual contracts are meant to do. They are not supposed to call people who are not really running their own business `contractors', people who are in fact employed by someone who has the power over them to set the conditions of work and so on.

If there is a range of people who for some reason are being called `small business' or `self‐employed' or `individual contractors' or who are not being called employees, perhaps we have to start asking this question: why is it that somehow or other those people can fall between the cracks? If they are, under this definition, called `employees' then it is time for the government to stop saying that this is too hard and to start dealing with such simple things as clarifying the employment status and then dealing with them and treating them fairly, which everybody must think is a reasonable thing.
Recommendation 2 is also very disappointing:
The committee recommends that the Government consider reinstating an amnesty for a period to allow community groups sufficient time to communicate—
not a radical thing—

with the outworkers and to persuade them of its benefits. The Committee further recommends that funding from the TCF 2000 Development Package be made available for community groups to inform outworkers of the amnesty.
Who is going to pay for that? It is not unreasonable to suggest that some funding be made available. But the answer is:
Not agreed. The Government does not believe that a reinstatement of the social security limited amnesty would be a viable or productive proposition.

If I was a cynic I would say that the government is keen to get their numbers of non‐complying social security people up. That is, it wants to put it to the public that there are lots of dole cheats out there—not people who do not know what their rights are, not people who do not know that they are not allowed to be exploited, not people who do not know that there are ways that they should be able to survive in Australia in 1997 without having to starve or live on starvation wages.
However, it is considered that data matching by the Department of Social Security is sufficient:
Data‐matching by the Department of Social Security commenced immediately following the end of the amnesty period, and has been underway since that time.

What does that mean? Does data matching by Social Security equate to giving information to people about their rights? I do not think it does. The data matching may well equate to finding people and getting those statistics so that Senator Newman can come into the Senate and say, `Look how many dole cheats we've got. Isn't this dreadful. We really would like the public to have faith in our social security system.' I think that that is what this is about.

It really is time to look at actual outcomes and circumstances and at whether people have ever had a fair go and do know, especially if they are not English speaking, what the issues are, what their rights might be and what rights may have been taken away in the way they have been treated.

BREAK.PARA: I said that I would speak for a short time. I know there are other people waiting to speak. But I hope that this will stay on the Notice Paper. I hope people will take it away and look at it in terms of a further response to the government, especially in relation to the legalities and the constitutionality, and make sure that what we end up with is a fair outcome for those people who are providing basic goods in Australia—footwear, clothing and textiles, and food, clothing and shelter. We should be able to produce those in Australia and we should be able to produce them without shameful pay and conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —As chairman of the Economics References Committee when this inquiry first commenced—which, as Senator Murray said, was the result of a term of reference moved in the Senate by former Senator Sid Spindler—I want to place on record that during that committee inquiry there was a unanimity of purpose in that nobody on either side of this chamber wanted to see workers exploited to the extent it was alleged prior to this inquiry taking place. It was a very important inquiry which in the end came up with recommendations. There may have been one or two exceptions but in most cases the recommendations were unanimous.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made those recommendations it was then up to the government of the day to respond. The government has seen fit to respond to the various recommendations in the way it sees as appropriate for the current situation. I was a chairman of other inquiries that this committee undertook. I note that the previous government would not respond to the recommendations of a CSIRO inquiry in particular. In this case the government has responded and while senators from the opposition and some of the other minor parties may not agree with the response, the response is here and there are many issues which the government has taken up and which it intends to act on out of that report.

There are some areas where they do not agree, and Senator Margetts has just highlighted one of them concerning amnesties for outworkers, et cetera. But it is worth remembering, and I will conclude on this note before seeking leave to continue my remarks, that at the end of the report one of the recommendations is that 12 months after putting down the report the committee review what has taken place in the industry to see whether any further recommendations should be made, or comment further on things that had happened since the government's response.

The committee is about to undertake that review of conditions or how things have changed since the report was written, and I think that probably when that review is done lots of the things that have been raised by Senator Jacinta Collins, Senator Murray and Senator Margetts will be issues that are included in that report. But I would reiterate that there was a unanimous view on that committee that nobody wants to see people, particularly those with poor English skills, being exploited in the outworkers industry, and it is the intention of the government in its own way, the way it sees fit, to make sure that that does not happen. With those few remarks, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (COLLECTION) BILL 1997

On 5 August 1997 the High Court held that business franchise fees on tobacco in New South Wales were invalid under section 90 of the Constitution. The franchise fees were held to be duties of excise which only the Commonwealth can impose. The decision also cast doubt on the Constitutional validity of other franchise fees imposed by the States and Territories. These fees are collected on tobacco, petroleum and liquor.

The High Court decision has a major impact on the budgets of the States and Territories. In 1997‐98 the business franchise fees on tobacco, petroleum and liquor are estimated to raise $5 billion in revenue.

As a result of the High Court decision, the States and Territories made a unanimous request to the Government to introduce measures to protect the State and Territory revenue. In response to the request of the States and Territories, the Commonwealth announced on 6 August 1997 a package of measures to protect State revenues already collected and replace future revenues by increases in certain Commonwealth taxes. The taxes may be seen as State and Territory taxes as the arrangements are being put in place at the request of the States and Territories to replace revenue put at risk following the High Court's decision. The package will:
. introduce a windfall tax.
. increase wholesale sales tax on alcoholic beverages;
. increase customs and excises on petroleum and tobacco.
The legislative package to give effect to these increases comprises 9 bills. These bills are:
. Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997
. Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Imposition) Bill 1997
. Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997
. Sales Tax (Customs) Alcoholic Beverages Bill 1997
. Sales Tax (Excise) Alcoholic Beverages Bill 1997,
. Sales Tax (General) Alcoholic Beverages Bill 1997
. Sales Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1997
. Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.3) 1997
. Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.3) 1997
The first three bills deal with the introduction of the windfall tax to protect State and Territory budgets against refund claims for revenue collected prior to 5 August 1997.

PARA.EMPHASIS: How the windfall tax will work

SPEECH.PARA: The windfall tax will apply from 5 August 1997.

The tax will apply whenever a person claims a refund of business franchise fees paid before 5 August 1997 because the fees are invalid under section 90 of the Constitution. The tax will also apply if a court orders payment of a refund for a similar reason. The windfall tax will only apply to refunds of business franchise fees on tobacco, petroleum and liquor.

The amount of the windfall tax will be 100 per cent of the refund claimed. However, the windfall tax will not apply to refunds in two circumstances. Firstly, the windfall tax will not apply to refunds which would have been made even if the franchise fees were valid.

Secondly, the windfall tax will not apply to the portion of a refund of a liquor franchise fee which relates to a licensing period after 6 August 1997. This will minimise the risk of double taxation which could have arisen as a result of the other elements of the safety net arrangements which increase the excise on petroleum and tobacco and the sales tax on alcohol. I understand the State and Territory Governments are committed to refunding liquor licensing fees for the licensing period after 6 August 1997.

The windfall tax is to be collected under a withholding system. The States and Territories will be required to withhold the tax from refunds of franchise fees which give rise to the windfall tax. The amount withheld will be applied as a credit against the taxpayer's liability for the tax. The regulations may also provide for the collection of unpaid windfall tax.

While the Commissioner of Taxation will have the general administration of the act, he will be able to enter into arrangements with the States and Territories for them to undertake that administration.
It is also proposed to make consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 as a result of the introduction of the windfall tax.

It is proposed that the refund of a State or Territory business franchise fee will be tax exempt to the extent to which it is subject to the windfall tax. It is also proposed that an income tax deduction will not be available for windfall tax incurred. This will ensure the imposition of the windfall tax is income tax neutral.

Four of the bills in this package relate to wholesales sales tax. Three of the bills impose increases in the rates of sales tax. Three separate bills have been drafted to increase the rate of tax to the extent that it is, respectively, a duty of customs, a duty of excise or a tax that is neither of these.

The rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages is to increase by 15 percentage points. This means that the rate of sales tax on wine, cider and similar beverages will rise to 41 per cent and for other alcohol the rate will rise to 37 per cent. The 12 per cent rate on low alcohol wine will not be affected by the price changes. The increase in the rates will apply to dealings from 3.30pm on 6 August 1997.

The fourth wholesale sales tax bill makes consequential amendments to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 as a result of the increase in the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages. The changes all apply from 6 August 1997.

A consequence of the increase in the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages is that it may force some taxpayers over the small business exemption threshold. Of particular concern is the impact on small liquor businesses and small wine producers.

Under the small business exemption, sales tax is not payable if the taxpayer's annual tax liability is $10,000 or less. It is proposed that the extra tax paid on alcohol is not included in determining if the threshold has been exceeded.

A similar problem arises with quarterly remitters. The increase in the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages may force taxpayers over the quarterly remitter threshold resulting in the payment of sales tax on a monthly basis.
To prevent this, it is proposed that the extra tax paid on alcohol not be included in determining if the quarterly remitter threshold has been exceeded.

This measure and the small business exemption change will ensure that the temporary increase in rates requested by the States and Territories does not increase the compliance costs of small businesses.

As a result of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements, some States intend to implement arrangements to rebate the difference between the new sales tax rate and the previous rate of liquor franchise fees. While the rebate will reduce the final cost of the goods to consumers, the rebate may have the unintended effect of reducing the taxable value of the goods for sales tax purposes and thereby reducing the amount of sales tax payable.

In order to ensure sales tax is paid on the correct value of the goods, it is proposed that the taxable value of alcoholic beverages cannot be reduced by any refund, rebate or similar payment made by a State or Territory to a sales tax payer in relation to the goods.

To assist in the administration of the State and Territory rebate arrangements, the States and Territories have asked for certain information to be made available on the additional sales tax collected. This Commissioner of Taxation is prohibited under the current law from disclosing such information.
The bill proposes that the Commissioner be allowed to disclose limited information to allow the States and Territories to administer their rebate arrangements.
The remaining two bills in the package make amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to increase the excise and customs rates of duty on tobacco and petroleum.
The excise and customs rates of duty on certain tobacco products will be increased by $167 per kilogram and on certain petroleum products by 8.1 cents per litre.
These increases were notified in Special Commonwealth Gazettes on 6 August 1997 and apply from 7 August 1997.
The increases in wholesale sales tax and customs and excise are estimated to raise around $6 billion in a full year. It is proposed the arrangements will be reviewed within 6 months.

All of the revenue collected by the Commonwealth under these arrangements will be returned to the States and Territories (after allowing for Commonwealth administrative costs). The package will accordingly be revenue neutral for the Commonwealth.
Full details of the bills included in this package are contained in the three Explanatory Memoranda circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bills to the Senate.
FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (IMPOSITION) BILL 1997
This bill is the second of three bills which implement the new windfall tax which is one element of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill imposes the windfall tax at a rate of 100 per cent which is mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
This bill is the third of three bills which implement a new windfall tax which is one element of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill makes consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 as a result of the introduction of the windfall tax.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES BILL 1997
This bill is the first of the three bills which increase the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages as part of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill modifies the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to the extent that the act deals with tax imposed by the Sales Tax Imposition (Customs) Act 1992.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
SALES TAX (EXCISE) ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES BILL 1997
This bill is the second of the three bills which increase the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages as part of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill modifies the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to the extent that the act deals with tax imposed by the Sales Tax Imposition (Excise) Act 1992.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
SALES TAX (GENERAL) ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES BILL 1997
This bill is the third of the three bills which increase the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages as part of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill modifies the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to the extent that the act deals with tax imposed by the Sales Tax Imposition (General) Act 1992.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1997
This bill makes consequential amendments to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 as a result of the increase in the rate of sales tax on alcoholic beverages.
The changes made by this bill in relation to:
. small business exemption;
. quarterly remittance;
. taxable value of goods;
. disclosure of information; and
were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997

This bill is the first of two bills which increase the excise and customs rates of duty on certain tobacco and petroleum products as part of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997

This bill is the second of two bills which increase the excise and customs rates of duty on certain tobacco and petroleum products as part of the Commonwealth safety net arrangements to protect State and Territory revenue.
This bill amends the Customs Tariff Act 1995.
The changes made by this bill were mentioned in my second reading speech on the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: — The committee is considering the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 as a whole and amendments 15 to 20, on revised sheet 366, moved by Senator Sherry for the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —When this bill was last before the committee, I was part way through what I had to say. Since then I have considered what Senator Sherry had to say in his generous remarks about my ability, such as it is, and I have looked at part 7 again. There is a problem with it, I think. It is a problem not so much of policy but almost of form. The act provides for certain things to be done and then creates a regime of offences to ensure that those things are done. I was wondering whether the way it is being done has been considered properly. For example, section 60 on page 36 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers under sections 52 and 53, paragraph 54(a) and sections 57 and 58 may be exercised only as provided in this section.
Subsection 3 states:
The powers may also be exercised in relation to any person for the purposes of an inquiry to the extent that the subject matter of the inquiry relates to a subject of Commonwealth power.

One of the powers that a chair or a commissioner appointed by the chair can do is summons people to a hearing. If that person does not attend, that person can be imprisoned. That person must answer whatever questions are asked, as long as it does not incriminate him or her.

BREAK.PARA: The width of this particular part is very wide. A minister could be summonsed in certain circumstances by a single commissioner who has been left alone because of circumstances that develop. That minister could be asked, on the wording of this section, what had been discussed within his or her department—indeed what had been discussed within cabinet. In other words, the sorts of things that are asked during estimates by eminent people such as Senator Sherry, Senator Hogg and Senator Murray but which are never answered can be asked by a commissioner or by a couple of commissioners. There is a requirement that answers be given under the pain of imprisonment up to six months, which seems quite extraordinary.

Under section 55 a person is saved from incriminating himself or herself but is not saved from giving commercial in confidence information because there is no exception put to that. So people can be asked how their business runs. A department of state can be asked how it conducts its affairs. It can be asked all these matters by a commissioner who is not an elected person, like a member of parliament, and the person has to answer it. The interesting thing is that a commissioner can issue the summons, bring someone before him and ask that person all sorts of questions which must be answered under the pain of a sentence of imprisonment.

The sorts of things that might be asked by this body would seem not to be the sorts of things that you would want to give these powers for. I am sure these powers are put there because they appear in other related legislation. The Productivity Commission will take over the powers of the Industry Commission, the Economic Planning Advisory Commission and the Bureau of Industry Economics. No doubt they have powers to get information, and those powers have simply been transferred across to this body but I think made quite draconian. It will be interesting to see whether these sorts of offences bear the same penalties in other legislation that they do in this legislation.

For example, the Copyright Tribunal has certain powers, but I do not think the penalties it can hand out are the penalties that are provided for here. As I said before, I do not think this is a matter of policy; I think it has been put in because people say, `This is an act. We have to enforce the provisions of this act, and this is the way we are going to do it.' If it is a matter of policy, it is a very interesting policy indeed.

All sorts of things can be asked by commissioners, as the act now sets out. The commissioners themselves do not have to have any qualifications that would involve a sense of what would be fair in asking a question and getting an answer. They do not have to have legal training. Lawyers are often criticised, but one thing they do have is a sense of a fair line of questioning. The commissioners do not have to be equipped in any way with qualifications that might enable them to exercise that judgment. Two of them can get together on an inquiry, summons whomever they feel is appropriate and ask them such questions as they want about how their business runs. If the people summoned are members of the Commonwealth Public Service, they can ask them whatever they want about how the department runs. If they are ministers, they can ask them how they are carrying out their ministerial duty. If those questions are not answered, the result might ultimately be that these people end up in gaol.

I would ask the parliamentary secretary whether those issues have been considered. It may be that they have. Section 57 says that the commission can order that particular piece of evidence not be made public. So perhaps it does contemplate that all sorts of secret things may be sought and obtained. It is interesting to read part of section 58. It says:
If documents are produced or given to the Commission under this Part—
and the commission can, as I say, get all sorts of very interesting documents, and very secret and confidential documents—
the Commission—
and then (b):
may keep possession of the documents for so long as is necessary for the purposes of the inquiry to which they relate . . .
State documents and business documents can be taken by this body and kept.

It seems to me that the powers of this commission are stronger even than the powers of the National Crime Authority; they are certainly much stronger than the powers of the police force. Looking at that part, it is just very worrying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond as succinctly as I can, because the debate on this bill has now gone into about its eighth hour. This is not to say that it is not an important matter; some of the matters we are dealing with are controversial. But this has been a long consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney: firstly, as Senator Sherry said at the very outset of the debate on debate on this amendment, the proposals for fines and penalties are the absolute equivalent of what is in the Industry Commission Act. I did not note any concern raised by you when that document went through the Senate back in about 1989. Even though I was not here to personally witness it, I have searched the Hansard and have not been able to find your raising these concerns. The powers of this commission are, for all intents and purposes, identical to those given to the Industry Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much greater.

—You can argue that. Also, you can argue that, because we are bringing three bodies together, we have a bigger body with more prestige, and so forth. But I do not accept that argument. I have said that many times, and I do not intend repeating it because it does not add to the information in relation to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that the reality is that at no time during the past seven years approximately that the Industry Commission has had these penalties available to it, even if you argue that the Productivity Commission may have some greater powers in some areas—and I do not accept that; at the moment it has very similar powers to the Industry Commission—has the Australian Labor Party or, in fact, any other party sought to amend these provisions. There was no committee reference, nor was there even any discussion about it. But Senator Cooney is someone who keeps a close watch on these things and we are lucky to have such senators in this place—and I mean that quite earnestly.

I would also say that one of the reasons for the fact that these matters have not been raised is that at no stage have these penalties ever been applied to one individual citizen or other legal entity, such as a corporation. That is not to say we should not have a close look at them; if you have these things hanging over your head, they are important matters. So it is not as though they have been used by the Industry Commission frivolously or for any wrong purpose in the past.

If there is serious concern, the coalition is prepared to have a look at these matters. But, because all we are doing is taking the provisions straight out of a bill which was put through this place in 1989 by the Labor Party and which was turned into law in 1990, and because there have been no problems raised with any of those provisions, we cannot see a strong argument for supporting this amendment.

However, we do foreshadow that, if these proposals in the bill are supported, the government is not only favourably disposed to having these matters—the matters that you have referred to generally in your contribution and the proposal that Senator Sherry has moved by way of an amendment—referred to an appropriate Senate committee; we are quite happy to do that. But more so, we are prepared to commit ourselves—and I do so on behalf of the government—to favourably look at any recommendations of that committee. So in other words, we are prepared to look at that.

We do not think there is any good ground, and we have not heard a good argument, for imposing the restrictions. They have not been a problem in the past seven years. They were not perceived to be a problem by anybody in this place, not a soul, back in 1989. They have not been used at all in the seven years. But we are not saying that we got it perfect. We are not saying that the Industry Commission had it right. What we are saying is that we think it would be a worthwhile use of an appropriate Senate committee to look at the penalties; but in the meantime, we would just move the Industry Commission Act penalties across into the Productivity Commission. That is what we would urge support for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for that. I think what he has said is accurate. I think the reason that these penalties have not become a problem is that they have never been invoked, and the Industry Commission has gone about its business without finding the necessity to call upon these things. That raises a couple of points.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point is this. If those penalties have never been invoked, it is perhaps time we abandoned them. I understand what the parliamentary secretary is saying when he comments that these ought to be looked at—and I think he is right—at some stage. But I think these are very savage penalties, as Senator Sherry says. If we were to get somebody, a commissioner or a chairman, starting using these penalties, their draconian nature would become apparent.

I am sure, as I said, it is not a matter of policy. I am sure it comes about because the people drafting the legislation feel that they have to have some penalty to enforce the provisions. But if you read those parts—leaving aside the history and the fact that we are no doubt going to have someone reasonable appointed to the position of chairman—and you look at the black letter law, it is very draconian. If they are on the books and they are draconian, that is a bad thing. If they are not needed—and history would seem to indicate that they are not needed—they should be dropped because they are too draconian to have on the statute book.

I would ask that this not be put aside but that the whole issue is looked at closely. I do accept, by the way, that I did not say anything about this and I was perhaps in a better position than most to look at it. As Senator Sherry pointed it out to me, it became apparent, so if anybody is to be criticised for what has gone on in the past, it is probably me. But I would like to recover that and see that this is looked at, and see where we go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a big man to admit that, Senator Cooney, and to say that he is pre pared to admit that he might have made a mistake and will have a look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition would quite genuinely like to see this matter referred. We will support a referral of this matter to a committee, and we have said we will favourably look at any recommendations of a committee on this matter.

Can I say that they are maximum penalties—and I think you do know that. They are not imposed by some rampant chairman running around trying to lock people up. They are matters that are decided by a court, just as, I suppose, when you are fined for not attending a federal election a court can decide to gaol you. And they often do gaol Australians for not turning up to get their name ticked off. So it fits in that category.

We believe that imposing a fine of something like $250 on a corporation like News Corp or Southcorp or some other body would be, for them, like flicking off a mosquito. It is not a penalty. But we do believe that the penalty issue should be looked at and it is an appropriate use of a Senate committee to do that. We think there is no reason why, in the meantime, we should not move the Industry Commission penalty regime into the Productivity Commission, and then you can refer it off to a Senate committee tomorrow if you want to. Give notice right now, refer it off tomorrow and come back to us in a few weeks time with a recommendation. It is on the record that we will look favourably at recommendations to change the penalty regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, gaols are scary places to contemplate. I appreciate that you say it is a maximum penalty but the maximum penalty would be six months gaol. Whether these are white‐collar crimes deserving of that potential penalty, I do not know. I am constrained in this debate—like you—by a lack of history. Generally speaking, penalties and punishments arise as a result of society assessing a practice which is unacceptable to it. I do not know what the Labor Party government at that time had as evidence of practice which would have warranted what are apparently draconian provisions.Was there any history or likelihood? Was there any empirical research which said that firms and companies which were asked to appear and to present information would not?

SPEECH.PARA: If you can help me, Parliamentary Secretary, how would the government of the day—and I guess the advisers would know, not you—have arrived at the view that there were so many people refusing to give information, refusing to assist the commission and refusing to provide what they were asked for, that you needed these excess terms? Because if there were none, and if there is no history—and you have ascertained there is no history over the last seven years—we do not need it. And if we do not need it, we should drop it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer that question, Senator Murray. I do not intend taking too much longer on this debate, except to say that we genuinely said we will have the matter looked at. My best advice at hand is to say that these have been regarded as generic penalty terms for similar sorts of provisions. I do not commit myself to this, but I have responsibility for the Australian Bureau of Statistics—amongst other bodies—at the moment, and I suspect that similar terms apply for non‐compliance with their requests for information. I know, because of my interest in the matter, that similar penalties apply to people who exercise what is a right of freedom in most other countries, and who do not turn up to vote at a federal election and then refuse to pay the fine.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that these are generic terms but I think the proposal that I have put forward is a sensible way to go. These provisions have been around; Senator Cooney described them as draconian. He voted for them in 1989, but you cannot judge someone fairly in 1997 for an act back in 1989. He said they should be looked at and I know that Senator Cooney would want the process that I have described to go ahead. That is what I hope the Senate will support, but I cannot add anything further to this debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take the time of the Senate unnecessarily, but I did ask a question before lunch about what has happened with respect to the staffing of the three predecessor organisations. Do you have any detail on that, Senator Campbell?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got it in the building, so we will get it delivered to you shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I can just imagine that if my former colleague, Senator Chamarette, were here she would have been on to this like a shot in terms of the imprisoning provision. As you know, in every bill she came across which had a penalty for imprisonment she changed that to penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly would be supporting amendments Nos 15 and 16 from the opposition, but I do think it is interesting that the parliamentary secretary has indicated that he would support a review of the penalties within this. It seems to me that there are a lot of bigger and more comprehensive things that need to be reviewed. The penalties may need to be reviewed but the whole kit and caboodle also needs to be reviewed.

The Productivity Commission's stocktake indicated that there should be an independent review of the operation of the key elements of the national competition policy framework and outcomes achieved, commencing in 1998. I do not know what they would consider to be an independent review—and I am not quite sure whether I would go along with who the government would probably consider would do an independent review—but the very least we need to do is look at a Senate review.

There are lots of things that need to be looked at, not just a tweaking of the wires. The whole workings of competition policy need to be looked at, as well as the outcomes. If the parliamentary secretary is willing, for a few weeks, to go on working out whether or not the fines are set at the right level then perhaps he should be considering whether or not we should do what the inquiry from the House of Representatives recommended, which was that we start looking at the socioeconomic impacts of competition policy—not just tweaking at the edges of something which might be going in totally the wrong direction.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any sense in proceeding with our next amendment to clause 62 because of the earlier debate we had and an earlier amendment that was, unfortunately, defeated. So I will not proceed with our next amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage, I would like to go back. Because of the defeat of division 2, competitive neutrality complaints, I think Senator Harradine did draw our attention—and I know Senator Campbell did as well—to clause 6(1)(c), functions of the commission. There does seem to be logic in deleting clause 6(1)(c) be deleted. Therefore I move:
Paragraph 6(1)(c), omit the paragraph.

By way of explanation, I point out that division 2, competitive neutrality complaints, was defeated by the Senate and, effectively, is no longer in the legislation. Clause 6(1)(c), functions of the commission, states:

on and after 1 July 1997, to receive and investigate complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements in relation to Commonwealth government businesses and business activities and to report to the Minister on its investigations . . .

In our view there is no sense in having that in the legislation. In respect of the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 , we have a later amendment that it be placed within the responsibility of the ACCC. That is a further debate to come.

This power in clause 6(1)(c) would be a new function. It was not amongst the old Industry Commission functions. I do not intend to speak at length about this, because I have already referred to the reasons why we believe the function of receiving and investigating complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements should reside with the ACCC. I know that the Democrats and Greens do not agree and will not be supporting our later amendment to the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill . I respect their view. When I referred to this matter earlier, when Senator Harradine drew it to our attention, I foreshadowed that this is what we would be doing.
Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

PARA.XREF: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION (REPEALS, TRANSITIONAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996

SPEECH.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment Nos 1 to 18 on sheet 626 would abolish the Industry Commission while allowing the staff of the commission a soft landing, which the government did not provide for the 200,000 they recommended be out of jobs. My feeling is that, in view of the changes that we have seen to the first bill, we should in fact drop these. I do not see that there would be any major advance in introducing them. I advise the committee that I do not intend to move the amendments on sheet 626 as a result of the changes to the earlier bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7 (after line 22), at the end of the bill, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part 3—Amendments of the Trade Practices Act 1974

SPEECH.PARA: Insert:
(1) On an after 1 July 1997, a person or organisation may complain to the Commission that:

PARA.TAB: (a) a particular significant Commonwealth government business or business activity is not being conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements that apply to it; or
(b) a particular significant Commonwealth government business or business activity should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements; or
(c) a particular significant Commonwealth business or business activity faces net competitive disadvantage and restraints in its capacity to compete against the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The complaint must be in writing.

(3) Competitive neutrality arrangements are the policy and principles contained in Clause 3 of the Competition Policy Principles Agreement. The objective of competitive neutrality policy is the elimination of resource allocation distortions arising out of public ownership of entities engaged in significant business activities. The principles apply to the business activity of publicly owned entities, not to the non‐business, non‐profit activities of these entities.
(1) The regulations may prescribe fees to be paid in relation to complaints made to the Commission under this Division.
(2) A complaint that is not accompanied by the prescribed fee (if any) is taken not to have been made until the fee has been paid.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 75AV Commission procedures for dealing with complaint

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Commission receives a complaint under this Division, it must investigate the complaint in order to determine whether there is a strong possibility that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the significant government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint is not being conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements; or
(b) the significant government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint should be required to be conducted in accordance with competitive neutrality arrangements; or
(c) the particular significant Commonwealth government or business activity faces net competitive disadvantage and restraints in its capacity to compete against the private sector;
as the case may be.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If the Commission determines that a possibility referred to in subsection (1) exists, it must make a written report to the Minister on its investigations and findings in relation to the complaint. 10

(3) If the Commission determines that a possibility referred to in subsection (1) does not exist, it must make a written report to the complainant on its investigations and findings in relation to the complaint.

PARA.TAB: Note: The Commission is also required to include information about competitive neutrality complaints in its annual report—see subsection 10(4).

SPEECH.PARA: (4) The report to the Minister under subsection (2) may include a recommendation that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Minister refer the matters raised by the complaint to the Commission for inquiry and report under section 11; or
(b) the Minister take other action in relation to the matters raised by the complaint.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) The Minister may specify additional procedures to be followed by the Commission in dealing with complaints under this Division, and the Commission must follow any procedures so specified.

(6) Additional procedures specified by the Minister must be given to the Commission by notice in writing, and the Minister must cause a copy of the notice to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister gives the notice to the Commission.
(1) If the Minister receives a report from the Commission under section 23, the Minister must, within 90 days of receiving the report:

PARA.TAB: (a) publish the report and his or her response to the report in any way he or she thinks fit; and
(b) give a copy of the report and the response to the complainant.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Before publishing the response, the Minister must consult with the Minister responsible for the government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint.

(3) The Minister referred to in subsection (1) must cause a copy of the Commission's report and of his or her response to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the response is published under subsection (1).
(4) Subsection (3) does not apply if the report and response have been tabled in each House of the Parliament under subsection (1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: 75AX Minister's response to Commission inquiry into complaint

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Minister refers a matter to the Commission for inquiry under section 11 in response to a report from the Commission under section 23, the Minister must within 90 days of receiving a report under section 11 on the inquiry, publish his or her response to the report on the inquiry in any way he or she thinks fit.

(2) Before publishing the response to the report on the inquiry, the Minister must consult with the Minister responsible for the government business or business activity that is the subject of the complaint.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 75AY Discretion not to investigate certain complaints

SPEECH.PARA: (1) In spite of subsection 23(1), the Commission may decide not to investigate a complaint if, in the opinion of the Commission:

PARA.TAB: (a) the complaint is frivolous or vexatious or was not made in good faith; or
(b) the complainant does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint; or
(c) an investigation is not warranted having regard to all the relevant circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If the Commission decides not to investigate a complaint it must inform the complainant of the decision.

I have already spoken on a number of occasions about why we believe the competitive neutrality complaints should be placed with the ACCC. I am aware of the numbers in this Senate with respect to this. I have not enjoyed Senator Harradine's support on this matter, so I would not be hopeful of a positive vote. I know Senator Margetts, and Senator Murray on the Australian Democrats' behalf are opposed to the ACCC. I recognise what the outcome will be, despite what could be the vigour of my arguments. I will not speak any further on this amendment, but I will ask that it be put.
Question resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.
Productivity Commission Bill 1996 reported with amendments; Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 reported without amendment.

That the report of the committee be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "and that the penalty provisions contained in the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 be referred to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee for inquiry and report by 29 October 1997".
I believe there is unanimous support for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in line with a commitment that I gave to the Senate when we were considering the penalty provisions. We said that it would be sensible for this matter to be referred to a committee for consideration and I am pleased that Senator Harradine has taken up our offer so quickly. The government has made a whole range of concessions which we think have improved the bill in some places. The idea of referring this penalty provision off to a committee is a sensible way of looking at what was a contentious issue for a number of senators around this place. Senator Harradine, we are very pleased to support this reference.

Original motion, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

That the bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1994 the Senate debated a series of bills related to the World Trade Organisation. It has not been until 1997 that that legislation has actually affected many people in Australia, and not many people in Australia knew at the time that it was going to affect them. It affected them in terms of the kinds of industries there were, how they operated, where employment was available, the terms of employment and a whole lot of other things including environmental rules, social rules and all sorts of things. They were affected by the agreement that was made and the bills that were put through here in 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, in 1997 we are beginning to find industries like the citrus industry, which was clearly identified in 1993 and 1994 as being problematic under those bills, having difficulties. The government at the time said that, no, everything would be okay. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries, which at the time were identified as going to be in serious difficulties as a result of the nature of the agreement, now in 1997 are being affected.

BREAK.PARA: We found there were other affected industries. They include parts of the dairy industry, the egg industry, the car industry and the sugar industry—we had all sorts of industries at the time saying that they had problems and most of them were told to shut up because everyone else would be okay. They are all surfacing now, three or more years later. In 1995 we came to this chamber and, with scandalously little debate, signed up to the 1995 competition policy legislation.

Only now are community groups beginning to see the impact that this is likely to have on them. They are not just industry groups; they are any people in the community who are concerned about the level and quality of services and accountability. They include environment groups, social justice groups, ordinary people in the community, consumers, all sorts of people right across the spectrum—people in rural and regional Australia, people from local governments. Everywhere you look, people are beginning to see the impact.

They still do not necessarily understand it. They are beginning to see that they are impacted, but they do not know exactly what they should do about it. It seems to me that maybe we will wait another year and all of this will be crunched into a very powerful structure. We have already got the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, which has been mentioned quite a lot in this debate, and we have the National Competition Council chewing through 2,000 pieces of legislation as we speak to see whether they are anti‐competitive. We have now got the Productivity Commission and today we have given them greater powers and less scrutiny than they had before.

I heard someone in the media the other day say that people should not be frightened of change; they should just go with the flow. I say that those people who are not frightened of change probably do not know exactly what is happening to them—and there are many people who do not. This is very complex and a lot of people do not understand. Competitive neutrality: what does it mean? Lowest cost tenders: what does that mean? Outcomes: they do know that; it means that things cost more, services that were available before are not available any more, there are simply not those things there that they used to know, they have to pay more for things or they cannot get them from the same places and so on—they are not convenient.

There are a lot of changes occurring, but not many people are in a position to recognise from where those changes are coming. There is time, I hope, for people to make their comments and to talk to people to find out what the issues are. Unfortunately, this bill is one of those steps in the wrong direction as far as I am concerned. It is jumping in with two feet; it is putting certain values—the dollar and private profits—above almost every other real value. There are some nice words and we will be looking to see whether those nice words do come to fruition. I also think that the actual basis of the competition policy will probably be stronger than anything else we have said today. That is unfortunate.

I would like to think that it will be less than another two or three years before people come to realise that we ought to be pointing the finger not at those people who fall in the process, and blame them in scapegoat politics, but at those people who are making these decisions without proper heed of the social, environmental and economic impacts that they are having.

I strongly oppose the way that this legislation has been put through; I strongly oppose the blind faith and ideology that has been used to shove this through, despite the many concerns that are arising in this society; and I strongly urge that we take the time to look at what these impacts are and make sure that we can change them before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the third reading. I did hear some echoes from the back; I noticed Senator Hill and Senator Kemp moaning and groaning. You would think that they would have made a substantial contribution in this important debate rather than trying to make silly interjections.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why Labor will be opposing the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 is that a number of the core amendments and changes that we sought to be made to what is to be a greatly enhanced Industry Commission have unfortunately been defeated. I note the earlier vote on the second reading by Senator Kernot, representing the Democrats, in opposing this legislation on the second reading. I did note Senator Margetts's vote and I did note Senator Colston's vote as well. I particularly noted the comments that Senator Kernot made at the ACTU congress this morning. I am sure that they will be viewing with interest the position that the Democrats take on the third reading of this legislation. It will be interesting to see whether the consistency is matched with the rhetoric of Senator Kernot at the ACTU congress this morning.

As I said earlier, there are a number of major amendments that unfortunately were not carried with respect to the Productivity Commission Bill. In particular, we have major concerns with the expansion of the functions of this new revamped Productivity Commission. I do not intend to keep the Senate for long. But we did point out that there is an extensive expansion of the Productivity Commission. One area in particular concerns a new power to receive and investigate complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements as well as the combining of many of the previous functions of the three successive bodies. We find that to be totally unacceptable in the new Productivity Commission.

With respect to policy guidelines for the commission, which was another major area of concern for Labor, unfortunately, there are still a number of areas in the policy guidelines with which we have a fundamental disagreement. One of those guidelines is the reference to the regulation of industry, including regulation by states, territories and local government, where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of Commonwealth government in the context of this greatly enhanced Productivity Commission. Earlier this evening we dealt with some issues, again in the context of a greatly enhanced Productivity Commission, relating to clause 7 of the legislation, which relates to offences. They are a number of the outstanding issues in this Productivity Commission Bill which we are considering that we have great concerns with.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, I do not want to take up the time of the Senate unduly. We have great concerns with the Productivity Commission as it has been presented to the Senate. There have been some changes but, unfortunately, not enough to satisfy the Labor opposition. The old Industry Commission is certainly a much better organisation than the proposed new Productivity Commission, as amended by the Senate.

So Labor, without hesitation or fear, will be voting against the third reading of this legislation. If the third reading is defeated, the old Industry Commission will still be in existence. The old Industry Commission still being in existence is a lot better than this Productivity Commission.

As I said earlier, if the Australian Democrats want to argue—particularly after Senator Kernot's comments this morning, that I am sure will be widely reported amongst the trade union movement and the media—that their version of an improved Productivity Commission Bill is better than the old Industry Commission, it will be interesting to see them sustain that argument in wider forums. That is Labor's position and that is how we intend to vote on the third reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you can guess from the reactions of Senator Sherry that I have been speaking to him prior to the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. The Australian Democrats loathe Labor's Industry Commission. We believe that Labor's Industry Commission destroyed many industries, destroyed over 200,000 jobs and pursued a one-eyed ideological campaign which did enormous damage to our economy and our country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked Senator Sherry if he would be prepared to vote both bills down with us so that both the Industry Commission and the Productivity Commission would go. We have made no secret, either in this debate or in the wider forums, of our attitudes to the Industry Commission and the Productivity Commission because we believe that they are tainted with that ideology originally set in place by Labor. However, Senator Sherry, on behalf of Labor, has indicated that he is not prepared to vote down the Industry Commission.

My firm personal belief is that the Productivity Commission, as improved, is a far better animal than is the Industry Commission. I have a great deal of trouble persuading my colleagues to shift from the position which we have adopted, which is to vote `no' to both. The consequence is that we will be left with the old Industry Commission. I have been handed a note from my party colleagues indicating that they have declined to accept my advice that we should in fact abstain, which to me was the only honourable route that we could take. However, we are placed in an impossible position, and I understand the position we are in. We will therefore be voting `no' to both bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has come to the table in a most genuine way. We have accepted significant amendments to a whole range of clauses in this bill. We have debated it for, I think, 8½ or nine hours line by line. We have conceded sensible amendments which we think have improved the legislation—its functions, the notice provisions, the appointment provisions, including new commissioners with special responsibilities for the environment, ecological sustainability, industry, employment and a range of other matters, the appointments of deputy chairmen, meeting provisions, the consultant provisions and a whole range of important concessions—
—Guidelines.

—The policy guidelines. These are massive improvements which even Senator Murray has just admitted make it a better body—and the Senate is contemplating voting it down after the government has come to the table and made these concessions. I think it is fair to say—strike me down if I am wrong—that in principle an enormous percentage of the Democrats' proposals and the Green proposals—not proposals, Senator Margetts, but certainly concessions—related to the detail of this bill. To see the Democrats vote against it will be particularly depressing to the small business community, particularly those wanting access to this body to deal with complaints. I hope we do get a majority in the third reading vote to see this bill come into law.

That the bills be now read a third time.
