SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The township of Jabiru in the Northern Territory has developed a unique and special characteristic. In voting terms traditionally for years and years the Labor Party held that seat with 57 per cent of the primary vote. That 57 per cent dissipated from the traditional voting pattern of that township at the 1996 federal election, when my federal colleague Nick Dondas and I achieved a change. We promoted a proposal to scrap the three‐mine uranium policy. At that election, in 1996, the vote shifted from the normal 57 per cent ALP, 43 per cent CLP that had been the traditional voting pattern to one of the ALP 45 per cent and the CLP 55 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: At last week's 1997 Northern Territory election this voting pattern of 45 per cent, 55 per cent was maintained. The community is different in that the population basically comprises three important groups: Aborigines, national park workers and mine employees. The seriousness of our policies on resources and the environment was carefully measured and resulted in what I would consider was that mind shift change in 1996, maintained this year in the Northern Territory election last Saturday.

Let me highlight some of the issues in the last 18 months of the Howard government that are now having an effect and will have an effect in Jabiru, in the surrounding Kakadu national park, in the immediate environs of that area and probably more generally in Arnhem Land. At last Saturday's election there was also a significant voting pattern change in a number of communities right throughout Arnhem Land, which again highlights the issues that are being drawn out.

Recently the Senate considered a select committee report on uranium mining and milling in Australia. I have spoken previously in the Senate on the various issues that were canvassed in that report. I did commend at that point not only my colleagues on this side of the chamber but also the welcome mood change within the Labor Party on the issues of uranium milling and mining in Australia. That Senate report has obviously gone on to highlight the issues that have now compounded.

In recent months there have been a number of other important initiatives. I would commend to the attention of senators and the public the announcements by the Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill, who has recently released the Kakadu regional social impact study as part of the important considerations for the Kakadu region.

That study has been conducted over the last six or 12 months in a professional manner. The report was developed after two important considerations: an Aboriginal project committee gave the matter detailed and thorough consideration, and the main body of the study advisory group to the report also made a number of key recommendations. These will comprise a very important basis on which the recommendations that Senator Hill has now made to the minister for resources, Senator Parer, will be considered, particularly for the important project of Jabiluka in the Northern Territory.

As part of this, these three important constituencies that intertwine in this area do have some important and significant issues to be addressed. It is obviously a part of the Northern Territory where it is important that special community consultations happen to ensure that all sectors of that community within both the national park and the township of Jabiru itself are consulted. Those issues are very closely aligned to mining interests, whether in the continuing project at Ranger or the proposal for development at Jabiluka.

There are important government considerations for the federal government and the Northern Territory government to consider in coming months. We must guarantee that employment, education and training are properly available not only to the Aboriginal community who live in the park region but also to people in the township itself. The issues of housing, particularly if any expanded mining proceeds, health services, important social programs in alcohol, and community facilities such as sporting and cultural activities, women's resources, and cross‐cultural training must be addressed to ensure that the community goes on and develops special arrangements.

I have taken the time to read the proposal with regard to the export of uranium from Jabiluka orebody No. 2 and the environmental assessment report that has been submitted to Senator Hill on this occasion. It includes a number of recommendations that are vital to the community and which address those issues that were environmentally focused. I am pleased to note that the report certainly highlights areas for special attention. Similar to the recent Senate report, it also highlights that there is no need for any deliberate or special constraints other than those that can be totally accommodated.

Not only is the area one of the most heavily regulated mining communities, but it already contains within it the important support on environmental issues of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, suitable auditing procedures are already embraced, there are cooperative arrangements between the Northern Territory government and the federal government, and there is a determined effort to ensure that Aboriginal liaison is pulled together and that we do see a comprehensive environmental safety and health management system.

Kakadu attracts something like 235,000 tourists per year at the moment. Many of these visitors not only focus on the natural attraction of the park itself but are able to focus on the issues surrounding uranium mining at Ranger. The public exposure to this is very important.

The Aboriginal community of the region is fragile. There are differences of opinion, there are jealousies and there are important issues to do with the traditional owners, many of whom do not live in the local area but still have a sense of place and community that is important and must be accommodated. Importantly, there are many other Aboriginal people and Territorians who chose to use the region to accommodate all these issues relating to mining, tourism, conservation and urban lifestyle. As we pull together each and every one of these issues, it is important to recognise that for the next decade or so Jabiru and Kakadu will continue to be major media focus points, and not just because of the radicalisation of so many of the small group demonstrators who constantly visit the area or wish to highlight for other political purpose their own agendas.

The community clearly demonstrated by the way they voted last week in the Northern Territory election and at the federal election of March 1996 that it supports the policies of the Country‐Liberal Party in the Northern Territory and the Liberal and National parties federally with regard resources, development and the environment. It certainly will be an area that, whilst it will always be under the microscope, will develop logically, very carefully and very fruitfully for the Australian and Northern Territory economies.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Sydney Airport Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Today this government finally got something right. Today this government announced that it would not proceed any further with its proposal to locate Sydney's second airport at Holsworthy. It is unfortunate, however, that it has taken 15 months and at least $6 million—probably more—of taxpayer's money for this government to come to the conclusion that what the Labor Party and the communities of south western Sydney, the Sutherland shire and the Illawarra have been telling them was the only conclusion they could ever reach, and that is that the Holsworthy site was never a suitable site for Sydney's second airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Hundreds of thousands of people in the area petitioned this government and told this government that this was a crazy proposal. Local councils, community groups and, as I said, consistently the Australian Labor Party told this government that their decision last May to include Holsworthy in the EIS process was ludicrous and should be abandoned. But the government never listened. They kept on with this proposal until eventually they were forced, by weight of the sheer overwhelming evidence that this would be an environmental and social disaster, to reach the only conclusion possible, that is, that Holsworthy could not be considered in any way suitable for Sydney's second airport.

The decision that they reached, and announced today, is exactly the same as the decision made by the Labor government back in 1985—that Holsworthy is unsuitable. So what we have seen from this government today is a recognition that the community was right, that the Labor Party was right, that the former government was right. But, unfortunately, they have had to waste $6 million of taxpayers' money to come to that conclusion. In the process, over the last 15 months they have created unnecessary anguish, distress and dislocation for hundreds of thousands of people living in this area.

Whilst people celebrate today the decision—the only decision that could be reached—they also send a message to this government that they will not forget, come the next election, the distress that this government put them through unnecessarily.

I want to pay tribute tonight to the great campaign conducted by the community, by the people of the region. Whilst there are many hundreds of people I could mention, unfortunately time does not permit me to do so. But I particularly mention Mr Jim McGoldrick from the South‐West Community Alliance, who in the very early stages following this disgraceful decision last May took up the fight on behalf of the residents of Holsworthy, Wattle Grove and other regions and kept at it. His driving force was responsible for petitions and submissions from in excess of 50,000 people, all opposing this airport proposal.

I also want to pay tribute to Phil Smith and his entire team at the Sutherland Environment Centre for their efforts on behalf of the people of the Sutherland shire and Illawarra region in campaigning against this crazy proposal. Their efforts demonstrated that ultimately you can even get a Liberal‐National Party government to listen to the community. But they should never have had to go through that trauma and distress. They should never have had to put in the hours and days and weeks and months of voluntary work in order to convince this government of what everyone else knew was a reality.
I also pay tribute tonight to the former member for Hughes, Robert Tickner, who took this issue up on behalf of the residents of the area, particularly the residents of the Illawarra.

But there are still some issues that have to be resolved. Questions still remain. Why was this decision made last May to include Holsworthy, when all of the evidence that had been put in the past demonstrated that it was just a ludicrous proposition: that there were major environmental concerns; that there were going to be major costs involved in getting rid of the unexploded ordnance; that it would have a major effect on the existing defence establishments at the Holsworthy range; and that it would create social dislocation through the massive noise that would have been generated over the homes of hundreds of thousands of people, people who had moved into this area, invested their life savings, taken out their mortgages, raised their children and developed communities, on the understanding that they were never going to have an airport in that region. Of course, they were deceived by the government at the last election when they were not told what was in store for them.

It is about time the government stopped hiding behind their claims of confidentiality and released the information and the advice that has been requested under the freedom of information legislation. They should come clean on just what was the reason that this proposal was put back on the drawing board again. They should come clean on what was the involvement of the Lawrence Hargrave project team; what secret deals were entered into at the time between ministers and the proponents of that proposal.
This has been tremendous news for the people of south‐west and southern Sydney and the Sutherland shire in particular—an area where I have lived all my life, and I declare an interest, of course.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, with the good news, this government has to put in some bad news. On the very same day that they have ruled out an airport at Holsworthy, what have they announced? They have announced that there is going to be a new reactor built at Lucas Heights—in the middle of probably one of the fastest growing regions of Sydney.

We all know that when the Lucas Heights establishment was built and opened in the 1950s it was actually in the bush. I used to live in Cronulla in those days, and I can remember my father taking us on an outing for the day to Lucas Heights to have a look at this newfangled technology. It probably took us about half a day to get there and get back, but today I can walk from my place in Engadine, or Yarrawarra, 100 yards up to the top of the hill and I can see the reactor. I can also see thousands of homes that surround it.

Whilst the people of the area have put up with that reactor and accepted that it was there, and they have done that because they may have bought their homes and moved in after that reactor was built, one thing they will not accept is an arrogant government putting a new reactor into that site. They will never accept that. Just as they have fought and opposed the siting of the airport and have won, they will also fight and oppose and win on this issue.

I will stand up here again, just as I have done on the Holsworthy issue. I can see that I will be making quite a lot more speeches on the adjournment debate and other occasions on this issue. You have to ask: what is it that this government does not like about the people of the Sutherland shire? Why do they want to give them another reactor? You would think that, in a country the size of Australia, you could find another location if we actually need a new reactor.

The McKinnon report in 1992 and even this Senate committee's report No time to waste recognises that there are fundamental questions that should be answered as to whether we need a new reactor. Are there alternative technologies that are available? There should be a full public inquiry into this issue before any decision is made. There certainly should be, as has been recommended, a decision on a waste repository site made by this government before a new reactor is built. They are the issues that have to be addressed. But what does this government do? It gives some good news to the people and then it gives them the bad news: a new reactor. It is not on, and we are going to stop it. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper on foreign affairs and trade released by the government last Thursday represents the government's attempts to look beyond election cycles and to try to chart the passage of foreign affairs and trade through the next 15 years. I congratulate them for that. Naturally enough, any paper produced by a government will reflect its ideologies and its world perspective. This paper is no different, but you do not have to read too far into the paper to realise that the government's attitude to foreign affairs is now inward looking, it is conservative and it is defensive.

SPEECH.PARA: The white paper states that the government's foreign affairs and trade policy is about advancing the interests of Australia and Australians. But what are those values? What is an intrinsic Australian value? How are they developed? Are they enduring? What changes are there to these values, and what influences these changes? I would suggest that Australian values relate to a fair go for all, to justice, to equality and to participation. It is these values that we ought to incorporate in the national interest—the name of the white paper.

Four pillars provide the framework for the white paper. The first is that the government gives priority to the Asia-Pacific region but particularly to east Asia, and I think that is a very good thing. The second is the forging of closer relationships with the United States, Japan, Indonesia and China all in that order. The third is the commitment to further trade liberalisation, including strong support for the World Trade Organisation and APEC. I think we have some problems with that. The fourth is the importance of bilateral relationships such as the basic building blocks for effective regional and global strategies with a selective approach to the multilateral agenda. I think that is a problem too.

The paper has a dominant and recurring theme of globalisation, trade and investment. Perhaps as a concession to the one member of the advisory panel with an obvious commitment to human rights—and I am very pleased he was there—it makes muted reference to Australia's commitment and role on human rights and to the international conventions which support them.

But the paper makes other statements which question the government's real commitment to such conventions—statements such as `Australia needs to direct resources and support to those areas of the UN system which most advance Australia's national interests.' I find it rather disturbing that Australia, a founding member of the United Nations, which has played the most significant role in the setting of international standards, especially for human rights, appears to be disengaging from the United Nations at the time when the institution needs the greatest support to meet the challenges of the next century.

The recent comments by the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, that the UN declaration on human rights represented Western values only and should be reviewed if not rewritten was met with opposition from leaders around the world. But the Australian government minister replied that it was unlikely that the declaration of human rights was going to be reviewed. I sincerely hope he is right, but we did not hear any statement from the government that reconfirmed the universality of human rights. I would have thought that would be the first statement that would come up after the statement of Dr Mahathir.

I applaud the government's stated commitment to human rights, but their actions suggest otherwise. The position Australia took that we would not sign the European Union's trade agreement because of its human rights clause did nothing for our international reputation, and it did not advance our national interests either. The white paper should be commended for spelling out a commitment to racial equality and to the elimination of racial discrimination, but a moral commitment to racial inequality is one thing. It is patronising and it is offensive to the region that the paper ends up saying that we are interested in the region for the economic benefits which follow from closer engagement.

It is a dangerous position, and it makes a mockery of the government's commitment while preaching the universality of human rights on the one hand to declare that linking human rights to trade services neither Australia's trade nor its human interests. It also conflicts with the government's stated commitment to the Asia-Pacific region. In a region where growing democratic movements are looking to Australia for leadership and for encouragement, it is not good enough for the government to be recoiling from democratic and human rights principles.

Of course the Democrats understand the importance of trade in our relationships with other countries. They are crucial relationships; they do form the basis of some of our domestic policies. But clearly our commitment needs to be defined in more than economic terms. Is the government wise to declare that economic relations in the region are our highest priority? Will the economic growth in east Asia experienced over the last 15 years continue for the next 15 years, particularly at the same speed?

There are political and economic uncertainties facing this region, not the least being the lack of skilled labour, physical infrastructure—an institutional weakness—and environmental degradation. Events on Bougainville and in Cambodia recently are constant reminders of the very fragile nature of once colonised nations engaging in the global economy. It is these very issues that we should be concerned about in our relations with any country, whether it is through bilateral or multilateral forums.

I moved a second reading amendment to the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill , a bill which appropriates funds and issues securities to effect Australia's membership to the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency. MIGA is an institution of the World Bank, and it is designed to foster foreign investment in developing countries by provid ing insurance against risks and by providing advisory services regarding foreign investment.

My amendment would have ensured that any Australian company which operated overseas did so in a manner which was consistent with the laws which apply to environmental and occupational health and safety standards in this country. Neither the government nor the opposition supported the amendment, but respect for human rights is an essential factor in any sound business environment, and it is a necessity in the creation of the best possible conditions for investment.

I was also disappointed that the diplomatic importance of our aid program was not given more priority in the white paper, particularly given the recent Simons review. Over the last two decades Australian governments have asserted that Australia's destiny lies with Asia, with which closer economic, military and cultural ties must be forged. Despite this though, successive governments have not been able to convince the Australian people or, indeed, Asian governments that Australia is part of this region.

While this paper places its commitment on the public record, more will have to be practically done to advance this relationship. We have been involved with ASEAN and APEC for some time, and yet we have still to truly develop those relationships. Perhaps more effort should be placed on gaining membership to the ASEM forum.

There is no assessment in the paper which answers the question of what happens if we fail to develop a closer relationship with the Asian region. Is it wise to state so categorically that there are four nations with whom we intend to direct our relations most significantly?

The defining of the United States, whose strategic engagement and commitment underwrite regional stability, can be seen as an outdated and Cold War approach to viewing our relationship with that country. We should also see the point of view that the US represents a threat to the Asian region and to Australia as an economic enemy, particularly in terms of agricultural dumping. Our relationship with the United States should be defined more maturely, and not solely in terms of security and of regional stability.

The argument about what the changing shift in power in the Asian region will mean for Australia is not developed. But regional security will come about through upgrading human rights standards and through the democratisation of Asian nations.

This is the first foreign affairs and trade white paper that I can remember. The government ought to be congratulated for producing it. It allows those of us outside the government to analyse its policy and commitment to the fundamentals of foreign affairs and trade policy. For the Democrats though, this basis should always be human rights—and I fear that this paper does not advance Australia's human rights commitment in the slightest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The sugar industry has been significant in the history and development of North Queensland. It has cemented its place in history further in another way—and that is for its leadership in environmental understanding and management.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to congratulate cane farmers throughout Queensland who, on their own initiative, are attempting to ensure that their industry becomes more environmentally sustainable. In particular, I congratulate the Mackay Canegrowers in North Queensland for an excellent initiative they have commenced.

Mackay Canegrowers have shown admirable foresight and environmental responsibility in establishing the Environmental Farmer of the Year Award. This annual award is part of a new system of awards aimed at recognising and rewarding growers in the Mackay cane growing region who manage their farming enterprises to minimise any adverse environmental impacts on their farming activities, and to promote and encourage biodiversity on their farms.

After calling for nominations, Mackay Canegrowers carefully whittled away the applicants for the inaugural award down to four. A team of four judges, including repre sentatives from the Canegrowers Environmental Advisory Committee, the Mackay Conservation Group, cane grower support organisations, Commercial Union Insurance and the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, then visited the farms in mid-June and assessed them according to numerous and rigorous environmental criteria.

These criteria, governing vital on-farm environmental considerations, included record keeping of soil testing and chemical and fertiliser use; erosion control, such as contouring and sediment traps; irrigation management, including the method of irrigation and tailwater management; fertiliser management; harvesting and trash management; pest management; waste disposal; management of original vegetation; and farm and household recycling.

After applying this comprehensive testing procedure, the judges determined the winner of the Environmental Farmer of the Year Award to be Plane Creek cane grower, Mr Keith Schmidtke. Mr Schmidtke's victory emphatically shows that with responsible and considerate management primary producers, who have for so long been the backbone of this nation, can successfully grow their product in an environmentally friendly fashion.

Mr Schmidtke's victory is made more meritorious by the significant improvements he has made to his farm since acquiring the 150 hectare property in 1970, and it emphasises the positive changes that are taking effect in farming and land management practices in this country. The property, when he acquired it, was riddled with problems, including eroding gullies and irregularly flowing creeks, and with only a handful of trees lining the creek banks. After a lot of effort, these concerns were addressed, and I am aware that the property now even has tailwater dams to collect farm run-off before it can enter the creek, thus protecting the creek and providing additional water for on-farm irrigation.

With between 1,200 and 1,300 cane growers in the Mackay region alone, and over nine million tonnes of sugar crushed from this area last year, the significance of such environmental initiatives cannot be, and should not be, underestimated. The more that initiatives such as those adopted by Mackay Canegrowers can be promoted and encouraged, the more winners there are. Not only does the environment benefit in tangible, measurable ways, but evidence is increasingly showing that farm output and quality of output is also improved, making it a win-win situation.

I applaud the Mackay Canegrowers organisation for establishing this bright initiative which has become part of an annually contested title, with nominations already being called for next year's award. I believe that more organisations can take a leaf out of the Mackay Canegrowers book and follow the excellent and responsible environmental example they have set. For example, there are cane growers who, even in the absence of the opportunity to win an environmental award, are taking their environmental responsibility seriously.

Tully cane farmer Mr Ross Digman has planted native forest trees along both the banks of the Tully River and his on‐property drainage canals. He has set aside part of his land as a native cabinet timber plantation to both diversify his income producing crops and to provide food and habitat for local wildlife. Furthermore, this particular farmer excavated an artificial wetland to replace wetland areas that have been drained in order to reinstate an important fish breeding habitat.

Mr Digman has also gone so far as to produce a video outlining his environmental initiatives; this video is available at video outlets in the area dubbed the `sugar coast'. In producing the video, Mr Digman aims to encourage his fellow cane growers to follow his lead not only for the sake of the industry's long‐term viability but also fro the sake of producing positive environmental outcomes.

BREAK.PARA: Environmental initiatives which redress some of the environmental damage of the past should not go unnoticed. Mr Schmidtke and Mr Digman should therefore be roundly congratulated for their efforts, as should the Mackay Canegrowers organisation for establishing the Environmental Farmer of the Year Award.

It is worth noting that this award complements the sugar industry's self-initiated environmental audit of 1996. This audit highlighted the need for cane growers to be further educated about the benefits of adopting green practices. Significantly, the Mackay Canegrowers environmental audit not only educates; it rewards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 June 1997.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that Giblett forest near Pemberton in Western Australia has been on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate since March 1994 for a wide range of high conservation values.

(2) Is the Minister aware that a coupe in the Giblett forest was logged in 1994 and 1995 and woodchips produced from that coupe were exported in contravention of the woodchip export licence granted to the Western Australian Chip and Pulp Co Pty Ltd, which is owned by the Western Australian corporation Wesfarmers Bunnings Limited.

(3) Is the Minister aware that, pursuant to section 30(3) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1974, it was the expectation of the Australian Heritage Commission that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would refer the proposed logging for export woodchips in Giblett forest to the commission for its consideration.
(4) Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has not referred the proposal to the commission.

(5) What steps will be taken to ensure that the Minister complies with section 30(3) of the Act and that logging for export woodchips is not again conducted in Giblett forest in contravention of the law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) In relation to Giblett Block, which is on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate, I am aware of investigations conducted during 1995, by the then Minister for Resources into allegations that woodchips had been exported from parts of Giblett Block without proper approvals. However, I understand the former Minister subsequently concluded that it would not be possible to prove any breach of an export licence.

(3 and 4) In relation to three year transitional woodchip export licences, I sought the AHC's advice under S30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act on 28 August 1996. That advice was provided by the AHC on 16 October 1996 and I took into account the AHC's advice before issuing the licences.
(5) Nearly 60% of the Giblett block is protected under a voluntary undertaking by the Western Australian Government not to log certain areas during 1997.

The sourcing of timber from crown lands in Western Australia for supply under export contracts is controlled by the Western Australian Minister for the Environment within the framework of the Deferred Forest Agreement, made between the Commonwealth and Western Australia. This agreement safeguards biodiversity, old growth, wilderness and other environment and heritage values in nominated unreserved areas during the development of a comprehensive adequate and representative reserve system.

Any timber harvested, whether it is intended to be used domestically or exported, can only be sourced from areas agreed under the DFA as not being potentially required to form part of the `comprehensive, adequate and representative' forest reserve system which will be implemented under a Regional Forest Agreement.

The transitional licences prohibit exports of woodchips sourced from Deferred Forest Areas on crown land, which were designed to maximise protection of National Estate values. Exports of native hardwood woodchips sourced from National Estate places outside Deferred Forest Areas are allowed under transitional licences (subject to compliance with other licence conditions).
Consequently, there is no further action with respect to transitional licences, required on my part which would trigger consideration of Australian Heritage Commission Act requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 June 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) When did the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) refer the applications for the importation of cooked chicken meat from Thailand, the United States and Denmark to the Meat Inspection Branch (MIB) and the Imported Food Section (IFS) of the department for advice on public health matters.
(2) When did AQIS receive advice back from the MIB and the IFS following the referrals in (1).
(3) Can copies be provided of the reports from both the MIB and the IFS to AQIS.

(4) When did AQIS refer the above applications to the National Food Authority (NFA), now the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, to enable that organisation to undertake a full public health risk assessment.
(5) When did the NFA provide AQIS with the completed risk assessment.
(6) Did that assessment deal separately with the three applications.

(7) Was that full public health risk assessment prepared by the NFA subjected, by either the NFA or AQIS, to a peer review; if so: (a) when did that happen; and (b) who undertook the review; if the assessment was not subjected to a peer review, why not.

(8) Was the NFA public health risk assessment released for public comment by either AQIS or the NFA; if so: (a) when was the document released; (b) how long was the period provided for public scrutiny of the document; and (c) how many organisations and individuals responded; if the document was not released, why not.
(9) Has AQIS considered all submissions received as a result of this process and responded to all submissions.
(10) Can a copy of the full public health risk assessment of imported cooked chicken meat undertaken by the NFA be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)—(3) The areas referred to in the question are organisational units internal to AQIS. Internal working papers are not available.
(4) AQIS referred the applications to ANZFA for risk assessment on 1 September 1994.
(5) Preliminary advice was received from ANZFA in September 1994. This advice was used by the Imported Foods Inspection Program of AQIS to set the inspection standards at the highest level.
(6) The three applications were dealt with concurrently in ANZFA's interim report.

(7) The ANZFA risk assessment was not subjected to peer review by AQIS. ANZFA's interim report recommended that cooked chicken meat be categorised as risk food, which would attract the most intensive rate of checking under the Imported Food Inspection Program administered by AQIS. Under the Imported Food Control Act 1992, ANZFA has the statutory responsibility for risk categorisation of imported food. It would therefore be inappropriate for AQIS to submit ANZFA's advice in this respect to peer review.
(8) AQIS did not release the interim report but included a summary of the report in AQIS policy memorandum 1996/32.
(a) The policy memorandum was released on 7 June 1996. A copy is provided.
(b) The period provided for public scrutiny of the policy memorandum was 3 weeks.
(c) All State Chief Veterinary Officers, CSIRO and major poultry industry associations responded to AQIS Policy Memorandum 1996/32.
Policy on public release of ANZFA risk assessments is a matter for that organisation.

(9) AQIS has considered all submissions received in response to the AQIS Policy Memorandum 1996/32. Concerns raised have been part of the deliberations of the technical working group established by me to allow industry a further opportunity for technical consultation on AQIS draft import conditions. These concerns have been addressed in AQIS Policy Memorandum 1997/9.
(10) The question should be directed to ANZFA.

IMPORTATION OF COOKED CHICKEN MEAT FROM THE USA, DENMARK AND THAILAND

A quarantine policy statement along the lines of this Policy Memorandum was provided as a basis for discussions between Mr John Anderson, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and industry representatives on 5 June 1996. At the conclusion of the meeting it was agreed that AQIS would proceed to issue a Policy Memorandum on this matter and that the draft quarantine requirements, copy attached, would be the subject of final consultation at a meeting between AQIS and the poultry industry.

AQIS has concluded its analysis of quarantine risks associated with the importation of cooked chicken meat. The draft Quarantine Requirements for the Importation of Cooked Chicken Meat (Attachment 1) are the arrangements under which importation of cooked chicken meat from the USA, Denmark and Thailand would be permitted.
A brief review of the issues raised by respondents follows.
BACKGROUND

In response to requests from the governments of USA, Denmark and Thailand for market access for their chicken meat, AQIS conducted a quarantine risk analysis. The commencement of the risk analysis was foreshadowed in a preliminary paper in 1990, which invited industry submissions. A discussion paper on uncooked and cooked chicken meat was published in April 1991 and comments were invited. After due consideration of responses AQIS decided to finalise the assessment of cooked chicken meat first with the more complex analysis of uncooked chicken meat to be GPO Box 858 Canberra ACT 2601 Tel: (06)272 4605 Fax (06)272 3399 considered subsequently. A position paper on cooked chicken meat, circulated by AQIS for consultation in June 1994, recommended that importation be permitted subject to prescribed quarantine conditions.
In the consultation phase which followed, the effectiveness of AQIS's proposed time/temperature parameters as a minimum treatment against disease agents of quarantine concern was agreed by
. the Bureau of Resource Sciences
. the Commonwealth's Chief Veterinary Officer
. the Australian Animal Health Laboratory
. the five State Agriculture Departments which responded to AQIS's position paper
. the Foreign Diseases Unit of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy
. the Australian Chicken Growers' Council
. the Australian Veterinary Association and Australian Veterinary Poultry Association
. the National Poultry Association and
. the Australian Poultry Industries Association.

Several respondents emphasised the need for effort to be made to ensure that poultry processors overseas complied consistently with the cooking and other conditions in the proposed quarantine requirements.

In addition to these concerns, poultry industries have also claimed that the economic impact of imports would harm the domestic industry. An Inter-Departmental Committee (IDC) has considered and reported upon this aspect, separate from the quarantine assessment. The IDC advised that, under the proposed AQIS protocol, the economic impact of imports would be unlikely to be so significant as to render current programs inadequate to deal with resultant pressures for industry adjustment. The Minister has encouraged the poultry industry to consider adjustment requirements and present a submission to the Government.
STANDARDS AT POULTRY PROCESSING PREMISES

In assessing foreign plants for approval to export to Australia, AQIS must have regard to standards for construction, equipment and hygienic operation which apply to comparable poultry processing plants in Australia. These domestic standards are the accepted baseline for public health and food safety in Australia. In accordance with obligations under the World Trade Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Standards, Australia may not impose a stricter standard on imported foods than currently applies to foods produced domestically, having regard to the goal of protecting health.

There are presently no uniform Australian regulatory standards for establishments processing poultry meat for domestic consumption. The Council of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Agriculture (ARMCANZ) has determined that aspects of national meat industry Codes of Practice dealing with public health will be mandated by amendment of State and Territory legislation. New standards have been written incorporating the principles of quality assurance, leaving prescriptive sections of the Codes for use as best practice guidelines, either for voluntary application as "recommended methods of compliance" with mandatory Australian Standards or by direct reference in State / Territory legislation.
The relevant Standards are:
. Australian Standard for Hygienic Production of Meat for Human Consumption,
. Australian Standard for Construction of Premises Processing Animals for Human Consumption,
. Australian Standard for Construction of Premises Processing Meat for Human Consumption and
. Australian Standard for Transportation of Meat for Human Consumption.
Copies of the Standards may be obtained from the Australian Government Publishing Service (SCARM Reports nos 53-56).

A national standard specific to hygienic production of poultry meat for human consumption, incorporating HACCP principles, is under development. When this is finalised and comes into force, it would become the relevant domestic standard for the purpose of evaluating foreign poultry plants for export to Australia.

In considering foreign plants for approval, AQIS would also take into account their compliance with relevant exporting country domestic legislation and the extent to which such foreign legislation may provide health safeguards equivalent to Australian systems. The US Poultry Products Inspection Act (1971) is an example of foreign legislation which may be considered to provide health safeguards equivalent to Australian requirements.

The National Food Authority (NFA) is presently finalising the development of a standard for the hygienic production and handling of food, incorporating HACCP principles. The NFA standard will apply nationally and will have particular relevance for production and post production handling of cooked meats.
EXPORTING PREMISES OPERATIONS

Poultry slaughter and processing plants must obtain AQIS approval prior to exporting to Australia. AQIS may inspect the plant before making a decision with regard to approval and/or may take into account existing approvals granted by competent veterinary authorities of foreign countries. The slaughter and processing establishments would be required to meet standards of construction and equipment that apply to comparable establishments in Australia.
Exporting premises must operate in accordance with HACCP principles so as to facilitate inspection and audit of slaughter, processing and product handling systems.
Processing equipment (cookers, ovens etc) must be fitted with AQIS approved systems for automatically recording time and temperature of cooking.

Officials of the veterinary authority of the country of export must be present in the plant at all times during the slaughtering of chickens and processing of cooked chicken meat intended for export to Australia. Ante-mortem and post-mortem examin ation must take place under official veterinary supervision.

Plants exporting to Australia must keep records of checks and corrective action carried out at critical control points for the production of cooked chicken meat, including thermograph records for all Australian export batches. These records must be kept by the manufacturing plant for at least 2 years and be made available to AQIS on request.
AQIS INSPECTION AND VERIFICATION
Establishments exporting cooked chicken meat to Australia may be inspected/ audited by AQIS at any time to confirm compliance with the "Quarantine Requirements".

To improve our knowledge of control systems and standards at processing plants in Thailand, AQIS will inspect and, if appropriate, approve plants nominated by the Government of Thailand. Representatives of industry and the Australian Veterinary Association with relevant technical expertise are invited to participate in the initial round of plant visits, at these organisations' expense.
An authorised quarantine officer will conduct a visual inspection of cooked chicken meat and documentation on arrival in Australia.
OTHER INGREDIENTS
Cooked chicken meat products which include other ingredients of animal or plant origin must comply with applicable Australian animal and plant quarantine requirements for these ingredients.
PUBLIC HEALTH ASPECTS

Imported cooked chicken meat must comply with the requirements of the Imported Foods Act and the Australian Food Standards Code including public health, packaging, labelling and compositional standards. Under the Imported Foods Act AQIS may sample, hold and test imported foods to confirm that the food complies with relevant Australian Food Standards Codes. Consignments remain under AQIS control until such time as inspection and analysis has been concluded. Any consignment that does not meet relevant standards or tests cannot be sold into the Australian market place.

The NFA has advised AQIS of its requirements for inspection and sampling of cooked chicken meat imports. In brief, every shipment from each supplier is to be inspected and sampled until five satisfactory test results are achieved, when testing frequency for that supplier would reduce to one of every four consignments and ultimately to one in twenty consignments, on a test and hold basis, based on satisfactory compliance with requirements. The NFA has advised that imported cooked chicken meat should be subject to analyses for Salmonella spp, Listeria monocytogenes, Campylobacter spp, antibiotics, and organochlorine/organophosphate compounds. Frozen cooked products will also be tested for Escherichia coli and coagulase-positive staphylococci. Testing for other pathogens may be added to this list on the basis of a further NFA risk assessment.

While this testing is not conducted primarily for animal quarantine purposes, it would provide relevant and valid information to confirm that the processing plant has employed good manufacturing practices. For example, clear results to laboratory tests including culture of organisms such as Salmonella spp would provide a reliable indication that post processing contamination had not occurred.
ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

Some respondents questioned whether the risk of adverse environmental impact, in the event that the importation of chicken meat were to result in an outbreak of exotic disease, merited designation of the proposal to import cooked chicken meat in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1975 (EP[IP] Act). Concerns at the potential for any disease outbreak to affect native bird species were also raised in this context.

The EP (IP) Act and the Administrative Procedures made under that Act, require the consideration of whether an action as defined in the legislation is an action which will, or is likely to, affect the environment to a significant extent or which will have the effect of permitting or facilitating an action by another person which will or is likely to result in such an effect. As decisions to permit entry of animal products, made under the Quarantine Act and consistent with Australia's conservative approach to risk, would generally be unlikely to constitute actions leading to significant adverse effects on the environment, the requirements of various environmental legislation would be generally fulfilled.

In the case of an importation of a non-viable animal product, such as cooked chicken meat, the potential for harmful impact on the environment clearly relates solely to the risk of entry of unwanted pathogenic organisms which have the potential to cause disease if the pathogen were to establish in susceptible animal populations. Through a formal process comprising technical analysis and consideration of appropriately conservative risk management options, AQIS is satisfied that a decision under the Quarantine Act to permit the importation of cooked chicken meat for human consumption is unlikely to have significant environmental implications. Consequently there is no need to designate a proponent in order to achieve the object of the EP(IP) Act.
CONCLUSION

AQIS has consulted widely and considers that all quarantine concerns have now been addressed. The proposed import conditions which were attached to AQIS's 1994 position paper have been modified to strengthen certification and verification aspects of the protocol. The 1994 paper has also been reformatted for greater clarity.
AQIS will accept comment on the attached draft quarantine requirements until 28 June. After this, comments will be considered and the requirements finalised.

QUARANTINE REQUIREMENTS FOR THE IMPORTATION OF COOKED CHICKEN MEAT
1. DOCUMENTATION

a. A permit to import de-boned cooked chicken meat/meat products*(herein referred to as cooked chicken meat) into Australia must be obtained in writing by the Australian importer from the Director of Animal and Plant Quarantine (Australia) (herein called the Director) prior to the product first being imported.
* Chicken meat refers to product which is cooked chicken meat only. Chicken meat product refers to cooked chicken meat in addition to other ingredients of animal or plant origin.
b Each application for permission to import must include the following details:
‐ name of the exporting and importing company
‐ name, address and identification/veterinary control number of the processing establishment
‐ country of origin of raw materials
‐ product type and name
‐ full details of any process of manufacture the meat has been subjected to including core temperature/time treatment processes, packaging and labelling and post processing quality control
‐ anticipated port or ports of entry
‐ container numbers (for sea cargo) and numbers of the official seals on the containers.
c Each application will be assessed on the above criteria as well as any other criterion which is considered relevant by the Director.
d Product type exported must correspond exactly to approved product.
2. REQUIREMENTS

a Certification accompanying each consignment must be endorsed by an official veterinarian in accordance with the current "Quarantine Requirements for the Importation of Cooked Chicken Meat" and will require on arrival, a "Quarantine Entry".
b. Only de-boned cooked chicken meat is permitted for importation.
c. The chickens from which the cooked chicken meat/meat products are produced must originate from the country of export.

d. The chickens must be slaughtered and the meat processed in establishments currently approved by the Director. The standard of construction and facilities of slaughter and processing establishments should be equivalent to standards that apply to comparable establishments in Australia. Product should be processed and handled in an hygienic manner and in accordance with good manufacturing practices as applied in Australia. AQIS may take into account existing approvals granted by competent veterinary authorities of foreign countries.
e. Officials of the veterinary authority of the country of export must be present in plants at all times when slaughtering chickens and processing cooked chicken meat for export to Australia.
f. Chicken meat for Australia must be processed and stored separately from all other meat products.

g. Processing equipment (cookers, ovens etc) shall be equipped with an AQIS approved system for recording time and temperature of cooking. Time and temperature records of processing for all consignments for export to Australia shall be maintained and be made available to AQIS on request.
h. While preparing product for Australia establishments must conduct slaughter and processing operations in accordance with quality assurance principles such as the HACCP approach.
i. Any ingredient of animal or plant origin present in product for export to Australia must comply with AQIS quarantine and other requirements.
Note

Imported cooked chicken meat must comply with the Imported Food Control Act 1992 and the Australian Food Standards Code under the National Food Authority Act 1991. Under this legislation, AQIS may inspect, sample, hold and test imported cooked chicken meat for microbial agents or residues of public health concern. Additional requirements regarding labelling, packaging and food composition standards must also be complied with. Information on the Australian Food Standards Code may be obtained from the National Food Authority.
3. CERTIFICATION
A certificate in English, endorsed by an official veterinarian of the exporting country, must accompany each consignment of cooked chicken meat and products.
The Official Veterinarian must certify that:

(i) the cooked chicken meat/meat product was de-boned and derived from chickens originating in the country of export and which passed ante-mortem and post-mortem inspection under official veterinary supervision;
(ii) establishment(s) where the chickens were slaughtered and the meat was processed and stored meet AQIS requirements for facilities and hygienic operation;
Note: Name(s), address(es) and veterinary control number(s) of plant(s) must be specified;
(iii) the chicken meat/meat product was heated at one of the following minimum core temperatures for the corresponding period of time.
70oC for 95 minutes or
72oC for 65 minutes or
74oC for 44 minutes or
76oC for 30 minutes or
78oC for 21 minutes or
80oC for 15 minutes
Note: The temperature/time parameter actually used must be stated;
(iv) the temperature recording equipment was checked during manufacture and was found to be in good order. Records confirm that the time/temperature parameters specified in (iii) were achieved;
(v) the cooked chicken meat/meat product complies with relevant national standards of the exporting country for control of residues and microbial agents of public health concern in food;
(vi) the cooked chicken meat/meat product for Australia was processed and stored separately from all other products;
(vii) the cooked chicken meat/meat product was packed on—---- (date), in clean, new packaging in a manner which prevented contamination;

(viii) the identification number(s) of the processing and packing establishment(s) is readily visible on the package or wrapping containing the cooked chicken meat/meat product in such a way that the numbers cannot readily be removed without damaging package or wrapping;

(ix) the cooked chicken meat/meat product is to be shipped in a clean container, the seal(s) of which are intact at the time of export and the identifying number(s) are in accordance with the import permit. This container does not contain any meat which is not eligible for export to Australia.
4. VERIFICATION
AQIS will maintain appropriate systems to verify these requirements will be complied with on an ongoing basis. Elements of this system will include:
(1) An authorised quarantine officer will conduct a visual inspection of the product and documentation on arrival in Australia:
(2) Inspection and detention of consignments and sampling/analysis of samples may be performed under the Imported food Inspection Program (IFIP);
(3) At the discretion of the Director, premises producing cooked chicken meat/meat product for export to Australia may be inspected/audited as to all aspects of compliance with these requirements.
5. REVIEW
Conditions for importation may be reviewed at any time at the discretion of the Director.
